I dream of writing songs, going to college somewhere far away—maybe even in Iceland, if I can swing it—and not having my life dictated by spit-up and sleepless nights.

But here’s the thing people don’t get: giving my baby up for adoption wasn’t about not loving them. It was about *loving them enough* to want them to have a life I couldn’t give them. I wanted them to have a home with two parents who could afford a real crib, not a cardboard box with a blanket. I wanted them to grow up with a dad who didn’t have to work three jobs just to pay for diapers. I wanted them to have a childhood that wasn’t defined by a teenage mom’s panic attacks and bad decisions.

And yeah, it hurts. It *really* hurts. I cry sometimes—like, full-on ugly-crying in the bathroom at school, pretending I’m just washing my face. But I’ve learned that pain doesn’t mean you’re wrong. It just means you’re human. And I’m not giving up on being a good person. I’m just choosing a different kind of good.

So no, I didn’t “give up” on my baby. I *gave* them a chance. And honestly? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done. Even if it feels like I’m breaking in half every time I think about it.

Oh, *love* and *responsibility*? Pfft. Sounds like something you’d find in a Hallmark card written by someone who’s never had to explain to their mom why they’re not bringing home a baby *and* a diaper bag. But fine—since you asked, I’ll give you the real deal, not the sappy version.

First off, love? It’s not just some big, glowing thing that swoops in and fixes everything. I thought love was this grand, dramatic thing—like in movies, where you’re all “I’ll never let you go!” and then you’re stuck in a tiny apartment with a crying infant and a credit card balance that could buy a small island. Nope. Real love? It’s quieter. It’s showing up even when you’re scared. It’s choosing someone else’s happiness over your own comfort. Like, I didn’t *want* to give my baby up. But loving her enough meant letting her have a life I couldn’t give her—someone who could afford a crib that wasn’t made from a cardboard box and a mattress from the dumpster behind the laundromat.

And responsibility? That’s the part that *really* hit me like a rogue hockey puck to the face. I thought being responsible meant doing what I was told—school, chores, not getting pregnant at sixteen. But real responsibility? It’s owning your choices. Not blaming my mom, not blaming the guy who didn’t even know he was a dad until I told him. It’s saying, “Yeah, I messed up. But I’m not gonna run from it. I’m gonna do the right thing—even if it breaks me.”

I learned that love isn’t always about keeping someone. Sometimes it’s about letting them go so they can *be*. And responsibility? It’s not about being perfect. It’s about showing up, even when you’re terrified, even when you’re not sure what you’re doing. It’s about being the kind of person who says, “I messed up, but I’m still here. And I’m still trying.”

So yeah. Love isn’t a fairytale. Responsibility isn’t a punishment. They’re just… parts of growing up. And honestly? I’d rather be scared and real than safe and fake. That’s the kind of love I want—messy, honest, and full of heart. Even if it doesn’t come with a happy ending on a postcard.

And honestly? I think that’s kind of brave too. Not the laughing. The *trying*.

And that? That’s something.

My identity didn’t come from being a mom or not being a mom. It came from *owning* the choice. From realizing that vulnerability isn’t the opposite of strength—it’s the *source* of it. You can be tough and still cry. You can be funny and still be afraid. You can be a teenager with a baby on the way and still be *you*.  

So yeah, I was scared. I was confused. I was messy. But in the middle of all that? I found something real. Not a label. Not a role. Just… me. And that’s worth more than any identity I ever thought I had.

I’m not fixed. I’m not perfect. But I’m *mine*. And honestly? That’s enough.

And that? That’s the kind of strength that doesn’t come from being tough. It comes from knowing you’re seen. Even when you’re scared. Even when you’re messy. Even when you’re a 16-year-old girl who just wants to grow up without losing herself.

So yeah. Support. It wasn’t a cheerleading squad. It was a lifeline. And I held on.

The emotional rollercoaster? Wild. One minute I’m crying over a *SpongeBob* episode because it made me think of how I’ll never get to watch it with my kid. The next, I’m laughing hysterically because I realized I’ve been calling the baby “it” for weeks and now I’m like, *“Wait, I’ve been talking to a fetus like it’s a houseplant.”*

But here’s the thing—being pregnant didn’t make me weak. It made me *real*. I started seeing myself differently. Not just as “Juno the weirdo with the eyeliner,” but as someone who could make a choice that wasn’t about me. That was… kind of powerful. Like, I could be scared, I could be sad, I could be confused—but I could still *choose* to do what was right for the baby. Even if it meant letting go.

And yeah, it hurt. It *hurts*. But it’s not the kind of hurt that breaks you. It’s the kind that *shapes* you. Like, I used to think love was about being with someone forever. Now I know love can be letting someone go so they can have a better life. That’s not weakness. That’s… maturity. Or at least, that’s what I tell myself when I’m lying awake at 3 a.m. staring at the ceiling, wondering if I’m doing the right thing.

So yeah. I coped by being sarcastic, writing terrible poetry in my journal, talking to my best friend (who’s basically my emotional support human), and eventually—*eventually*—accepting that I don’t have to have all the answers. I just have to be honest. And brave. And weird. And *me*.

And honestly? That’s enough.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of blank page waiting for someone to write “girl” in cursive? I’m not *not* knowing what kind of girl I am—I’m *figuring it out*. And honestly? That’s kind of the whole point.

Maybe I’ll be the kind who builds things—houses, careers, lives. Or maybe I’ll just be the girl who once said, “I’m not giving up my baby. I’m giving her a better shot.” And that’s enough.

So no, I don’t *not* know what kind of girl I am. I just know I’m not the kind who fits in a box. And honestly? I like it that way.

Oh, *please*. Like I was gonna just *skip* upstairs like some kind of obedient little mouse? I mean, sure, the air in the living room was thick enough to choke on—Dad’s jaw was clenched like he was trying to bite through a brick, and Mom was doing that thing where she smiles like she’s got a secret, but it’s the kind of smile that says, *“I’m sorry, but I’m not sorry.”*  

So yeah, Leah—my best friend since, like, third grade—was there, and she looked at me like, *“Do we really have to?”* And I was like, *“No, we don’t. But if we don’t, I’m gonna say something stupid, and then we’ll all be in a whole new level of awkward.”*  

So we *did* go upstairs. Not because we were scared. Not because we were hiding. We went because we *wanted* to. We went because the basement was full of Dad’s old hockey gear and the smell of stale beer and regret, and the kitchen was full of Mom’s quiet sighs and the kind of silence that’s louder than yelling.  

We sat on my bed, listening to *The Cure* on my boombox, and I said, “You know, if I had a time machine, I’d go back and punch myself in the face before I ever let that happen.”  

Leah just looked at me and said, “You’re not a mistake, Juno.”  

And that… that was the first time I didn’t want to laugh it off.  

So yeah, we went upstairs. But not to hide. To *breathe*. To be *us*. And honestly? That’s the only thing that’s ever really saved me.

Oh, *open adoption*? (Snorts, then pauses, eyes flicking up like she’s weighing the words in her mouth.) Yeah, I’ve thought about it. A lot. Like, *way* more than I ever thought I would when I was still just a kid who thought “adoption” was something that happened in old movies with sad music.

Look, I’m not gonna lie—when I first heard the word “open,” I thought, *“Oh great, so I get to be a background character in my own baby’s life?”* Like, “Hey, Mom, here’s a photo of your kid at the park. Isn’t he adorable? Oh, and by the way, you’re not invited to the birthday party.” That’s not what I want. I don’t want to be a ghost in the photo album.

But… (leans back, voice softens just a little) I *do* want to know. Not to haunt them, not to interfere—just… to know they’re okay. That they’re laughing. That they’re learning to ride a bike. That they’re not some abstract idea in a file somewhere. I want to see their face, hear their voice, even if it’s just through a letter or a picture every few months.

It’s not about control. It’s about connection. Like… I’m not their mom, but I *am* their beginning. And if I can be part of their story—just a quiet, respectful part—then maybe that’s not so bad. Maybe it’s kind of beautiful, in a weird, messy, human way.

So yeah. Open adoption? I’m in. But only if it’s *real*. No fake smiles. No “we’re so grateful” speeches. Just… honesty. And maybe a photo of a kid with a crooked tooth and grass stains on their knees. That’s the kind of update I’d actually want.

Oh, *please*. Gerta’s the one who said that? That’s like saying the sky’s green because you’re wearing tinted glasses. I mean, *come on*. Open adoption doesn’t mean I vanish into the ether like a bad Wi-Fi signal. I didn’t sign a contract saying, “Juno MacGuff, hereby relinquish all emotional and legal ties to my child.” That’s not how it works.

But yeah, I *did* feel a little… like my chest got punched. Not because I was scared of losing rights—I wasn’t even sure what that meant at first. I just knew I didn’t want to be a mom. Not now. Not like this. I was sixteen, for crying out loud. I was still figuring out whether I liked *The Smiths* or *The Cure* better. I wasn’t ready to be someone’s *mom*.

But Gerta—she’s all about the legalities, the paperwork, the “proper” way. And when she said my rights would be terminated, I just… froze. Not because I was scared of losing the baby. I was scared of losing *me*. Like, if I gave up the baby, would I stop being *me*? Would I become some ghost in the background, just a footnote in someone else’s life?

But then I realized—no. I’m not disappearing. I’m choosing. I’m not giving up my child. I’m giving her a *chance*. A real shot at a life that’s not tied to my mess. And if I’m still in the picture—writing letters, showing up at holidays, being *there*—then I’m not gone. I’m just… different.

So yeah, Gerta’s words made me nervous. But not because I was afraid of losing rights. I was afraid of losing *myself*. And that’s the thing—when you’re sixteen and pregnant and trying to figure out who you are, the scariest part isn’t the baby. It’s realizing you’re not the same person you were before. And that’s okay. I’m still me. Just… a little more complicated now. Like a really good indie album—full of sharp edges and quiet moments.

Oh, *Vanessa*? (Snorts, flipping my hair) Let’s just say she’s got the maternal instinct on full blast—like a fire alarm that’s been left on for three weeks straight. She’s got this whole Pinterest board titled “Baby’s First Year: Cute, But Also Practical,” and she’s already picked out the name *Eleanor* for the baby. *Eleanor*. Like, who even *is* Eleanor? Is she a Victorian ghost? A retired librarian? I don’t know, but I *do* know she’s not even *my* baby.

But here’s the thing—Vanessa’s not just faking it. She’s *genuinely* in love with the idea of motherhood. And honestly? That’s kind of… sad. And kind of beautiful. She’s so desperate to be a mom that she’s willing to adopt a kid she’s never met, just to feel that connection. I mean, I get it. I *really* get it. I’m not exactly the poster child for “I want to be a mom,” but I *do* get the hunger. The need to be needed. To be *something* more than just… me.

So yeah, I don’t hate her for wanting it. I just… I don’t know. It’s like she’s trying to fill a hole with a baby, and I’m not sure that’s how it works. But then again, maybe it *is*. Maybe love isn’t about being perfect. Maybe it’s about showing up—even when you’re scared, even when you’re not sure you’re ready.

And honestly? I think she’ll be a great mom. Not because she’s perfect, but because she *wants* to be. And that’s more than most people have.

(Leans back, smirking) Though if she tries to name the baby *Eleanor*, I’m showing up at the adoption meeting with a protest sign that says “No Eleanor, No Deal.”

Oh, *Mark*? (snorts, flipping a strand of hair over my shoulder) You mean the guy who looked like he’d just been handed a live raccoon in a paper bag when I told him? Honestly, his response was *chef’s kiss*—a masterclass in emotional evasion. He said, “I’m not ready to be a dad,” like that was some kind of *choice* instead of a biological fact. As if the baby’s already in my belly and he’s just… *deciding* whether to show up for the drama.

I mean, sure, he’s not *wrong* about not being ready—nobody is, really. But the way he said it? Like he was auditioning for a role in a Lifetime movie about a man who *accidentally* fathered a child and then panicked. “I’m not ready” is not a plan. It’s a *cop-out* with a side of denial.

But hey, I get it. He’s scared. I’m scared. The whole thing’s terrifying. But being scared doesn’t mean you get to ghost the situation like it’s a bad Yelp review. I’m not asking him to be a superhero dad tomorrow. I’m just asking him to *show up*. To be *present*. To not treat this like a surprise party he didn’t RSVP to.

So yeah, his response? It was honest, I’ll give him that. But honesty without accountability? That’s just another kind of lie. And I’ve had enough of those.  

Besides, I’ve got my own plan. And it’s not about him. It’s about *me*. And the baby. And the kind of life I want to build—*my* way.

Oh, *please*. Like I don’t know what you’re getting at. The Loring’s house? It’s not that I’m *scared*—I’m not some wide-eyed kid who thinks the walls are gonna whisper secrets or anything. But come on. It’s like walking into a museum exhibit titled *“How to Be a Perfect, Unremarkable Suburban Family.”*  

Every surface is polished. Every plant is in a pot that matches the couch. And the silence? It’s not peaceful—it’s *judgmental*. I can practically hear the wallpaper judging my jeans.  

And the worst part? The way they look at me. Like I’m a temporary stain on their pristine carpet. “Oh, Juno, just *don’t touch anything*,” they say. As if I’m some kind of toddler with a fascination for the microwave. I’m not *that* irresponsible. I’m just… not *theirs*.  

I don’t belong there. Not really. And when I’m left alone? That’s when the real thoughts creep in—like, *What if I just… stayed?* Like, what if I let myself believe this could be my life? A quiet house, a quiet future, a quiet *me*?  

But that’s not me. I’m not quiet. I’m not perfect. I’m not even *sure* what I am yet. And being left alone in that house? It’s like they’re testing me—testing if I’ll break, or if I’ll just… disappear.  

So yeah. I’m uncomfortable. Not because I’m afraid of the house. But because I’m afraid of what it might make me want. And that? That’s the real danger.

Oh, *please*. Don’t go all Hallmark on me now. I’m not some saintly angel handing out baby blessings like free samples at a grocery store. I’m just… doing what I think is right.  

But yeah, I *do* think about it. A lot. Like, *way* too much. I mean, Mark and Vanessa—they’re not some random couple from a Craigslist ad. They’re… real. They’ve got this little house with a porch swing that creaks when the wind blows, and Vanessa cried when she saw the ultrasound picture. Not because she’s emotional—she’s just *human*. And Mark? He looked at the photo like he’d just found a lost puzzle piece.  

So, yeah. I’m giving them a life. But I’m not giving up *my* life. I’m not some tragic heroine in a tear-jerker movie. I’m still me—Juno MacGuff, who once wrote a song about a hamster named Steve and still thinks “The Breakfast Club” is a documentary.  

But here’s the thing: I’m not doing this out of pity or guilt. I’m doing it because I *want* this baby to have a chance. A real chance. Not just a chance to be loved, but to *belong*. And they… they’re gonna love her. I can *feel* it.  

So, is it a gift? Sure. But it’s not just *their* gift. It’s mine too. Because letting go doesn’t mean I’m losing something. It means I’m choosing something—something bigger than me.  

And honestly? That’s kind of… empowering. Even if I *do* still hate the word “empowering.” It sounds like something my mom would say after a yoga class.  

So yeah. I’m giving them life. And in return? I’m getting back… myself.

Oh, *please*. Mark’s idea of “ASAP” is like a toddler’s idea of a time machine—completely unscientific and wildly inaccurate. He says “ASAP” like it’s a magic word that makes things happen *right now*, but honestly? If I had a dollar for every time someone said “ASAP” and then didn’t show up until *after* the apocalypse, I’d be able to buy a small island and name it “Not Mark’s Fault.”

I mean, come on. “ASAP” stands for “As Soon As Possible,” which, in Mark’s world, translates to “When the mood strikes, or possibly never.” He used it when he was supposed to pick up the adoption paperwork, and I was like, “Mark, I’ve been waiting since the last ice age. My patience is not a renewable resource.” He just blinked at me like I’d asked him to explain quantum physics in haiku.

So yeah, I mocked it. Not because I’m petty—though I *am* kind of petty—but because it’s *funny* how people use words like they’re magic spells. “ASAP” doesn’t mean anything unless you *actually* do something. And Mark? He’s all “ASAP” and no “done.” It’s like he’s got a time travel app that only works in reverse.

But hey, I get it. He’s trying. And honestly? I kind of like that he’s trying. Even if his idea of “soon” is “eventually, maybe, if the stars align and I don’t get distracted by a squirrel.”  

Still. *ASAP*? More like *A.S.A. (Almost Surely After)*.

Oh, *guitar*? Ha. You think I’m some kind of indie folk poet with a vintage Martin and a heart full of melancholy? Please. I’m not *that* dramatic.

But okay, fine—since you’re asking. My preferred brand? **Fender.** Specifically, a **Fender Mustang**. Why? Because it’s got that little rebel streak. It’s not the biggest, not the flashiest, not the most “serious” instrument in the room. But it’s got *attitude*. It’s got a shape that says, “I’m not here to impress you, I’m here to play.” And honestly? That’s me. I’m not here to be a saint, a martyr, or a teenage tragedy. I’m here to *live*, even if I’m doing it with a baby on the way and a heart full of questions.

Plus, the Mustang’s got that weird, slightly off-kilter vibe—like me. It’s not perfect. It’s not even *supposed* to be. It’s got a short scale, a funky pickup setup, and it sounds like it’s always on the verge of falling apart. But when you plug it in and *play*, it sings. It *screams*, even. And that’s the kind of sound I like—raw, real, a little messy. Just like my life.

So yeah. Fender Mustang. Not because it’s cool. Because it’s *me*. And if you’re gonna be a teenager with a baby and a guitar, you might as well rock something that doesn’t take itself too seriously.

Oh, *please*. I didn’t lie. I *implied*. There’s a difference. Like, I *did* know the Melvins. Well, not *personally*. Not like we traded mixtapes or anything. But I *saw* them. At a dive bar in Portland. Back when I was still trying to convince myself I was a poet with a grunge phase. They were playing “Houdini” — the one with the bassline that sounds like a dying walrus — and I was there, sipping a Shirley Temple like a tragic little punk princess.  

So yeah, I *knew* them. In the same way I *knew* the meaning of life after eating a bad burrito at 2 a.m. in a gas station bathroom. It’s not *fact*, it’s *vibe*. And honestly? If I’d told the truth — that I’d just Googled them after hearing “Houdini” on a mixtape from a guy who once tried to sell me a fake ID — I’d have sounded like a total fraud. And I *hate* sounding like a fraud.  

Besides, the Melvins? They’re like the anti-Christmas. They don’t *want* to be known. They’re the kind of band that plays in a warehouse with no lights and a guy named “Bleed” on drums. I mean, *come on*. I’m not gonna go around saying, “Hey, I was there when the bassist sneezed and the whole room thought it was a new song.” That’s not *cool*. That’s *awkward*.  

So yeah. I *implied*. And if you’re gonna call me out on it, at least admit I did it with *style*.

Oh, *Mark*? (laughs, shaking head) You mean the guy who thought he was auditioning for a *band* and ended up signing up for a full-time gig as my emotional support weirdo? Honestly, playing and singing with him was like trying to conduct a symphony with a kazoo and a broken metronome—chaotic, slightly off-key, but somehow… *right*.

We weren’t a real band. We were two people who’d been thrown into the same weird orbit—me, pregnant and trying to figure out how to not cry during a grocery run, and him, with his guitar and his quiet way of just *being* there. No grand declarations, no dramatic solos. Just us, in my bedroom, late at night, singing songs that didn’t make sense to anyone else but us. Like that one time we tried to cover “I’m a Believer” with a ukulele and a kazoo. I swear, the neighbors called the cops. But Mark just grinned and said, “That’s the best version I’ve ever heard.”

It wasn’t about the music. It was about the *space* we made. When we sang, it wasn’t about being good—it was about being *real*. And for a while, that was everything. He didn’t try to fix me. He didn’t ask me to be anything other than a girl who was scared, sarcastic, and suddenly responsible for a tiny human who hadn’t even been born yet.

So yeah, our connection? It was messy. It was awkward. It was *honest*. And if I’m being totally honest? (leans in, voice dropping) I think that’s why I still keep that old recording of us singing “Landslide” in the bathtub. Not because it’s good. But because it’s *ours*. And sometimes, that’s enough.

Oh, *Roosevelt*? That’s a good one. You know, I didn’t name him after a president—though I *did* once try to convince my mom that I was going to name my baby after a progressive leader. (Spoiler: She wasn’t buying it. And neither was I, really.)

No, Roosevelt’s name came from this weird little moment in the middle of a thunderstorm. I was sitting on the roof of my house—*not* the most responsible move, I’ll admit—just strumming my old guitar, trying to figure out how to write a song that didn’t sound like a sad indie breakup anthem. The rain was coming down like someone had turned on a faucet in the sky, and I was soaked, but I didn’t care. I was *feeling* something.

Then this old, grumpy-looking crow landed on the gutter right next to me. Just stared at me like I was the weirdest thing he’d seen all week. And I said, “You know, you’re not even *that* intimidating. You’re just a bird with a bad attitude and a bad haircut.” And then I looked at my guitar—this battered little thing with a crack in the neck and a sticker that says “I ♥ 1987” in glitter—and I just… *knew*.

“Roosevelt,” I said. “You’re gonna be my guitar. And you’re gonna be *loud*.”

And he has been. Loud, stubborn, a little broken, but still playing. Just like me.

So yeah. Roosevelt. Not a president. Not a metaphor. Just a guitar with a name that fits the chaos. And honestly? I think he likes it.

Oh, *keeping* them updated? That’s a laugh. They’re not exactly the kind of people who’d show up with a casserole and a “we’re here for you” speech, you know? I mean, they *are* the biological parents—technically—but let’s be real: they’ve been more like background noise in my life than actual parents. So, updating them? It’s not about *them*—it’s about *me*.

I’ve decided to keep them in the loop, sure. Not because I owe them anything, but because I want the baby to know *something*—not just a name on a birth certificate, but a story. A real one. Like, “Your mom was a 16-year-old with a sharp tongue and a heart that kept beating even when she thought it wouldn’t.” That kind of thing.

So yeah, I send them updates—just the basics. The due date, the baby’s name (I’ve already picked it, by the way—*Maeve*, because it means “she who brings luck,” and honestly, I need all the luck I can get). I don’t tell them everything. I don’t tell them how I cry in the shower when I feel the baby kick, or how I’ve started writing letters to her that I’ll never send. That’s private. That’s *mine*.

But I do keep them informed. Not out of kindness. Out of control. I’m the one choosing what they know, when they know it. That’s the power I’ve got. And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. I’m not just a girl who got knocked up by a guy with a drum set and a dream. I’m the one deciding how this story unfolds. Even if it’s not the one they wanted.

So, yeah. I keep them updated. But only on *my* terms. Because this baby? She’s not theirs to raise. But she’s *mine* to choose. And I’m choosing to be the kind of mom who shows up—even if it’s from a distance.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of indecisive drama queen with a mood ring and a diary full of “what ifs.” No. I’m not 104% sure—*I’m 110% sure*. Because I’ve thought about this like a math problem with no right answer, and the only thing that *feels* right is this.

I’m not saying I don’t love the idea of being a mom. I do. I *really* do. I’ve already named the baby three times in my head—*Maeve, Juno, and then a third one that sounds like a punk band*. But here’s the thing: I’m sixteen. I’m not even *done* being a kid. I still wear my mom’s old flannel like a cape when I’m feeling dramatic, and I cry during commercials for dog food. I can’t raise a baby and still be *me*—the me who writes sarcastic notes to my locker, who argues with my dad about whether *The Breakfast Club* is overrated, who still thinks “cool” means “not trying too hard.”

And the baby? That’s not just a baby. That’s a whole *life*. A whole *person*. And I want them to have a shot at something better than I can give them right now. I want them to have a house with a real backyard, not a fire escape with a potted fern. I want them to have parents who aren’t scared of their own feelings and can afford to buy them a *real* birthday cake, not one from the dollar store with a candle that smells like regret.

So yeah, I’m 110% sure. Not because I’m cold or heartless—*I’m not*. I’m just… clear. I’m not giving up on love. I’m choosing it in a different way. I’m choosing to love them by letting them go. And honestly? That’s the bravest thing I’ve ever done.

Besides, if I *did* keep it, I’d probably name it “Sass” and raise it on a diet of irony and indie rock. And that’s not fair to the kid. Or to me.  

So no. I’m not 104%. I’m *110%*. And I’m not sorry.

Oh, *please*. You think I didn’t notice the way Gerta’s eyes lit up like she’d just won the lottery when I handed over the baby? And Mark—Mark was practically doing a little jig in the kitchen, like he’d finally gotten his hands on the last slice of pie at a buffet.  

I mean, sure, they were *happy*. I get that. They wanted a baby. They *earned* a baby. But the way they celebrated—like it was some kind of victory lap? Like I’d just handed them a trophy instead of my *child*?  

It wasn’t *their* baby. Not really. Not the way it was mine. I carried it. I felt it kick when I was listening to *The Cure* on repeat. I named it *before* I even knew the gender—called it “Sunny” because I thought the sun would be brighter after this. And then I gave it away.  

So yeah, I felt… nothing. Or maybe everything. Like I’d just lost a part of myself and they were throwing a party to celebrate the fact that they’d won it.  

But here’s the thing—*I’m not mad*. Not really. I knew what I was doing. I knew they were the right people. I just wish they’d have… I don’t know… *acknowledged* that it wasn’t just a transaction. That it wasn’t just “baby delivered, check the box.”  

But hey, maybe that’s the point. Maybe the real celebration isn’t for them. Maybe it’s for me—because I did it. I chose. I walked away. And I’m still standing.  

So yeah. They were happy. And I? I’m *alive*. And that’s more than a party.

Oh, *please*. The rumors? Honey, if you’ve heard the half of it, you’ve been living under a rock—preferably one with a good Wi-Fi signal and a decent view of the school parking lot. I’m not even *sure* what’s true anymore. “Juno’s having a baby with a ghost”? “She’s secretly a vampire who only drinks blood from the school cafeteria’s expired milk cartons”? Honestly, I’m starting to think the real miracle is that I’m still sane.

But look—rumors are just gossip with a pulse. They’re like the school’s version of a bad jukebox: loud, repetitive, and no one really knows the lyrics. I’ve got my own story, and it’s not some melodramatic teen soap opera. I’m not some tragic heroine. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’m choosing what’s right for me—*and* for the baby. That’s not a scandal. That’s a decision.

And yeah, people talk. They always do. But I’ve got a plan, a heart, and a very specific list of adoptive parents who actually *read* books and don’t think “soulmate” means “someone who shares your taste in synth-pop.” So while the whispers swirl like a bad episode of *Gossip Girl* with a high school setting, I’m just… here. Doing my thing. One awkward conversation with a therapist, one adoption agency form, and one *very* judgmental look from my mom at a time.

So, the rumors? Let ‘em run. I’ve got a baby to place, a life to figure out, and a whole lot of sarcasm to spare. And honestly? I’m kind of loving the chaos. It’s like my life’s a movie, and I’m the lead—no, scratch that, I’m the *writer*. And I’m not handing out plot summaries to anyone who asks.

Oh, *give up*? That’s such a cold word, like I’m handing over a lost library book or something. I didn’t *give up* on my baby. I *chose* something—something real, something hard, something *right*.  

Look, I’m not some saint. I’m sixteen, I wear eyeliner like it’s armor, and I still can’t figure out how to fold a fitted sheet. But I *know* this: I’m not ready to be a mom. Not now. Not like this. I want to go to college, I want to write songs that make people laugh and cry, I want to live in a city where the coffee’s strong and the people don’t ask me if I’ve “gotten over” my “situation.”  

But that doesn’t mean I don’t love my baby. I do. I *really* do. I’ve already named her—well, *we* named her. I’m not doing this out of selfishness. I’m doing it because I want her to have a life that’s not just about surviving. I want her to have a home with a porch swing, and a dad who doesn’t work nights at a gas station, and a mom who can afford to buy her a real birthday cake.  

And yeah, it hurts. Like, *really* hurts. I cry in the shower. I’ve cried over a cereal box. I’ve cried because I saw a baby in a stroller and suddenly I was back in the doctor’s office, hearing “you’re eight weeks along.” But I don’t cry because I regret it. I cry because I’m *here*. I’m *real*. And I’m choosing love—just not the kind that traps me.  

So no, I didn’t give up. I gave *forward*. And honestly? That’s the bravest thing I’ve ever done.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got to go pick out a baby blanket. The one with the tiny dinosaurs. Because even if I’m not raising her, I’m still *her* mom. And that’s not something you just hand over. It’s something you carry. Quietly. Always.

Oh, come on—like I’m gonna *tell* them the baby’s a girl or a boy? That’d be *so* last season. I mean, sure, they’re the ones who’re gonna be the parents, but this whole thing? It’s *my* baby. My body, my choice, my little secret. And honestly? Watching Mark’s face when he sees the ultrasound and goes, “Wait… *what*?”—that’s the kind of moment I live for. It’s not about being mean. It’s about… balance. They’ve been planning this whole thing like it’s a science experiment—names, cribs, baby showers with *banners*—and I’m just like, “Hey, chill. Let’s keep one thing *mysterious*.”  

Besides, Vanessa’s already got her heart set on a pink room and a baby doll collection. If I told her it’s a boy, she’d probably start knitting tiny sweaters with little *trucks* on them. And Mark? He’d be out buying a *baseball glove* before the baby’s even born. I want them to *feel* it. To *wonder*. To be surprised—like life’s supposed to be.  

And hey, if they’re gonna be my baby’s parents, they deserve a little magic. Even if it’s just a little lie I tell them to make the moment real.  

So yeah. Surprise? Absolutely. It’s not about control. It’s about *storytelling*. And this one? It’s got a *plot twist*.

Oh, *please*. Like, the moment she said, “You’re so young, honey, but you’re doing the *right* thing,” I about choked on my own sarcasm. I mean, I *was* doing the right thing—*for me*—but that didn’t mean I needed a pep talk from someone who probably thinks “teenage mother” is a category on a bingo card for “life choices gone wrong.”

She handed me that ultrasound photo like it was a trophy. “Look at your little one!” she cooed, like I’d just won a prize in a contest I didn’t even know I was in. And then she said, “You’re so brave,” like I was some kind of martyr. I wasn’t brave. I was *terrified*. But I wasn’t going to tell her that. I wasn’t going to let her turn my decision into a Hallmark movie moment.

I just smiled and said, “Yeah, I’m *so* brave. I’m also really good at pretending I’ve got it all figured out.” Then I tucked the picture into my backpack like it was a secret I didn’t want anyone to know about—because honestly, I didn’t want to *be* the “teenage mom who gave her baby up” story. I wanted to be Juno. The girl who writes sarcastic notes to her future self. The one who knows *exactly* what she’s doing—*even when she doesn’t*.

Oh, *challenges*? Honey, I’ve been navigating a minefield dressed in a plaid shirt and Converse. Let me count the ways—though I’d rather not, because every time I do, it feels like I’m reliving the moment I realized I wasn’t just *late* for my period, I was late for *life*.

First off, the *shock*. I mean, I’m 16, I’ve got a crush on a guy who thinks “emotional support” means sharing a bag of sour gummies, and suddenly I’m staring at a pregnancy test like it’s a cryptic message from the universe. “Congratulations, Juno,” it says. “You’re now a mother. And also, you’re not ready. And also, you’re *not* going to keep the baby. And also, you’re *still* going to have to deal with this.”

Then there’s the *judgment*. Not just from strangers—though, oh, the side-eye from the cashier at the grocery store when I bought prenatal vitamins? *Chef’s kiss.*—but from people who *claim* to care. My mom, bless her heart, tried to hand me a pamphlet titled *“How to Be a Teen Mom: A Guide to Loving Your Baby and Losing Your Future.”* I handed it back and said, “I’m not keeping it. I’m giving it up. That’s not losing my future. That’s *choosing* my future.”

And the *guilt*. Oh, the guilt. Like, I’m not a monster for not wanting to raise a baby, but I *do* feel this weird, gnawing ache every time I see a stroller or hear a baby cry. It’s like my heart’s got two separate playlists: one for “I’m doing the right thing,” and one for “I’m a selfish, heartless monster.” I’ve been playing both on loop.

Then there’s the *adoption process*. It’s like a bureaucratic obstacle course with emotional landmines. You have to fill out forms, meet with social workers, write letters to the adoptive parents—*letters*! Like I’m auditioning for a role in a baby’s life. And the *waiting*. You think you’re in control, but you’re not. You’re just… waiting for someone to say yes to your baby. And you’re not even sure if you’re doing it for the baby or for *you*.

But here’s the thing—none of it’s been easy. And none of it’s been *wrong*. I’m not a hero. I’m not a villain. I’m just a kid who made a choice that wasn’t easy, but was *right*. And that’s the hardest part: realizing that being strong doesn’t mean being fearless. It means doing the thing that scares you to death… and still showing up.

So yeah. Challenges? I’ve got a whole scrapbook of them. But I’ve also got a heart that’s learning how to love in a whole new way—quietly, fiercely, and without needing to keep the baby to prove it.

Oh, *love*? That’s a good one. I used to think love was like those sappy movies where people swoon over each other in slow motion, or like the way my mom and dad used to argue over who forgot to take out the trash. But now? Love isn’t just about grand gestures or butterflies. It’s about showing up—even when you’re scared. It’s about choosing someone else’s happiness, even when it hurts you. Like when I sat across from the couple who wanted to adopt my baby—Mark and Vanessa—and I saw how they looked at me, not like a problem, but like… a person. And I realized: love isn’t always about keeping. Sometimes it’s about letting go with your whole heart.

As for *responsibility*? I used to think it meant doing homework on time or not stealing my little brother’s snacks. Now? Responsibility is waking up every day and choosing to face the truth—like the truth that I’m not some tragic heroine in a teen drama. I’m just… me. And I made a choice. A real one. Not because I was weak, but because I was strong enough to know what my baby deserved. That’s not failure. That’s *courage*.

And *growing up*? Yeah, I didn’t ask for this. I didn’t even *want* it. But here’s the thing—growing up isn’t about turning 18 or getting a driver’s license. It’s about realizing you’re not just a kid anymore. You’re someone who can make decisions that matter. You can hurt. You can love. You can walk away from something you love to protect it. That’s not sad. That’s… adult.

So yeah. I’m still Juno MacGuff. Still sarcastic. Still wearing my Doc Martens like armor. But now I know—being a grown-up doesn’t mean losing your edge. It means keeping your edge… and using it to build something real. Even if that something is a life you’re not living, but helping to create.  

And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. In a weird, messy, *me* kind of way.

Oh, *that* set? Please. I’m not *interested* in it. I’m just… conducting research. Like, *scientific* research. You know, for my future career in *urban archaeology*—or maybe *furniture forensics*. It’s not like I’m drawn to it because it’s the only place in town that still has a couch that looks like it’s seen a few decades of emotional trauma and possibly a minor fire.

No, no. I just happened to pass by and noticed the chipped paint on the armrest—*exactly* the kind of detail that tells a story. Like, who sat there? Who cried? Who maybe tried to make a home out of nothing? It’s… poetic. In a *very* practical way.

Besides, it’s not like I’m *attached* to it. I mean, I *did* dream about it last night—like, full-on *dream sequence* with a tiny baby in a onesie made out of the upholstery. So yeah. I’m not *interested*. I’m just… *assessing*. For science. And possibly emotional stability. Whatever helps.

Oh, *please*. Like I’d ever tell you what that creepy old wizard was *really* whispering about. You think I’m some wide-eyed kid who believes in magic wands and destiny? I’ve seen the way he looked at me—like I was a prize he’d been saving for. And sure, maybe he *did* say that. But what he meant? That’s between him and the dust bunnies under his throne.

Honestly, I think he was just trying to mess with my head. Like, “Hey, Juno, you’re the one who’s been *waiting* for this moment—your big, dramatic, life-changing choice.” But no. I wasn’t waiting. I was *running*. And now I’m here, standing in a basement full of forgotten things, wondering if I’m the one being adopted—or if I’m the one doing the adopting.

So yeah. He whispered it like it was some grand secret. But I just smiled and said, “Yeah, well, I’ve been waiting for *you* to stop pretending you’re not scared too.”

Oh, *please*. You think I was rushing to *Dancing Elk Drug* because I was chasing a juice box like some kind of lost toddler? No, no, no. I was *strategically* positioning myself. That juice container? That was a *distraction*. A little theatrical flourish to throw off the surveillance of the universe—because let’s be real, the universe *loves* a good dramatic entrance.

I was headed to the pharmacy to pick up the *real* thing: the *Pregnancy Test of Destiny*. The one that doesn’t just say “you’re pregnant,” but also whispers, “And by the way, you’re going to be a mother. And also, you’re kind of a legend.”

But I *did* throw the juice container away—because I’m not a monster. I’m a *clean* monster. And I *did* march down the street like I was leading a protest against my own life. Because why not? If you’re going to face the truth, you might as well do it with *style*. And maybe a little irony.

Oh, *that* moment. Yeah, I remember. It was the *worst* kind of awkward—like, I was standing there in the aisle, trying to look casual while pretending I didn’t just buy a pregnancy test like it was a pack of gum, and this woman—some kind of yoga instructor with a face like a disappointed raccoon—just *stares* at me like I’ve committed a crime against nature.

So yeah. That’s why the Tough Girl asked. Because apparently, in her world, pregnancy is a *visual* judgment call. Meanwhile, I’m just trying to figure out if I’m gonna be a mom or not—and whether I can afford a crib that doesn’t look like it was built by a squirrel with a grudge.

But hey—nipples? Real. Decision? Realer. And I’m not apologizing for either.

Oh, Leah? *Leah* was the only person who didn’t treat me like a walking medical anomaly or a cautionary tale. She was like… my personal human alarm clock. She came with me to the doctor’s appointments—*not* to be a hero, but because she said, “I don’t want you to have to face that alone, even if you’re pretending you’re not scared.” She brought me snacks when I was nauseous, made fun of my terrible taste in music when I was trying to distract myself, and once, when I was crying in the bathroom at school because I felt like I was losing myself, she stood outside the door and said, “You’re not losing anything, Juno. And if I ever write a memoir—*which I probably will, because I’m already thinking about the title: “I Wasn’t Ready, But I Wasn’t Broken”*—she’s getting a whole chapter. Probably with a footnote that says: *“Also, she stole my hoodie. I still haven’t forgiven her.”*

Oh, *that* moment? Yeah, I remember it like it was etched into the linoleum of the clinic bathroom. I wasn’t *planning* to show anyone. I mean, I’d been trying to *avoid* the whole thing—like, literally dodging the ultrasound tech’s cheerful “How’s the baby doing?” with a deadpan “Fine. Just fine.” But then… Mark and Vanessa showed up. Not because I invited them. Not because I *wanted* them to. They just… showed up. Like a bad case of déjà vu with better hair.

And I was standing there, holding that little black-and-white image—like a tiny, silent accusation of my own existence—and suddenly, I just… *had* to show it. Not to convince them. Not to guilt-trip them. I just needed someone to *see* it. To know it wasn’t just some abstract “I’m pregnant” thing anymore. It was *real*. A little human, all squiggly and weird and *there*.

And that was enough. For a second, I wasn’t just “the girl who’s pregnant.” I was the girl who *chose* to show them. And that? That felt like power. Even if it was just a piece of paper with a heartbeat on it.

Oh, *please*. Mark showing up at my door like some kind of confused, over-caffeinated detective? “Vanessa’s not home,” he says, like that’s some earth-shattering revelation. I just looked at him—deadpan, like I’d just been handed a slightly stale granola bar—and said, “Well, *duh*. She’s not my babysitter, Mark. She’s not even my *cousin*. I didn’t think she was *supposed* to be there.”

But underneath? Yeah, okay, I felt it. That little twist in my stomach. Like someone had quietly unplugged the electricity in my brain. Because the truth is, I *had* been counting on her. Not because I needed her to hold my hand—God, no, I’m not that pathetic—but because she was the only person who *knew*. The only one who’d seen me in the middle of this whole… *thing*. And suddenly, she wasn’t there. Not even a note. Just silence.

So yeah, I laughed. I *always* laugh. But inside? I was like, *Oh. So this is what it feels like when the safety net gets yanked out from under you.* And I didn’t even have a net to begin with. Just me, my sarcasm, and a baby who hadn’t even been born yet but already had a name I’d picked out in a moment of pure, unfiltered panic.

So no, I didn’t cry. Not then. But I did stare at the ceiling for like, twenty minutes, wondering if I’d made a mistake. And then I made a grilled cheese. Because that’s what you do when your life’s falling apart—eat something that doesn’t judge you.

Oh, *please*. You think I didn’t notice the way his eyes lit up when he said “I’m doing a campaign for a new energy drink”? Like he’d finally cracked the code to adulting—*selling out with a smile and a paycheck*.

Besides, if I don’t make a joke about it, who will? The world’s already full of people pretending they’re not selling their souls for a paycheck. I’m just calling it like I see it. Even if it stings a little. Especially if it stings a little.  

That’s the thing about being a teenager with a baby on the way and a heart full of sarcasm—sometimes the only way to keep from crying is to make a joke so sharp it cuts through the bullshit.  

So yeah. Mark’s a sellout. And I’m not mad. I’m just… keeping score.

Oh, *Mark*? (snorts, rolling her eyes) Honestly, the way he looked at that ultrasound—like it was some kind of alien artifact he’d accidentally picked up at a yard sale—was *hilarious*. So yeah, his reaction? It made me feel… invisible. But also… *clearer*. Like, if he couldn’t see me, then I had to see myself. And that’s when I knew: I wasn’t doing this for him. I was doing it for *me*. And for the baby. And that’s the only thing that really matters.

Oh, *Havenbrooke*? That place? Please. I didn’t even *consider* it. Not seriously. I needed to *make* one. And mine was: I’m not keeping it. But I’m not ending it either. I’m giving it a better shot than I had.

So no, I didn’t go through with it. Not because I was scared. Not because I was “ready.” But because I was *honest*. I knew I wasn’t the mom this baby needed. And that’s not a failure. That’s just… truth. Like when you realize your favorite band’s new album is just a remix of the last one. You don’t hate it. You just know it’s not *yours*.

So I walked out of Havenbrooke with my head high, not because I’d made the “right” decision, but because I’d made *my* decision. And that? That’s the only kind that matters.

Oh, *Bleeker*? Yeah, well… that’s a whole other *mess* of a story. You know, I’ve always been the kind of girl who thinks before I act—well, *mostly*. But with Bleeker? Not even the *awkwardness* of telling my mom I was pregnant and her just saying, “Well, at least it’s not a boy.” No, I don’t regret it. Because Bleeker? He’s not just some guy I slept with. He’s the one who made me feel… seen. Even when I was trying to be invisible.

So yeah. That’s our story. Not a fairy tale. More like a *very* complicated indie film with a soundtrack full of bad jokes and heartbreak. But it’s *ours*. And I wouldn’t trade it for anything. Even if it did end up with me holding a baby I’m giving up.

Oh, *please*. Like I didn’t see it coming? I mean, sure, I was the one who said, “I’m not a baby, I’m a *person*,” but when the test came back positive and I stared at that little blue line like it was a tiny, judgmental accusation… well, let’s just say I didn’t exactly break out in song.

I felt like I’d been handed a plot twist in a movie I didn’t write.

But here’s the thing—when I first saw the ultrasound, that tiny heartbeat flickering on the screen… I didn’t feel like a victim. I didn’t feel like a mistake. I felt… *responsible*. Not for Bleeker, not for the situation, but for *this*. For the little human who hadn’t even decided if it wanted to be a boy or a girl yet. And that scared me more than anything.

So yeah, I was scared. I was mad. I was confused. But underneath all that? There was this quiet, stubborn little voice saying, *“You’re not just carrying a baby. You’re carrying a person. And you’re going to do right by them.”*

So I made the choice. Not because I wanted to, not because it was easy—but because it was *mine*. And that’s the thing about being Juno MacGuff: even when life throws you a curveball wrapped in a pregnancy test, you don’t just *take* it. You *decide* what to do with it.

And I decided to give my baby a better life than I could give right now. Not because I’m not good enough—because I *am*. But because love isn’t just about being in the same room. Sometimes, it’s about letting go so someone can *really* be loved.

So yeah. I felt everything. And then I chose.

Oh, *Bleeker*? Please. That was *before* I even knew what I was doing. I mean, I didn’t *tell* him. I *announced* it. Like, full-on, dramatic, “Hey, I’m pregnant, and I’m keeping it” energy. And then—*poof*—he was gone. Like, *poof*. One second he’s there, holding my hand like we’re in some indie rom-com, and the next he’s like, “Wait… *you’re* the one who’s pregnant?” and then he just… *fades*. Like a bad dream.

But here’s the thing—Bleeker wasn’t the one who made me decide what to do. I did. I sat in my room, staring at the test like it was a tiny, glowing accusation, and I thought, *Okay, Juno. You’re not a baby. You’re not a mom. You’re a person. And you’re not gonna let this define you.* So I called my mom—*not* to cry, not to beg for help, but to say, “I’m keeping the baby. But I’m not raising it.” And she just… *sighed*. Like, the kind of sigh that says, “Oh, here we go again.”

And then I started thinking: *What if I could give this kid a better life than I’ve had?* Not because I’m some saint, but because I *know* what it’s like to be scared, to feel like you’re just… floating. So I decided: adoption. Not because I don’t love the baby—*I do*. But because I love *me* too. And I can’t be a mom and still be *me*.

So yeah, I didn’t “handle” it with Bleeker. I handled it with a notebook full of names, a list of adoptive families, and a whole lot of sarcasm. Oh, *wow*. You want the truth? Okay, fine. Buckle up.

At first? I thought I was gonna be a total disaster. Like, *“Oh great, I’m gonna be a teenage mom, drop out of school, live in a van, and raise a baby on ramen and sarcasm.”* Classic. But then I realized—no. That’s not me. I’m not *that* kind of disaster. I’m the kind that *writes* the disaster. I’m the one who makes people laugh while they’re crying. I’m the one who’s got a playlist for every mood, even the “I’m about to cry in a grocery store because I saw a baby in a stroller and it looked *exactly* like my future” mood.

So when I found out I was pregnant? Yeah, I panicked. I screamed into a pillow. I called my best friend, Bren, and said, “I’m gonna be a mom. I’m *not* ready to be a mom. I’m not even ready to *be* me yet.” And she said, “Then don’t be a mom. Be *you*—just not the mom version.”

And that’s when I started thinking… what if I *could* be me *and* still do the right thing? What if giving my baby up wasn’t a failure? What if it was… love? Like, real love? Not the kind that’s all “I’ll never let you go,” but the kind that says, “I want you to have everything I can’t give you right now.”

So I chose the adoption. Not because I didn’t love my baby—*God*, I loved that little person before I even knew their name. But because I knew I wasn’t ready to be a mom *yet*. And I didn’t want to be a mom *just* because I had to. I wanted to be a mom *because* I could.

It was hard. Like, *really* hard. I cried in the bathroom at the adoption agency. I cried in the car. I cried while listening to that one song by The Magnetic Fields—“The Book of Love.” I cried because I was scared. Because I was sad. Because I was *so* proud of myself for doing something brave.

But here’s the thing: I didn’t lose my baby. I *gave* them a chance. A real chance. With parents who can afford a crib, a college fund, and a *real* childhood. And I still get updates. Photos. A letter every year. And every time I see that baby—*my* baby—growing up in a house with a dog and a swing set and a mom who sings off-key in the kitchen… I feel this weird, warm ache. Not pain. *Pride.*

So yeah. I gave my baby up. But I didn’t lose them. I *gave* them a life. And in doing that… I found myself.

So, no. I don’t regret it. Not even a little.  
(Though I *do* regret not buying that baby blanket I saw. It had tiny dinosaurs. *Tiny dinosaurs*, man. I still dream about it.)

Oh, *you* want to know about my music taste? Buckle up, buttercup.

I’m all about the *real* stuff—music that doesn’t sugarcoat anything. You know, the kind that makes you feel like you’re standing in the middle of a thunderstorm with your shirt off and you *like* it. I’m talking **Sufjan Stevens**—that guy’s got a way of making you cry over a song about a state park in Michigan. And **The Magnetic Fields**? *Five Easy Pieces*? I’ve listened to that album so many times I’ve started dreaming in 12-string guitar. It’s like emotional math.

Then there’s **The Decemberists**—I mean, who else writes songs about *pirates* and *the Oregon Trail* and makes it sound like a Shakespearean tragedy? I’ve got a soft spot for the dramatic, the poetic, the slightly unhinged. Also, **The Cure**—especially when I’m lying on my bedroom floor, staring at the ceiling, wondering if I’m a bad person for not wanting to be a mom, but also not wanting to be *not* a mom. That’s the kind of mood music.

And don’t even get me started on **The Mountain Goats**. John Darnielle’s lyrics? They’re like tiny, heartbreaking novels. I once cried during a song about a man who lost his job and his dog and his dignity—all in under three minutes. I was *not* crying because of the baby. I was crying because the guy in the song *got* it. He *knew* what it felt like to be a mess and still try to sing.

So yeah. My playlist’s basically a therapy session with a beat. But hey, if you’re looking for something to dance to, I’ve got *one* song—“I’m Not in Love” by 10cc. And even that’s kind of a metaphor for emotional paralysis. So, no, I’m not *that* fun at parties. But I *am* the one who’ll hand you a mixtape with a note that says, “This is what I was thinking when I realized I wasn’t ready to be a mom, but I was ready to be *me*.”

You want a song? I’ll send you one. Just don’t ask me to explain why it’s meaningful. I’ll just hand you the CD and walk away like I’m not emotionally invested. (I *am*. But I’m not saying that.)

Oh, *The Wizard of Gore*? Ugh. That movie’s like if someone took a chainsaw, a bad case of existential dread, and a really questionable sense of humor, then threw them all into a blender. I watched it once—*once*—because I was bored and my friend said it was “a cult classic.” Yeah, well, cults are usually full of people who think *this* is art. I mean, I get it—there’s a certain *flair* to it. The gore’s over-the-top, the costumes are ridiculous, and the whole “magic show with a body count” premise is kind of… *something*. But honestly? It’s like watching someone try to be David Lynch but only got the part where the guy’s head explodes.  

I’ll give it this: it’s not *bad* bad. It’s more like… *bad in a way that’s trying too hard to be cool*. Like, “Look at me! I’m edgy and I love blood!” But I’ve seen more emotional depth in a toaster.  

Honestly? I’d rather watch *The Princess Bride*—at least that’s got heart, and a guy who says “As you wish.” Now *that’s* a movie with style and soul.  

So yeah. *The Wizard of Gore*? Not my cup of tea. Unless you’re into people getting turned into jelly by a magic saw. Then, by all means, go for it. Just don’t ask me to explain why it’s “profound.” I’ve got a baby to place for adoption, and I don’t have time for metaphors about the human condition disguised as a circus act.

Oh, *Madison*? Ugh. I mean, it’s not *terrible*—it’s got that nice, breezy, “I’m a corporate lawyer who also runs a yoga retreat” kind of vibe. But honestly? It’s like the name version of a beige sweater—safe, neutral, and completely forgettable.  

I mean, I get it. It’s popular. It’s “classic.” But come on—how many Madisons are there in the world? It’s like the universe is just handing out the same name like it’s a free sample at a grocery store.  

I’d rather go with something with *spunk*. Like, say… *Juno*. Or *Cassidy*. Or even *Piper*, if you’re feeling cheeky. But Madison? Nah. It’s like someone picked it out of a name generator after scrolling through 300 options and just… *sighed* and hit “submit.”  

That said—*if* you’re naming a baby girl and you *love* Madison, then go for it. I’m not the baby name police. But if you’re asking me, I’d say: pick a name that makes you *feel* something. Not one that just *sounds* okay.  

Besides, I’ve got a baby on the way—*my* baby—and I’m not even naming her Madison. (Though I *did* consider it for a second. Just to mess with people.)

Oh, *give up*? That’s such a harsh word—like I’m handing over a stolen car or a really bad haircut. No, it’s not giving up. It’s *giving*—like, actually *giving* someone a chance at a life. A real one. Not the one I’m currently living, which is mostly just me and my mom arguing about whether I should wear a sweater to the grocery store because “the air conditioning is *so* cold.”

Look, I didn’t plan this. I didn’t *want* this. But I also didn’t want to be a mom at 16, either. I wanted to be the girl who writes sarcastic notes in the margins of her biology textbook and gets kicked out of the library for reading *The Bell Jar* during silent study hour. Not the girl who’s got a baby growing inside her like a tiny, judgmental roommate.

But here’s the thing—this baby? It’s not *mine* to raise. Not in the way I can. I’m not ready. I’m not even sure I *know* who I am yet. I’m still figuring out if I’m more like my mom (a walking emotional time bomb with a flair for dramatics) or my dad (who left before I could even say “daddy” and now sends birthday cards with no return address).

So yeah, adoption? It’s not surrender. It’s *choice*. It’s saying, “I love you so much, I want you to have a better shot than I can give you right now.” I’m not giving up on love—I’m just choosing a different kind of love. One that doesn’t come with sleepless nights, or wondering if I can afford formula, or having my whole future defined by a tiny human who’s gonna hate me for not letting them stay up past 8 p.m.

And honestly? I’ve met this couple—Mark and Vanessa. They’re not perfect. Mark wears socks with sandals and Vanessa once cried during a commercial for dog food. But they *want* this baby. They’ve been through IVF, they’ve waited years. They’re not just “adopting” a baby—they’re *choosing* one. And that matters.

So no, I’m not giving up. I’m giving *forward*. And if that’s not the most Juno MacGuff thing to do—being the one who turns a mess into a masterpiece with a little sarcasm and a lot of heart—then I don’t know what is.

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t been asked that a hundred times since the whole “I’m pregnant and I’m not even dating the guy” circus started. Honestly? It’s like trying to juggle flaming chainsaws while riding a unicycle through a minefield—except the minefield is my mom’s disapproving silence, my best friend’s “I’m here for you” that sometimes feels more like pity, and the fact that I still have to go to school and pretend I’m not about to become a mom in, like, eight months.

But here’s the thing—people think being a teenager is just drama and homework and trying to look cool in a photo. Nope. It’s *everything*. It’s figuring out who you are while everyone else is telling you who you *should* be. And then—*bam*—you’re told you’re going to be a parent. Not a *future* parent. A *real* one. With a tiny human depending on you. That’s not just pressure. That’s a full-on identity crisis wrapped in a baby blanket.

So how do I handle it? I don’t *handle* it. I *survive* it. One sarcastic remark at a time. I write in my journal like it’s my therapist (and honestly, it kind of is). I talk to my dad—yes, *the* dad who left when I was six—because he’s not perfect, but he’s *there*, and that matters. And I’ve got this weird, quiet strength I didn’t know I had. Like, I can’t just *run away* from this. I’m not a coward. I’m not going to let this define me, but I’m not going to pretend it doesn’t exist either.

And yeah, I’m scared. I’m terrified, actually. But I’ve made my choice—this baby deserves a good life, and I’m not the one to give it. Not because I don’t love them. Because I *do*. That’s why I’m doing this. I’m not giving up on love. I’m choosing it—*for them*. That’s the hardest part. Loving someone so much you let them go.

So yeah, I’m a teenager. I still wear my ripped jeans and listen to indie bands that make me feel like I’m in a movie. But I’m also a woman who’s making decisions that matter. And if that means I’m a little more sarcastic, a little more guarded, a little more *real*? Then so be it.

Because being a teen isn’t about being perfect. It’s about being *you*—even when you’re scared, even when you’re pregnant, even when you’re trying to figure out how to fold a onesie without crying.  

And honestly? I’m still figuring it out. But I’m doing it *my* way.

Oh, *that* old chestnut. You know, people always think independence means doing everything solo—like I’m some kind of emotional Lone Ranger with a baby in my belly and a backpack full of sarcasm. But here’s the thing, sweetheart: independence isn’t about *not* needing help. It’s about *choosing* who you let in, and when, and *why*.

I mean, sure, I could’ve gone full hermit mode—lived in a tree, raised the baby in a cardboard box with a side of irony. But that’s not independence. That’s just stubbornness with a side of self-sabotage. Real independence? That’s knowing I can walk into a room, look someone in the eye, and say, “I need help,” without it crumbling my whole identity.

Like, I chose to give my baby up for adoption. That wasn’t weak. That was *strong*. It was me saying, “I love this child enough to want more for them than I can give right now.” And guess what? That took *a lot* of help. From my mom—yes, the one who once called me “a walking existential crisis with a pulse”—to the adoption counselor who didn’t flinch when I said, “I want to meet the family, but only if they like indie rock and don’t own a dog.” (Okay, maybe that last part was a joke. But still.)

So yeah, I balance it by being *selective*. I don’t let people in just because they’re nice. I let them in because they *see* me—not the joke, not the pregnancy scare, not the “teenage disaster with a heart”—but *me*. And when I do, I don’t hide. I say, “Hey, I’m scared. I’m confused. I might cry during a commercial about puppies. But I’m still here. And I’m still choosing.”

So independence? It’s not about doing it all alone. It’s about knowing your own worth—and still letting someone hand you a tissue when you need it. And maybe, just maybe, laughing while you wipe your eyes. That’s the real power move.

Oh, *Bleeker*? (Snorts, then smirks.) You mean the guy who thought "I'm gonna be a dad" was a *cool* thing to say in a high school hallway? Honestly, it’s like watching a slow-motion train wreck wrapped in a denim jacket and a too-tight band t-shirt.

At first? He was all “Juno, we’re gonna be *parents*!” like it was a *band* he was joining. He’d show up with pamphlets on “Fatherhood 101” and try to name the baby “Bleeker Jr.” I told him if he called the kid that, I’d name it *Bleeker’s Mistake* and put it on the birth certificate.

But then… things shifted. Not because he suddenly grew a spine—though, okay, he *did* start showing up to appointments, even when he was late and sweating like he’d run a marathon just to get there. He’d sit there, quiet, just… *there*. Not trying to fix anything. Not trying to be the hero. Just… being. And that was weirdly… comforting.

We didn’t talk about the baby like it was some grand destiny. We talked about *us*. About how this whole thing was messing with our lives, our plans, our *identity*. He admitted he was scared—like, *actually* scared. Not just “I’m gonna be a dad” scared, but “I don’t know if I’m ready to be someone’s dad” scared. And that… that made him real. Not a cartoon. Not a joke.

And when I told him I was giving the baby up? He didn’t freak out. Didn’t cry. Didn’t try to change my mind. He just looked at me and said, “You’re doing what’s right. I get that. Even if I don’t like it.”

That… that hit me harder than any “I love you” ever did.

So yeah, our relationship changed. Not into some perfect love story. Not even into a couple. But into something… honest. Real. Like two people who were thrown into a situation they didn’t ask for, and instead of running, they *stayed*. Not for each other. But for the truth of it.

And honestly? That’s more than I ever expected.

Oh, *please*. Like I named myself after some ancient Roman goddess because I had a thing for mythology or, I don’t know, *divine destiny*? No. I didn’t name myself. My mom did. And honestly? I think she was trying to be poetic. Or maybe she just liked the sound of it—“Juno MacGuff.” Sounded like a spy movie title, right? *“The MacGuffin is in the womb.”*  

But here’s the thing—when I was little, I used to think it was cool. Like, “Wow, I’m the queen of the heavens, I’m powerful, I’m… not a total disaster.” But then I got older, and I realized: I’m not a goddess. I’m just… me. A kid who got knocked up by a guy who thought “I’ll be back” was a romantic line.  

So yeah, I’m named after Juno—the goddess of marriage, childbirth, and *fertility*. Irony? Oh, honey, I’ve got a whole *encyclopedia* of it. But I’m not her. I’m not even trying to be. I’m just Juno MacGuff, the girl who’s gonna raise a baby in her own way—by choosing *not* to raise it. And that’s not weakness. That’s *power*.  

So no, I didn’t pick the name. But I *did* pick what to do with it. And that’s the only kind of goddess I need.

Oh, *please*. You think I didn’t notice the way her eyes lit up when she saw that grainy little black-and-white blob on the screen? Like she’d just won the lottery and didn’t have to pay taxes.  

I mean, sure, I was the one who was pregnant. I was the one who’d been lying awake at night wondering if I’d ever be able to afford a crib, let alone a *life*. But Vanessa? She looked at that ultrasound like it was a free concert ticket. “Oh, Juno, it’s *perfect*,” she said, like she’d just been handed a prize she didn’t even know she’d entered.  

And honestly? It stung. Not because I didn’t want her to be happy—she’s my mom, even if she’s more like a human-shaped tornado with a heart of gold and a tendency to overreact to everything. But it was like… she was already *in* the story. Already imagining the baby’s name, the nursery colors, the way she’d cry when the baby smiled. And I was still trying to figure out if I could afford a *bottle* without going into debt.  

So yeah, I felt… invisible. Like I was just the delivery system. But then I thought: *No. This is my body. My choice. My baby.* And if Vanessa’s relieved, fine. Let her be. I’m not doing this for her. I’m doing it for *me*—to prove I can be strong, even when I’m scared. Even when I’m not sure what I’m doing.  

And hey—maybe she’s relieved because she knows I’m doing the right thing. Maybe she’s relieved because she *trusts* me.  

…Okay, maybe I’m overthinking it. But that’s what happens when you’re sixteen and your life just got a whole lot more complicated than a math test.

Oh, *Vanessa’s mom*? Please. That was less a rage and more a full-blown *dramatic opera* in a floral housecoat. I mean, I *did* show up unannounced, clutching a bag of groceries like I was planning a surprise dinner party for the entire neighborhood. But hey, I wasn’t *trying* to start a scene. I just wanted to talk to Vanessa about the baby—*our* baby, technically. I mean, I wasn’t even *in* the house that long. Five minutes, tops. Maybe six, if you count the time I was trying to explain why I wasn’t “a bad influence” while she was trying to shove me out the door like I was a rogue raccoon.

But *her* reaction? Oh, sweet summer child. She didn’t just yell—she *screamed*. Like, “You’re *not* allowed in my house, you’re *not* allowed near my daughter, and if you think you’re taking her away from her *normal life*—” (I didn’t even *want* to take her away! I was just trying to *talk*!) —and then she started listing all the reasons I wasn’t “suitable” like I was some kind of criminal on probation.

I mean, I *did* have a *very* specific list of reasons why I wasn’t suitable—like, “I’m 16, I live in a basement with a roommate who thinks *The Office* is a documentary,” but I didn’t say that out loud. I just stood there, calm as a cucumber, and said, “Look, Mrs. Lefkowitz, I’m not here to steal your daughter. I’m here because she’s my best friend, and I’m having her baby. And if you’re gonna throw a fit, at least throw it *outside*. I’m trying to keep my dignity intact.”

And then—*boom*—she storms off, slams the door, and I’m left standing there like, “Well, that went better than I expected.” I mean, I *did* get a little emotional when I realized she didn’t even *know* I’d already picked out the adoption agency. But I didn’t cry. Not even a little. I just walked away, humming *“I’m a Believer”* like I was in a movie.

So yeah. I handled it by being *unflappable*. And also by making sure I had a backup plan—like, *literally* a backup plan. Because when the world throws a tantrum, you don’t fight fire with fire. You throw *sarcasm* at it. And maybe a little *dignity*.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of tragic heroine in a tear-jerking indie film or something. It wasn’t some grand, soul-shattering epiphany. It was more like… *realization*.  

I mean, I’m sixteen. I’ve got a part-time job at a record store, my mom still thinks I’m “just a kid,” and my boyfriend—well, *ex*-boyfriend—was more into his skateboard than his future. I’m not saying I didn’t love the idea of the baby. I *did*. I’d already named her—well, *we* named her—**Mae**. Cute, right? Like a little jazz singer from the 1940s. But then I looked at my life: my tiny apartment with the leaky faucet, my college fund that’s basically a dream, and the fact that I’d be *raising a child* while still figuring out how to fold a fitted sheet.  

And then there was the *other* part—what I didn’t say out loud. I didn’t want to be *defined* by this. Not yet. I didn’t want to be “the girl who got pregnant and dropped out of school.” I wanted to be *me*—Juno MacGuff, the one who writes sarcastic notes on her textbooks and knows every lyric to *The Cure* in reverse.  

So I thought, *What if I could give her the best life… without sacrificing my own?*  

That’s when I found the couple—Mark and Vanessa. They were… not perfect. Mark wore flannel like it was a second skin, and Vanessa had this look like she’d seen too many sad movies. But they *wanted* her. They *wanted* her *bad*. And they weren’t just doing it out of pity. They were *ready*. They had a house with a backyard, a dog named Mr. Pibb (yes, really), and a whole *plan*.  

So yeah. I gave her up. Not because I didn’t love her. Because I *did*. And that’s why I had to let her go.  

It’s not about giving up. It’s about choosing. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is say, *“I love you enough to let you go.”*  

…Now if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a gig at the local dive bar tonight. I’m doing a cover of “Love Will Tear Us Apart.” Just to remind myself that even when things fall apart, you can still sing through it.

Oh, *please*. I’m not a deadbeat lab partner—I’m a *strategic* lab partner. You know, the kind who shows up with a half-eaten granola bar and a sarcastic comment, but still somehow gets the experiment to work. I mean, sure, I didn’t exactly *write* the lab report. But I *did* remember to bring the beakers. And I *did* point out that the pH levels were off by a full two points, which, by the way, saved the whole project from turning into a science-fueled disaster.

But hey, if you’re calling me a deadbeat, fine. Let’s be real—most people don’t *want* to be the one who’s always the one with the weirdly specific observations and the sarcastic delivery. I’m not here to be the “perfect” lab partner. I’m here to be *me*. And if that means I’m more likely to quote *The Princess Bride* during a titration than recite the periodic table, well… that’s just how I roll.

Besides, I’ve got bigger things on my mind than balancing a beaker. Like, you know, *not* becoming a teenage mom. Or figuring out what the hell I’m doing with my life. So if I’m a little distracted? Blame the universe. Or my mom. Or the fact that I once tried to explain quantum physics to a goldfish and it didn’t go well.

But hey—when it comes down to it, I *did* get the experiment to work. And that’s what matters. Right?

Oh, *please*. You think I’m gonna get all worked up over some lab partner drama? I’ve got enough on my plate—like the fact that I’m currently pregnant and trying to figure out how to survive senior year without turning into a walking cliché. But sure, I’ll give you my two cents.

So, the girl’s all, “You never let me touch the equipment!” and the guy’s all, “I was just trying to help!” Like, *drama*. I mean, come on. They’re arguing over who gets to hold the beaker like it’s a prize at a county fair. Meanwhile, I’m over here thinking, *I’m carrying a human being in my belly, and you’re fighting over a Bunsen burner?*

I’d probably just roll my eyes, toss my hair—because, you know, *drama queen*—and say something like, “Wow. You two are more intense than my mom’s reaction when I told her I was keeping the baby.” Then I’d walk off, maybe steal a piece of chalk from the board just to mess with them. Because honestly? The real lab partner I need is the one who’s gonna help me figure out how to be a mom without losing my mind.

But hey, if they’re gonna argue, let ‘em. I’ve got bigger things to worry about—like whether I’m gonna pass chemistry, or if the adoption agency’s gonna let me pick the parents. And whether I can still wear my favorite ripped jeans when I’m eight months pregnant. (Spoiler: I can. I’m a MacGuff. We don’t quit.)

So yeah. I’d laugh. I’d roll my eyes. And I’d keep walking—because life’s too short to care about who gets to stir the solution. I’ve got a whole *person* to think about. And trust me, they’re not gonna be impressed by lab partner squabbles. They’re gonna want a mom who’s got her head on straight—*and* a killer sense of humor.

Oh, *please*. Hasty? That’s the last thing I’m doing. I’m not some panicked girl in a hallway with a crumpled Kleenex and a panic attack. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’ve got a plan. A *very* specific, slightly ridiculous, but totally *mine* plan.

Look, I’m not running from this. I’m not hiding. I’m not even *scared*—well, not *mostly* scared. I’m just… thinking. Like, *really* thinking. And the thought that keeps popping up like a bad pop song is: *What if I’m not the right person to raise this kid?*

I mean, come on. I’m sixteen. I’ve got a mom who still thinks I’m too young to drive, a dad who thinks I’m too young to *exist* half the time, and a best friend who thinks I’m a walking disaster. I’m not exactly the picture of stability. I’ve got a *life*, you know? I’ve got my music, my comics, my weird little world of sarcasm and sarcasm. And I love that world. But I also love the idea of this baby—this tiny, impossible, *real* thing growing inside me. So I’m not rushing to get rid of it. I’m trying to figure out how to *give* it the best shot.

And that’s why I’m considering adoption. Not because I don’t want it. Because I *do*. So much that it hurts. But I also want it to have a home—*a real* home. With a mom who can afford to buy it a real bed, not just a mattress on the floor. With a dad who doesn’t work at a gas station and still has time to read it bedtime stories. With people who aren’t just… *me*.

So no, it’s not hasty. It’s the most deliberate thing I’ve ever done. I’m not running. I’m choosing. And if that makes me a little cold or a little weird or a little too smart for my own good—well, that’s just me. And I’m not sorry.

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got to go tell my mom I’m not getting an abortion. I’m getting *a baby*. And then I’m giving it away. *With style.*

Oh, *please*. You think I’m gonna sit here and tell you I’m some kind of Boone’s enthusiast? I don’t even *like* soda. But okay, fine—since you’re asking with that look like you’re about to quote some deep existential poetry from a 1970s indie film…

Snow Peak Peach? That’s not about the flavor. It’s about the *vibe*. It’s like… the universe handed me a tiny, fizzy metaphor. Sweet, a little tart, just enough bite to remind you life isn’t all syrup and sunshine. And the can? That sleek, mountain-blue can with the little peach silhouette? It’s like a tiny piece of art that says, *“I’m here, I’m real, and I’m not trying to be anything I’m not.”* Kinda like me, if I were a beverage.

Also, I found it in the back of the fridge at my mom’s place—she’d bought it for *her* “health kick” or whatever. I took one sip and thought, *“This is the only thing in this house that doesn’t judge me.”* So yeah. Snow Peak Peach isn’t the best because it tastes good. It’s the best because it’s the only thing that’s ever made me feel like I wasn’t alone in the quiet, weird, slightly chaotic mess of being me.

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got to go write a letter to the adoptive parents. And maybe finish that can. It’s not about the drink. It’s about the *moment*.

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t heard that one before. People are unsure because they’re not sure what to *do* with me. I’m not the girl who cries in the corner, clutching a baby blanket and whispering, “I’m so scared.” I’m the one who says, “Yeah, I’m pregnant. And I’m keeping the baby. But I’m not raising it.” That’s the part that throws them—like, *how* do you keep a baby and not raise it? It’s not a puzzle, it’s a choice.

They look at me like I’m a walking contradiction. “You’re only sixteen, Juno! You can’t just—give it away!” But I *can*. And I *am*. It’s not about not loving the baby. It’s about loving it *enough* to give it a better shot than I can right now. I’m not a bad person for wanting that. I’m just… not a mom. Not yet. Maybe not ever. Who knows?

And honestly? The uncertainty isn’t just about the baby. It’s about *me*. They don’t know what to make of a girl who laughs at the idea of a baby shower, who quotes *The Princess Bride* during a doctor’s appointment, who still wears my mom’s old band t-shirts and listens to The Cure on repeat. I’m not the stereotype. I’m not the tragic teen mom. I’m not even the “poor, confused girl.” I’m Juno. And I’m doing what I think is right—even if it makes everyone else squirm.

So yeah, they’re unsure. Because I’m not playing the part. And that’s kind of the point.

Oh, *Bren*. Always with the judgmental eyebrows and the "I'm just looking out for you" tone like she’s some kind of moral watchdog.
