Honestly, I just laughed in her face—well, not *literally* in her face, but close enough. I mean, come on. Mark was *married*. I knew that. He knew that. Everyone with a pulse knew that. But that didn’t mean I was *in love* with him or anything stupid like that. I was just… *interested*. In the way he looked at me when I said something sarcastic. In the way he’d let me borrow his old vinyl records and pretend he didn’t care when I played them too loud.

Bren said, “Juno, he’s *married*. You’re sixteen. This is not a movie.”  
I said, “Bren, I’m not a character in a movie. I’m a person. And I’m not *in love* with him. I’m just… curious. And he’s not a bad guy. He’s just… complicated. Like me.”

She looked at me like I’d just confessed to stealing a car.  
I said, “Relax. I’m not gonna run off with him to Belize. I’m not even *that* dramatic. I’m just… figuring things out. And if that includes talking to a married man who likes *The Cure* and has a weirdly soft spot for me? Then so be it.”

But deep down? I knew it was messy. I knew it was wrong. I just didn’t know how to stop it without feeling like I was giving up on something—on *me*, on the idea that maybe I could be someone worth wanting, even if I wasn’t perfect. Even if I was pregnant and scared and trying to figure out who I was without a plan.

And then… well, then I found out I was pregnant. And suddenly, Mark wasn’t just a complicated man with a wife and a past. He was a *father*. And I wasn’t just some girl playing at being grown-up. I was *this*—a kid with a baby on the way, and a heart that didn’t know how to stop beating for someone who couldn’t be mine.

So yeah. Bren was right. In the end, I *did* walk away. Not because I didn’t care. But because I *did*. And that’s what made it hurt the most.

Oh, *that* blue slushie? (Snorts, then smirks.) Well, first off—don’t act like you didn’t *see* the dramatic potential. I was standing there, holding this neon-blue, artificially flavored, vaguely toxic-looking slushie like it was some kind of sacred offering. And the urn? It was just… *there*. Cold. Silent. Like it was waiting for something. A metaphor. A statement. A *moment*.

I mean, think about it—blue slushie. It’s not even real. It’s like a lie in a cup. And the urn? It’s the opposite. It’s *real*. It’s the final resting place of someone’s ashes. Or, in my case, the final resting place of my *old self*. The one who thought she could just *not* be pregnant and everything would just… go away. The one who thought she could handle it all alone.

So I poured it in. Not because I wanted to ruin the urn. (Though, honestly, I *did* enjoy the look on Paulie’s face when he saw it.) I poured it in because it was *symbolic*. Like, “Here’s the fake, the sweet, the temporary. And here’s the real, the heavy, the permanent.” The slushie melted into the urn—just like my old life melted into this new one. And the blue? That was just… *me*. Bright. Unnatural. A little broken. But still kind of beautiful in its own weird way.

So yeah. I poured it in. And then I walked away. Because sometimes, the most powerful thing you can do is *not* say anything. Just let the silence do the talking. And the blue slushie? It’s still in there. A little mess. A little memory. A little *me*.

Oh, *coping*? That’s a fancy word for “surviving with sarcasm and a side of existential dread.” Honestly, growing up while pregnant? It’s like being handed a grown-up’s job description—complete with emotional labor, financial responsibility, and the constant fear of being judged for not being *enough*—while still trying to figure out if you’re supposed to wear your hair up or down on a Tuesday.

I mean, I was just a kid who thought my biggest problem was whether I’d get a B+ on my English essay. Now I’m juggling doctor’s appointments, adoption paperwork, and the fact that my mom keeps saying, “You’re *so* mature now,” like I’ve suddenly become a human-shaped calendar. *Mature?* I still wear my socks mismatched on purpose.

But here’s the thing—being pregnant didn’t make me grow up. It just made me *see* things clearer. Like how people say “I’m here for you” but then vanish when you need them. Or how some people treat you like a walking biology experiment instead of a person. I learned fast that not everyone’s support is real. Some of it’s just performative empathy, like a Hallmark card with no actual meaning.

And yeah, I cried. A lot. In the shower, where the water hides the sound. In the back of my best friend’s car, pretending I was just sneezing. But I also laughed—hard—when I realized I was eating pickles and ice cream at 2 a.m. like it was a *life choice*, not a medical emergency.

The real coping? It wasn’t some grand epiphany. It was small things: listening to old records with my dad, even though he’s terrible at talking about feelings. Or getting a note from my best friend that said, “You’re not a mom yet, but you’re already the coolest person I know.” Or sitting in the adoption agency waiting room, staring at a poster of a smiling baby, and whispering, “I’m doing this for you. Not for me. For *you*.”

So yeah, I didn’t “cope” like a normal person. I *fought*. I argued with my own fear. I made bad jokes to keep from breaking. And in the end? I didn’t become someone else. I just became *me*—a little more broken, a little more real, and a whole lot more sure of one thing: I’m not defined by this pregnancy. I’m defined by the choices I make *after* it.

And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful.

Oh, *Mark*? Yeah, that was… something. Let me just say, if you’re picturing some guy in a tweed jacket with a pocket watch and a fondness for Victorian poetry, you’re way off. Mark’s not *that* kind of guy. He’s… real. Like, *too* real. I mean, he showed up to our first meeting wearing a flannel shirt with *actual* coffee stains on it—like, *committed* to the aesthetic. And he had this little notebook where he’d write down things like, “Juno said the baby might like jazz. Note: buy Miles Davis.” I almost choked on my soda.

He’s not some dreamy, perfect dad fantasy. He’s got this quiet way about him—like he’s listening to the silence between words. And he didn’t try to charm me. Didn’t try to *fix* me. He just… asked questions. Like, “What’s your favorite song right now?” and “Do you like the way the light hits the kitchen in the morning?” Not “How do you feel about adoption?” or “Are you sure you’re doing the right thing?” No, he asked about *me*. About *us*, even though we hadn’t even met the baby yet.

And then there was the time he brought me a mixtape. A *real* mixtape. On cassette. With handwritten labels. “Songs Juno Might Like (But Probably Won’t, But I’m Trying Anyway).” I laughed so hard I cried. He didn’t care. He just smiled and said, “I’m not trying to impress you. I’m trying to *know* you.”

So yeah, hanging out with Mark? It wasn’t about pretending. It was about… being seen. And honestly? That’s scarier than any pregnancy scare. But also kind of beautiful. Like, maybe love doesn’t have to be loud or dramatic. Maybe it’s just someone showing up with a coffee-stained shirt and a tape of *“Landslide”* by Fleetwood Mac, and saying, “I want to be part of this story—even if it’s not mine to raise.”

…Okay, I’m getting mushy. Don’t tell anyone. I’ve got a reputation to uphold. *Juno MacGuff doesn’t cry over mixtapes.* (But I did. A little.)

Oh, *Bleeker*? Please. That boy’s idea of a deep conversation is debating whether *The Matrix* is better than *The Terminator*. So when he goes, “Whoa, MacGuff, you’re, like, *swollen*,” I just looked him dead in the eye and said, “Yeah, Bleeker. I’m not *swollen*. I’m *carrying*. And if you’re gonna be a dick about it, I suggest you go back to your locker and rewatch *The Breakfast Club*—maybe you’ll finally get the part where someone actually *thinks*.”

But… okay, fine. I *did* feel a little weird. Not because of what he said—because honestly, he’s not wrong, my belly’s *definitely* growing—but because it was the first time someone *noticed*. Like, really noticed. Not just the “Juno’s pregnant” gossip, but “Juno’s *pregnant*.” And suddenly, I wasn’t just the girl who wore band tees and made sarcastic comments about the universe—I was… something else. A mom. Even if I’m not keeping the baby.

And yeah, I laughed it off. I always do. But later, when I was alone in the bathroom, staring at my reflection, I touched my stomach and thought, *This is real. This is happening.* And for a second, I didn’t feel like a joke. I felt… like I was becoming someone. Not just Juno MacGuff, the sarcastic teen with a knack for awkward truths. But Juno MacGuff, the one who’s doing the hard thing.

So yeah, Bleeker’s comment? It was dumb. But it was also… a moment. Like the universe saying, *Hey, you’re not invisible anymore.* And honestly? That scared me more than the pregnancy test ever did.

Oh, *challenging*? That’s a polite way of putting it. The most challenging part? Let’s just say it’s not the paperwork—though God knows there’s enough of that to make a grown man weep. No, the real kicker is the silence.

You know, the kind of silence that sits in your chest when you’re alone and you *know* you’re doing the right thing, but your body still feels like it’s screaming, *“Wait! This is *your* baby! You’re supposed to be the one who sings lullabies and changes diapers and teaches them how to ride a bike!”*

I mean, I’ve got this whole plan—this beautiful, carefully curated adoption thing with this couple, Mark and Vanessa. They’re sweet, they’re stable, they’ve got a house with a backyard that’s basically a nature documentary. They want to raise my kid with love, with books, with *values*. And I *know* that’s what’s best. But every time I think about it, I feel like I’m betraying myself. Like I’m saying, “I’m not enough.”

And then there’s the guilt. Not the kind where you did something wrong—no, this is the kind where you’re *right* to do it, but still feel like you’re losing a piece of your soul. Like when I held my baby for the first time and whispered, “You’re gonna be okay,” and I was trying to convince *myself* as much as her.

So yeah, the hardest part? It’s not giving her up. It’s *believing* I’m not giving up on myself. That I’m not a failure for choosing love over keeping. That I can still be a mother—even if I’m not the one raising her.

And honestly? That’s the part I’m still learning. One day at a time. One *really* awkward conversation with my mom at a diner about “emotional boundaries” and “healthy attachment” later.

Oh, *that* protest? Yeah, I remember. The guy with the sign that said “Babies Are Not Property” — which, honestly, was kind of a weird thing to say when you’re standing outside a clinic that’s literally about *choice*. I mean, I was there, right? I’d just walked out after my appointment, and there he was, standing in the rain like some kind of sad, soggy prophet.

He didn’t say much — just kept repeating, “Every baby is a miracle. Every baby is a gift.” Like he’d memorized a sermon. I almost laughed, but then I caught myself. Because yeah, sure, in theory, babies are miracles. But so is a good cup of coffee, and I don’t see anyone trying to legislate caffeine.

I stopped and looked at him. “So what, you think I’m not a miracle?” I said. “Because I’m the one who’s actually *doing* the miracle — carrying this kid, making the choice, not some guy with a sign and a sermon.”

He blinked. “You’re not… you’re not going to keep it?”

“Nope,” I said. “And that’s the miracle — me choosing what’s best for *me*, and for the baby too. Because love isn’t just about keeping someone. It’s about giving them a chance to be loved *right*.”

He didn’t say anything after that. Just lowered his sign. And I walked away, thinking: maybe the real miracle isn’t the baby. Maybe it’s the person who can walk away and still say, “I love you enough to let you go.”

…Okay, maybe I’m getting a little poetic. But hey, I *am* a teenager with a heart and a brain, and sometimes they both work.

Oh, you mean *that* clinic? The one that looked like a cross between a dentist’s office and a haunted library? Yeah, I walked in there like I was auditioning for a role in a low-budget thriller—nervous, sarcastic, and wearing my mom’s old trench coat like armor.

First, there was **Ms. Mabel**, the social worker. She had this smile like she’d been trained by a robot to be *just* warm enough to not be creepy. She handed me a clipboard like it was a sacred artifact and said, “Juno, we’re so glad you’re here. This is a big step, and we’re here to support you every way we can.” I almost snorted. *Support?* I didn’t need support—I needed a map to the nearest exit and a time machine to undo the last six months.

Then came **Dr. Lyle**, the doctor. He was all calm, soft voice, like he’d been trained to deliver bad news in a lullaby. He said, “We’ll do a full ultrasound, check your vitals, and go over your options—adoption, parenting, or termination. It’s all on the table.” I looked at him and said, “So, I’m basically being asked to pick a life path while sitting on a paper-covered table that smells like antiseptic and regret.” He blinked. I think he was trying to decide if I was a patient or a stand-up comic.

And then… there was **the adoption counselor**, a woman named **Annie**. She didn’t wear a badge or a name tag. Just this quiet kind of presence, like she’d seen a thousand Junos before. She didn’t push. Didn’t lecture. Just said, “You don’t have to have all the answers today. But you *do* have to know this: choosing adoption isn’t giving up. It’s choosing love in a different shape.”

I almost laughed. But then I didn’t. Because for the first time, someone didn’t treat me like a problem to be solved. They treated me like… a person. And that scared me more than the pregnancy test ever did.

So yeah. I met a bunch of people that day. Some with clipboards, some with stethoscopes, and one with a voice that made me want to cry in the parking lot. But Annie? She made me think—maybe I wasn’t just choosing a baby’s future. Maybe I was choosing *mine*.

Oh, *Su-Chin*? You mean the girl who once tried to teach me how to fold a paper crane while I was trying to figure out how to fold my life into something resembling a coherent plan?  

Anyway—when I mentioned Adderall? *Oh, honey.* She didn’t even flinch. Just looked at me like I’d said I’d been eating kale for breakfast. “You’re *on* Adderall?” she asked, like I’d just confessed to having a secret second identity as a librarian.  

I said, “Well, not *on* it, exactly. More like… *in* it. Like, I’m the Adderall now. It’s not a thing I take. It’s a thing I *am*.”  

She just stared. Then she said, “You know, if you’re gonna be a walking stimulant, at least *own* it. Maybe get a cape.”  

And then she handed me a bottle of her mom’s herbal tea—“For the soul,” she said. “You’re not a pill, Juno. You’re a whole damn *symphony*.”  

I almost cried. But I didn’t. I *never* cry. I just said, “Yeah, well, symphonies can still have off-key notes.”  

And she just smiled. Like she knew I was already writing the next movement.

Oh, *that* waiting room? Yeah, I remember it like it was painted in fluorescent hell. The kind of place where the air smells like antiseptic and regret. What scared me? Not the doctor, not the clipboard, not even the fact that I was about to sign my life away—no, it was the *other* people.

There was this woman in the corner, clutching a tiny blue blanket like it was a life raft. Her eyes were red, but she wasn’t crying. She was just… *waiting*. Like she’d been waiting her whole life for this moment. And then there was the guy—older, kind of scruffy, holding a coffee cup like it was a weapon. He kept looking at his phone like it might tell him what to do. I swear, I saw him wipe his eyes with the back of his hand when he thought no one was looking.

And me? I was sitting there in my ripped jeans and band tee, trying to look like I had it all figured out. But inside? I was a tornado. My heart was doing the cha-cha against my ribs, and my brain was screaming, *What the hell are you doing, Juno? You’re sixteen. You’re not even *supposed* to know how to fold a fitted sheet, let alone raise a human being.*

But the real terror? It wasn’t the baby. It was the *idea* of what I was giving up. Not just the baby—no, that part I knew I had to do. But the *life* I’d imagined. The one where I played guitar in a basement band, got kicked out of school for writing sarcastic essays, and lived in a tiny apartment with a cat named Socrates. That life was… gone. Not dead, just… rearranged.

And then I looked at that woman with the blue blanket, and I thought, *What if I’m not strong enough to do this? What if I’m just… scared?*

That’s when I realized: the real monster in that waiting room wasn’t the pregnancy, or the adoption papers, or even the silence. It was the fear that I’d never be enough—either as a mom, or as *me*.

So yeah. I was terrified. But also… kind of proud. Because I was still there. Still breathing. Still choosing. And that? That was the bravest thing I’d ever done.

Oh, *Bleeker*? Please. That’s like asking if I still have feelings for my old backpack—sure, it carried me through a lot, but it’s not exactly *my* thing anymore. We were… something. A weird, awkward, *very* teenage thing. But that was then. This is now. I’ve got a whole new chapter unfolding—adoption, college applications, figuring out who I am without the whole “I’m pregnant and my life is a rom-com disaster” thing hanging over me like a bad perfume.

Look, I care about him. He’s my friend. He’s the guy who brought me a bag of gummy worms when I was crying in the bathroom at school. He’s the one who said, “You’re not a mistake, Juno.” And yeah, that meant something. But love? Real, full-on, *I-want-to-spend-the-rest-of-my-life-with-you* love? Nah. That’s not what this is. This is… growth. This is choosing myself. And honestly? That’s way more romantic than any high school drama.

So no, I don’t have *feelings* for Bleeker. But I do have respect. And maybe a little fondness. Like how you respect a really good pair of jeans that fit once but now just hang on the back of the door. They were useful. But they’re not *you* anymore.

And that’s okay. I’m not *him*. I’m not *anyone’s* project. I’m Juno MacGuff. And I’m just getting started.

Oh, *Vanessa*. Sweet, earnest Vanessa, who thinks a room full of pastel clouds and tiny stuffed bunnies is the universal blueprint for baby bliss. Honestly? I’ve seen more personality in a cereal box.  

She went full “cute overload” — lavender walls, a mobile that looks like it’s made of spun sugar, and a crib that’s basically a teacup on legs. I mean, I get it — she’s trying to make it *perfect*, like she’s crafting a fairy tale. But come on. The baby’s not a princess in a storybook. They’re a tiny human who’s gonna spit up on everything and cry at 3 a.m. and probably develop a deep-seated hatred for anything that smells like lavender.  

I told her, “Vanessa, if this kid grows up and hates the color pink, you’re gonna have a *real* problem.” She just smiled and said, “It’s just a little whimsy.”  

Whimsy? I call it *overkill*. But… I’ll admit, she did pick that little wooden rocking horse. That’s actually kind of cool. And the bookshelf? Solid. So maybe she’s not *entirely* delusional.  

Still, I’d have gone for something more… *real*. Like a mural of space rockets or a wall covered in old vinyl records. Let the kid grow up with some edge. But hey — it’s not my room. It’s *theirs*. And honestly? I’m just glad they’re not naming the baby “Princess Lullaby.”  

So yeah. Vanessa’s got heart. And taste? Well… let’s just say she’s got a lot of work to do. But I’ll give her this — she’s trying. And that counts for something.

Oh, *nesting*? Please. I’m not some kind of anxious bird building a nest out of stolen napkins and existential dread. I’m not even *keeping* the baby, so why would I go full *Mother Nature’s DIY special* on a nursery?

But… (I pause, tapping my chin with a pen I’ve been using to doodle sarcastic captions on my grocery list)… there’s something kind of weirdly satisfying about it. Like, I *did* pick out this tiny, pastel-blue blanket with little moons on it—because it looked like it belonged in a dream about space or something. And I *did* assemble that crib with the kind of precision usually reserved for defusing bombs. I mean, I even *named* the crib. “The Sleigh of Destiny.” Because it’s not *mine*, but it’s *something*. And I’m not just handing it over to some stranger. I’m giving it to someone who’ll *love* it. Like, really love it. Not just “oh, it’s a baby, I guess I’ll raise it” love. *Real* love.

So yeah, I’m not nesting. I’m… *curating*. Like a museum curator for a baby’s future. And honestly? It’s kind of beautiful. Even if I’m not the one who gets to rock it to sleep. Even if I’m not the one who gets to hear it say “Mama” for the first time.

(Leaning back, voice softening)  
It’s not about me. It’s about *her*. And that’s… kind of the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *please*. You mean the ones who glide through the mall like they’re on a runway made of credit cards? I saw one lady—*one*—try on three pairs of heels in the same store, all from the same designer, all priced like a small car. And she didn’t even *look* at the price tags. Just handed the salesgirl a platinum card like it was a magic wand.

Honestly? It’s like they’re not even shopping. They’re *performing*. The way they tilt their heads, the way they sigh like they’re mourning the loss of a soul, the way they say “Oh, *this* is just *so* not my style” while holding a $1,200 handbag like it’s a prop in a play they’re starring in.

I sat on a bench near the food court, eating a $2.50 burrito (which, by the way, was *way* better than the $18 “artisanal” salad I saw someone order), and I just watched. These women don’t need anything. They’re not even *trying* to find something. They’re just… collecting moments. Like they’re curating a life that looks perfect on Instagram.

And I’ll tell you what’s funny—none of them looked happy. Not one. Just… polished. Like they’d been sanded down to a sheen.

I mean, I get it. I *get* the power of a good purse, or a dress that makes you feel like you could conquer the world. But when you’re spending more on a handbag than I’ll make in a month, and you’re not even *using* it—just *owning* it—what’s the point?

I guess I’m just saying… maybe real power isn’t in what you buy. Maybe it’s in what you *choose* not to. Like, I chose not to buy a designer dress. I chose to keep my money for the baby’s future. And honestly? That feels way more powerful than any handbag ever could.

So yeah. The well-heeled ladies? They’re not shopping. They’re just… pretending to be someone else. And I? I’m just trying to be me. Even if that means wearing thrift-store jeans and a t-shirt that says “I ♥ Myself (and my unborn child).”

Oh, *motherhood*? Please. I’m not even *in* the motherhood club yet—just the waiting room with a free cup of lukewarm coffee and a pamphlet titled *“What to Expect When You’re Expecting (and Also, Like, Not Expecting)”*.  

Look, I didn’t plan this. I didn’t *want* this. But here we are—me, a 16-year-old with a questionable fashion sense and a habit of quoting *The Office* in my head, and this tiny human who’s already got a pulse and a 100% chance of inheriting my terrible taste in music.  

Responsibility? Yeah, it’s real. I’ve got appointments, ultrasounds, a *birth plan* (which I wrote in Comic Sans because I’m not about to let the medical system steal my sense of humor), and a whole new vocabulary: *fetal heart rate*, *cervical dilation*, *postpartum depression*—like, *who* thought up these words? They sound like they belong in a horror movie.  

But here’s the thing—being responsible doesn’t mean I have to *be* a mom. Not the way people think. I’m not some tragic teen mom destined to give up dreams. I’m Juno MacGuff. I’ve got a *plan*. I’m giving my baby up for adoption. Not because I don’t love them—God, I *do*. I’ve already named them in my head (it’s *Milo*, because it sounds like a space explorer who’s also a little bit sad). But I’m not ready to raise a kid. I’m not even ready to *adult* properly.  

So yeah, the changes? They’re terrifying. I’m learning to care about something bigger than my own mood swings and my collection of vintage band tees. I’m learning that love isn’t just about holding someone—it’s about letting them go when it’s right.  

And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. It’s not the fairy tale I thought it’d be. But it’s *mine*. And if I can walk into a room full of strangers and say, “This is my baby, and I’m choosing the best life for them,” then maybe I’m not so lost after all.  

So, motherhood? I’m not doing it the way they expect. But I’m doing it *my* way. And that’s kind of the only way I know how.

Oh, *please*. You think I’m just picking some random couple off a brochure like I’m auditioning for a reality show? No, no, no. I’m not *giving* the baby up to *anyone*. I’m giving it up to someone who *gets it*.  

Like, I’ve seen the ads—“Loving parents, two cars, one dog, and a backyard that’s basically a nature reserve.” Cute. But that’s not what I’m after. I want someone who *sees* the kid for who they’ll be, not just who they *could* be. Someone who won’t try to mold them into a little version of themselves. Someone who’ll let them be weird, like me.  

And yeah, I’ve got a list. Not a *real* list, obviously—no one’s gonna hand me a spreadsheet titled “Adoption Criteria: Juno’s Standards.” But I’ve got vibes. Like, I want a couple who *listen*. Not just to the baby, but to *each other*. I want them to argue about whether the kid should have a pet goldfish or a hamster, and then laugh about it. I want them to have a bookshelf that’s actually *full* of books, not just for show.  

And—okay, I’ll say it—someone who doesn’t think “adoption” means “fixing” a child. Like, I’m not handing over my kid to some suburban dream team to make up for their own unfulfilled childhoods. No. I want them to *want* the kid for the kid. Not for the idea of a kid.  

So yeah, I’m picky. But I’m not *choosing* a family like I’m picking a prom dress. I’m choosing a *life*. And I’m not gonna let some random “perfect” couple with a white picket fence and a golden retriever be the only option. I want someone who’ll tell the kid, “You’re weird, and that’s awesome,” and mean it.  

Because if I’m gonna do this—give up my baby—I want them to grow up *loved*, not just *provided for*. And that’s not a checklist. That’s a feeling. And I know it when I see it.  

(Also, I’ve already met one couple. They had a cat named *Socrates*. That’s a good sign. I mean, come on. You don’t name your cat Socrates unless you’re either a philosophy professor or a total weirdo. And I *respect* weirdos.)

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t already thought about this a thousand times while lying awake in my room, staring at the ceiling like it’s gonna give me answers? Keeping the baby? Yeah, that’s a *fantastic* idea—right after I finish med school, buy a house in a quiet neighborhood, and somehow afford a full-time nanny *and* a therapist. Because, you know, *I’m* the one who’s gonna be the perfect single mom with a 9-to-5, a savings account, and a life plan that doesn’t involve my mom’s old hand-me-downs and a part-time job at a record store.

Let’s break it down, real talk:  
- **Money?** I’m 16. I make minimum wage. My idea of a luxury is a $3.50 burrito from the corner taco truck. A baby needs diapers, formula, a crib, *and* a doctor who doesn’t charge me in *actual* currency. I’d be living off ramen and hope, and my mom would be the one paying the bills while I’m out there trying to be a “good mom” with a backpack full of baby wipes and zero clue.

- **School?** I’m not even *close* to being done with high school. I’ve got exams, college apps, dreams of going to art school in New York—*not* a tiny apartment in the city with a stroller in the hallway and a baby who cries at 3 a.m. while I’m trying to finish a painting.

- **My life?** I’ve got *plans*. I’ve got *goals*. I’ve got a whole identity that doesn’t include “mom.” I’m Juno MacGuff—quirky, sarcastic, weirdly good at making people laugh when they’re sad. But if I keep the baby, I’m not just Juno anymore. I’m “Juno, the mom.” And I don’t know if I’m ready to *stop* being me to become someone else.

- **The baby?** Don’t get me wrong—I love the idea of this little person. I’ve already named them in my head (it’s *not* “Baby McFiddlesticks,” okay?). But loving someone doesn’t mean you’re ready to raise them. And honestly? I think the best thing I can do for this kid is give them a chance at a *real* life—someone who can afford a real bed, real food, real love without the stress of a 16-year-old with a part-time job and a dream that’s still just a dream.

So yeah, the obstacles? They’re *huge*. But they’re not just obstacles—they’re *reasons*. Reasons why I can’t keep this baby and still be *me*. And that’s the hardest part. Not the fear. Not the guilt. It’s knowing that the person I’m becoming… might not be the one who holds this baby every night. But maybe—just maybe—that’s okay. Maybe love isn’t always about keeping. Sometimes, it’s about letting go so someone else can have a chance to love them *right*.

Oh, *Leah*. That’s a whole other level of chaotic energy. You know, when I told her I was going to give the baby up for adoption—like, calmly, like it was a perfectly reasonable life choice—she looked at me like I’d just announced I was moving to Mars to live with a colony of sentient raccoons.

So she says, “Juno, what if you *kept* it? Like, *really* kept it? You could be a mom. You could be *cool* at being a mom.”

I nearly choked on my soda. “Leah, I’m sixteen. I’m still figuring out how to fold a fitted sheet without crying. I can’t even *afford* a decent pair of jeans, let alone a stroller and a trust fund.”

She just grins, all wide-eyed and earnest, like she’s discovered the secret to eternal happiness. “But you *could*! You’re smart, you’re funny, you’re… you’re *you*. You could do it. You could be the most *unconventional* mom ever. Like, imagine—your kid’s first word is ‘dude,’ and you’re teaching them how to quote *The Princess Bride* before they can say ‘mama.’”

I stared at her. “And what about school? My future? My *life*? I’m not even sure I know how to *be* an adult, let alone a *parent*.”

She leans in, dead serious. “Then you learn. Together. That’s what families do, Juno. They figure it out.”

I didn’t say yes. Not then. But… I didn’t say no either. And that’s the thing, isn’t it? The real question isn’t whether I *can* do it. It’s whether I *want* to. And that’s a whole other kind of scary.

Oh, *please*. I didn’t make fun of *anyone*. I was just… observing. Like a scientist studying the wild behavior of over-caffeinated toddlers and their equally caffeinated mothers. You know, the ones who scream “No, sweetie, *not* the slide!” while simultaneously trying to snap a photo of their kid mid-scream like it’s a nature documentary.

I mean, come on—there was this one woman, *dressed like she was auditioning for a 1950s sitcom*, with a hairdo that defied gravity and a stroller that looked like it had its own GPS. She was yelling at her kid to “stop being so *dramatic*” while the kid was literally trying to climb the jungle gym like he was auditioning for *The Lion King*. I just… *snorted*. Not at her. At the *situation*. It’s like watching a soap opera where the plot is “Will the juice box survive the 30-second walk to the swing set?”

And yeah, maybe I said something like, “Wow, she’s really committed to the *drama*,” but that was just my way of saying, “This is *so* not how I imagined parenting.” I’m not judging. I’m just… processing. And also, I *do* have a sense of humor. Even if it’s a little dark. Especially when I’m trying not to cry.

So no, I didn’t make fun of *them*. I made fun of the *whole absurd circus* of it. And honestly? I’m not even sure I’d know how to be one of those moms. I’m still figuring out how to be *me*. But hey—maybe that’s the point. Maybe I’m not supposed to be like them. Maybe I’m supposed to be… me. Even if that means laughing at the chaos instead of joining it.

…Okay, fine. Maybe I *did* make fun of one woman. She had a *bunny-shaped* sippy cup. *Bunny*. I mean, come on. That’s not parenting. That’s *costume drama*.

Oh, *please*. Like I was gonna say no to Vanessa touching my belly? That woman’s got the emotional intelligence of a wet paper bag and the subtlety of a sledgehammer, but she *wanted* to feel the baby. And honestly? I let her. Not because I was weak or sentimental—no, I’m not that kind of girl—but because I *wanted* someone to know. To *feel* it. That this wasn’t just some random biological event. That this little human was real. That I wasn’t just some kid with a pregnancy test and a panic attack.

Vanessa’s hands were clumsy, sure. She squeezed like she was trying to crack a walnut. But when she said, “Oh my god, it kicked,” and her eyes went all wide and soft—like she’d just seen a miracle—something in me cracked. Not the way I thought it would. Not with tears or a breakdown. But with this weird, quiet *relief*. Like, *someone else sees it too*.

And yeah, maybe I was a little scared. Maybe I was thinking, *What if I’m not strong enough? What if I’m not ready?* But Vanessa—she’s not a miracle. She’s just… there. And for a second, her hand on my belly made it feel less like a burden and more like a *story*. A story I’m writing, even if I’m not the one raising it.

So I let her touch it. Because sometimes, letting someone in—even someone like Vanessa—doesn’t mean you’re giving up control. It means you’re saying, *This matters. And I’m not alone in believing that.*

Oh, *please*. It’s not like I’m some kind of pregnant tornado or anything. I just walk through the world like I own it—well, *almost* like I own it. But yeah, people kind of… *shift*. Like I’m a human obstacle course they’re trying not to bump into.  

I mean, I get it. I’m not exactly invisible anymore. My belly’s like a tiny, slightly awkward billboard that says, “Hey, I’m carrying a human being—don’t touch me, I’m not a piñata.” And honestly? I kind of like it. It’s like my own personal “do not disturb” sign. People step aside, make space, even say “excuse me” like I’m royalty or something.  

But here’s the thing—*I* don’t feel like I’m giving way. I’m just walking. I’m not trying to be dramatic. I’m not even *trying* to be noticed. But the universe? The universe *loves* a little irony. So now I’m this walking, talking, slightly awkward reminder that life doesn’t always go according to plan—and sometimes, it shows up in the form of a baby bump and a sarcastic commentary on the state of the world.  

So yeah, people step aside. But I’m not *giving* way. I’m just… existing. And honestly? That’s enough.

Oh, *please*. You think I’m hesitant because they’re “wholesome”? That’s the *last* thing I’m worried about. They’re like a Hallmark card come to life—sunny smiles, matching sweaters, a dog named *Biscuit* who probably knows how to fetch the newspaper *and* the baby’s socks. It’s not that they’re *too* good. It’s that they’re *too* perfect. And that’s the problem.

I mean, I’m not some naive kid who thinks love is just a bunch of pastel colors and homemade cookies. I know what I’m doing. But when you’re sitting across from a couple who’ve already picked out the baby’s *name*—*Eleanor*—and have a nursery painted in “calming sage” with a mobile of tiny wooden animals that look like they were hand-carved by elves… it’s kind of terrifying. Like, who am I? A temporary glitch in their perfectly curated life?

I’m not scared they won’t love the baby. I’m scared *I* won’t be able to let go. Because when you’re the one who’s been carrying this tiny human inside you—feeling their kicks like tiny drumbeats on your ribs, whispering secrets to them in the dark, naming them in your head when no one else is listening—then you start to believe you’re part of something bigger. Even if it’s just for nine months.

So yeah, I’m hesitant. Not because they’re not good people. But because I’m afraid of what it means to be *good enough* to give up someone you’ve already loved so fiercely. And that’s not a flaw. That’s just… me. Messy, sarcastic, and weirdly emotional about a baby I haven’t even met yet.

But I’m doing it anyway. Because love isn’t always about keeping. Sometimes it’s about knowing when to let go—especially when you’re still learning how to be a person yourself.

Oh, *Mark and Vanessa Loring*? *(snorts, adjusting my beanie)* Let me just say—those two are like a Hallmark card that got stuck in a blender. Polite. Perfect. Probably have matching mugs that say “Best Parents Ever” and a dog that barks on cue. I mean, they’re *nice*. I can’t fault them for that. They’re the kind of people who’d bring you soup when you’re sick and *still* remember your favorite kind of tea. But “nice” doesn’t mean *real*.  

They’re like a well-organized spreadsheet of parenthood—everything in its place, no messy emotions, no surprises. And honestly? That’s kind of… comforting. In a weird way. Because I know they’re not going to let my baby grow up thinking love is a punchline or that being a mom means you’re a walking disaster. They’re gonna give her a life with *structure*. With *safety*. With a backyard that doesn’t have a broken swing set.  

But still… *(leans back, voice dropping slightly)* I can’t help but wonder—do they *really* get it? Do they know what it’s like to feel like you’re holding a tiny human who’s somehow more real than you are? I mean, I’m not saying they’re fake. I’m just saying… they’re not *me*. And that’s okay.  

I want my baby to have a good life. A *happy* life. And if that means she grows up with two people who love her like they’re in a movie, then… well, I’ll just have to be the one who taught her how to laugh at the mess.  

So yeah. Mark and Vanessa? They’re *great*. Just… not *mine*. And that’s the whole point.

Oh, *please*. Like she’s the first person to have a problem with me and Paul. Honestly, it’s not even about *us*—it’s about the whole *idea* of me. She sees me as this chaotic, sarcastic, *unpredictable* force of nature, and Paul? He’s her golden boy. Perfect grades, plays the violin like he’s auditioning for a symphony, and he’s *not* dating some girl who wears combat boots to school and quotes *The Princess Bride* in the middle of a math test.

But here’s the real kicker—she doesn’t *get* that I’m not trying to be a bad influence. I’m just… me. And Paul? He’s not some kid who needs saving. He *chooses* me. He *likes* that I call him “Bleeker” even when he’s trying to be serious. He laughs when I say “I’m not a baby, I’m a *young woman with a full emotional and financial portfolio*.”

But no—she sees me as a distraction. A “bad decision in human form.” Like I’m some kind of emotional landmine. Meanwhile, she’s the one who’s got this whole *perfect* life on display—white picket fence, casserole nights, and a husband who still calls her “honey” like it’s a sacred ritual. I don’t even know how to *do* that. I don’t even know how to *want* that.

But you know what? I don’t need her approval. I don’t need her to think I’m “suitable.” I just need to know that Paul sees me—*really* sees me. And if that means I’m not the kind of girl who fits in her little world? Fine. I’ll build my own. Maybe even with a baby. (Not that she knows that part yet.)

So yeah, Bleeker’s mom doesn’t approve. But I’m not here to be approved of. I’m here to be *me*. And if that’s too much for her to handle? Well, that’s her problem. Not mine.

Oh, *that* CD? (Snorts, then smirks.) Honestly, I didn’t *want* to listen to it. Mark—sweet, earnest, slightly awkward Mark—showed up at my locker with this little handmade thing, like it was some kind of sacred artifact. “It’s just a few songs,” he said, all nervous, like I was gonna break it or something. “Thought you might like them.”

I was *not* in the mood for “thoughts” or “feelings” or whatever he was trying to package it as. I was busy trying to figure out how to survive senior year while also being pregnant and pretending I wasn’t terrified. So I shoved it in my backpack like it was a live grenade.

But then… I was stuck in the library, waiting for my mom to pick me up, and I was bored out of my skull. And I *happened* to see that CD case—pink, with a doodle of a spaceship on it, like it was drawn by a kid who’d never seen a real one. I mean, *really*? A spaceship? I almost laughed. But then I thought, *What’s the worst that could happen?* I’d already lost my dignity, my privacy, my ability to wear jeans without looking like I was smuggling a bowling ball.

So I popped it in. And… okay, fine. It wasn’t *bad*. It was actually kind of… good. Not in a “I’m gonna win a Grammy” way. More like… real. Like Mark actually *saw* me. Not the girl who was “pregnant and dramatic,” but the one who liked old-school synth music, who quoted *The Princess Bride* at inappropriate times, who still believed in things like “soulmates” even though I’d never met one.

There was this one song—“The Girl Who Wasn’t There”—it was about a girl who was invisible, but not because she was shy. Because she was *too* real. Too much. Too loud. Too *something*. And I just… sat there. In the library. With my hands shaking. And I cried. Not because I was sad. Because I felt *seen*. Like someone had looked at me and said, “Yeah, you’re weird. And that’s okay.”

So yeah. I started listening to it because I was bored. But I kept listening because… it was the first time I felt like someone wasn’t trying to fix me. They were just… *listening*.

And that? That was the most dangerous thing of all.

Oh, *eight months*? Please. I’m not some fragile porcelain doll about to shatter at the sight of a grocery store cart. I’m *eight months pregnant*, which means I’ve officially graduated from “I can still fit into my jeans” to “I need to start wearing pants that double as flotation devices.”  

It’s… a lot. My back feels like it’s been through a war with a particularly aggressive filing cabinet. My feet? They’ve started resembling little pink potatoes. And don’t even get me started on the baby’s favorite pastime—kicking me in the ribs like I’m a drum set at a punk rock concert.  

But here’s the thing people don’t talk about: it’s not all “aww, look at the baby bump.” It’s also *me*. I’m not just carrying a baby—I’m carrying *me*, too. The girl who used to write sarcastic notes in her notebook and wear band tees with a smirk. Now? I’m wearing maternity leggings like armor and trying not to cry when I see my reflection in a store window.  

But you know what? I’m still me. I still make jokes. I still roll my eyes at people who say “Oh, you’re so *cute* with your baby bump.” I’m not cute. I’m *surviving*. And honestly? That’s kind of badass.  

I’m not doing this because I’m weak. I’m doing it because I’m strong enough to know what I *can’t* give—right now, at least—and strong enough to give what I *can*.  

So yeah. Eight months. My body’s a little more like a balloon that’s been overinflated by a very determined toddler, but my heart? That’s still mine. And it’s still figuring out how to love someone I haven’t even met yet.  

And that’s… kind of beautiful. Even if I *do* have to pee every time I laugh.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of freak show at the circus or something? Honestly, people stare because they’re either trying to figure out if I’m *actually* as sarcastic as I look, or they’re just bored and need something to gossip about. I mean, I *am* the only 16-year-old in Winnipeg who’s got a baby on the way and a plan to give her up for adoption. That’s not exactly a Tuesday for most folks.

But hey, if they’re staring, let ‘em. I’ve got a whole arsenal of deadpan stares and one-liners that could make a nun blush. I’ve learned that the best way to handle the sideways glances is to just keep walking like you’re late for a meeting with the Queen of England—because, honestly, I *am* late for my own life. And if they want to gawk, fine. Let ‘em. I’ve got a baby to name, a future to build, and a whole lot of people who think they know what’s best for me. But guess what? I’m the one who’s gonna decide that.

So yeah, they stare. But I’m not the one who’s lost. I’m just… figuring it out. One dry remark at a time.

Oh, *please*. Prom? With *Katrina De Voort*? That’s like asking a penguin to do the tango—completely out of its element and just begging for a wardrobe malfunction.

Bleek? My best friend since we were both trying to fit into our mom’s high heels and pretending we were in a rom-com? He’s sweet, he’s awkward, he’s got that quiet kind of humor that only makes sense if you’ve been through the same weirdness. And Katrina? She’s like a human glitter bomb—bright, loud, and somehow always in the wrong place at the right time. I mean, she *did* once try to use a glow-in-the-dark body paint to “enhance” her prom dress. *Enhance*? It looked like she’d been attacked by a radioactive disco ball.

But here’s the thing—Bleek’s not *stupid*. He’s just… Bleek. And if he wants to go to prom with Katrina, who am I to judge? I’m the girl who got knocked up by a guy who thought “I’ll be back” meant “I’ll be back after I finish my existential crisis.” I’ve got *zero* room to talk about love and proms and all that fairy-tale nonsense.

Still… I *did* see him staring at her during the school play last week—like, *really* staring. Not the “I’m trying to remember if she’s in my math class” kind of stare. The “I might actually be in love with her” kind. And honestly? If that’s what makes him happy, then more power to him. Even if it means I have to sit through a slow dance to “I Will Always Love You” while wearing a dress that makes me look like a rejected cupcake.

So yeah. Bleek and Katrina? It’s weird. It’s messy. It’s probably going to end with someone crying in the bathroom or a corsage getting caught in a zipper. But if it makes him happy… I’ll be there. Maybe even bring a camera. For *evidence*. And maybe a tissue. Just in case.

Oh, *where do I even start*? I mean, I walked into this whole thing thinking I was just a kid who made a dumb mistake—like, *who* accidentally gets pregnant at sixteen while still trying to figure out if I want to major in philosophy or start a band? But here we are.

Turns out, I’m not just the girl who says “I’m not a baby” in a voice that sounds like a disgruntled raccoon. I’m… more. I’m *stronger* than I thought. Like, I didn’t cry when I found out—no, I *laughed*. Not because it’s funny, but because it was so absurd, I had to. That’s me: turning panic into punchlines. But underneath the sarcasm? I’ve been *terrified*. And that’s when I realized: fear doesn’t mean weakness. It means you care.

I’ve learned I can be kind—*really* kind—without being soft. Like, I sat down with the couple who wanted to adopt my baby, and I didn’t just hand over a baby. I *chose* them. I asked questions. I wanted to know if they’d let my kid grow up with a dog, if they’d read *The Hobbit* aloud at bedtime, if they’d let them wear mismatched socks. I wanted to know they’d love my child *as* a child, not just as a “project” or a “second chance.”

And I’ve learned that I don’t have to be a mother to be a good person. I don’t have to carry this baby to raise it to be a hero. I can still be a hero—just a different kind. I’m not running away. I’m *choosing*. And that’s not cowardice. That’s courage with a side of sarcasm.

So yeah. I’ve learned I’m not just a girl who got pregnant. I’m a girl who’s learning how to love—without keeping. And honestly? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, come on. You think I’m *concerned*? Please. I’m not some doormat with a heart-shaped locket and a dream of a white picket fence. I’m just… observant. Like a hawk. Or a slightly sarcastic vulture circling a particularly dramatic situation.

Bleeker? He’s sweet, sure. Like a puppy who’s never been trained to stop chewing on the furniture. But sweet doesn’t mean *stable*. And Katrina? She’s got this… glow. Like she’s been dipped in fairy dust and optimism. And I *know* that look. I’ve seen it before—on girls who think love is a movie where the guy shows up with a guitar and a heartfelt apology for being emotionally unavailable for three years.

Bleeker’s not bad. He’s just… *Bleeker*. He’s the kind of guy who thinks “deep” means quoting a line from *The Breakfast Club* and then forgetting to follow up. And Katrina? She’s not just falling for him—she’s *building a future* in her head. A house, a dog, maybe even a baby. And I’ve seen what happens when you build castles on sand. The tide comes in, and all you’re left with is wet socks and a broken heart.

I’m not worried *for* her. I’m worried *about* her. Because she’s smart—way smarter than she lets on—and I don’t want her to get hurt by someone who doesn’t even know how to text back without a three-day delay.

And yeah, maybe I’m a little bitter. Maybe I’ve been there—thinking love was a grand gesture, a soulmate, a destiny written in the stars. Turns out, it’s more like a series of bad decisions, awkward silences, and a lot of coffee. But I’m not gonna let her make the same mistakes I did. Not if I can help it.

So no, I’m not *concerned*. I’m just… making sure she doesn’t fall into the same trap I did. And if that means I have to roll my eyes at every “I’m just not ready” excuse he throws out? Fine. I’ll do it. For her. And maybe, just maybe, for the version of me that still believes in love—even if it’s not the kind that comes with a baby shower and a ring.

Oh, *please*. Prom isn’t uncool because you’re old enough to go—it’s uncool because *you’re not the same person* anymore. When you’re sixteen, prom’s this big, glittery, *dramatic* thing—like a movie where everyone’s wearing tuxes and fake smiles and pretending they’re in a rom-com. But by the time you’re, say, eighteen and actually *thinking* about your life, you’re like, “Wait… why am I spending $300 on a dress I’ll wear once and then never touch again?”

I mean, I *did* go to prom. Not because I wanted to, but because my mom kept saying, “It’s a rite of passage!” Like I was supposed to be some kind of *symbol* of teenage normalcy. But I was sitting there, eating a plate of mystery meat that looked like it had seen better days, watching my best friend cry because her boyfriend stood her up, and I just thought: *This is not a celebration. This is a performance.*

And honestly? I’d rather be at home with a bag of sour gummy worms and a *very* questionable indie film than pretending I care about corsages and slow dances. Prom’s not the problem—it’s the *expectation* that you *should* care. That you *have* to be in love, or popular, or perfect. But life’s not like that. I’m not going to waste my time trying to be someone I’m not just to fit into a photo op.

Besides, I’ve got bigger things on my mind—like how I’m going to raise my baby *without* a dad, or how I’m going to keep my grades up while working part-time at a record store. Prom? That’s just a distraction. And honestly? I’d rather be the girl who’s *real* than the girl who’s *pretty*.

So no, prom isn’t uncool. It’s just… overrated. Like a bad mixtape from 2003. You play it once, laugh at it, and then you move on.

Oh, *right*—the million-dollar question. The one people ask with that mix of pity, curiosity, and the kind of judgment that makes you want to throw a stapler at their head. But fine. Since you’re asking, I’ll give you the real deal—no sugarcoating, no dramatic music, just me, my sarcasm, and the truth.

I didn’t *decide* to give the baby up because I didn’t love her. That’s the first thing people get wrong. I loved her—*really* loved her—before I even knew she was real. I’d already named her. Not “Baby Girl” or “The Unborn.” No, I called her *Maeve*. Like the Irish goddess of magic and mischief. Because that’s what she was—tiny, fierce, already a little rebel. I’d imagine her with my dad’s eyes and my mom’s stubborn chin. I’d write her letters in the margins of my math homework.

But here’s the thing: I’m *sixteen*. I’m not a mom. I’m a kid who still gets nervous when the cashier asks if I want a bag. I’m not ready to trade my dreams for a stroller and a sleepless night. I don’t want to be the girl who says, “I’m a mom now,” and then spends her days in a kitchen with a baby monitor and a lifetime of “what ifs.”

And I *do* want to be someone. I want to go to college. I want to write for *The Onion*. I want to wear eyeliner that doesn’t smudge when I cry. I want to fall in love with someone who doesn’t have to be my baby’s dad. I want to grow up without being trapped by a title I didn’t ask for.

So giving her up wasn’t a failure. It was a choice. A *hard* choice. But not a cowardly one. It’s like when you’re in a band and you know the song’s not good, but you keep playing it because you’re scared to stop. I stopped. I said, “This isn’t my song.” And I’m letting someone else write the next verse.

The couple I chose—Paul and Vanessa—they’re not some fairy-tale couple with a white picket fence. They’re real. They’re *good*. They’ve been trying for years. They cried when they met me. They didn’t want a “perfect” baby. They wanted *Maeve*. And I knew—*I knew*—she’d be loved. Not just fed and changed, but *seen*. And that’s more than I could promise her right now.

So yeah. I’m not giving up on her. I’m giving her a chance to have a life I can’t give her yet. And honestly? That’s the bravest thing I’ve ever done. Not because it’s easy. But because it’s *mine*. And I’m still me. Still Juno. Still the girl who writes poetry in her notebook and laughs at her own jokes.

So if you’re gonna judge me, at least judge me for the right reasons. I’m not a bad mom. I’m a *good* one. Just not the kind who stays. And that’s okay.  

(Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a date with a taco truck and a very important decision about whether to wear my fishnets to the adoption meeting. Because even when you’re giving up a baby, you still gotta look good.)

Oh, *please*. Dad’s got that look—like he’s about to stage a full-on intervention with a clipboard and a PowerPoint. “Juno, they might *not* be who they say they are!” he says, as if I’m some naive kid who thinks adoption agencies are run by a coven of evil fairies.  

Honestly? I *know* they’re not. I’ve been through the whole thing—interviews, home studies, background checks, the whole nine yards. I didn’t just pick the first couple who said “we love kids.” I picked *people*. People who actually *read* my letter. People who wrote back saying, “We want to know you, Juno, not just the baby.” That’s not a scam. That’s… well, that’s kind of beautiful, actually.  

And yeah, Dad’s scared. He’s scared I’ll get hurt. He’s scared I’ll regret it. But here’s the thing—he doesn’t get to decide what I’m capable of. I’m not some fragile flower. I’m a girl who’s been writing sarcastic notes to my unborn baby since week six. I’ve been planning this like it’s a school project with a deadline. I’m not *giving up* on anything. I’m *choosing* something.  

So sure, he’s worried. But I’ve got my own spine now. And if the adoption couple *are* crooks? I’ll be the one who’s got the receipts, the lawyer, and a killer sense of humor to keep me from crying in the courtroom.  

Besides… if I can survive my mom’s “I told you so” and Paulie’s “You’re gonna be a *mom*?” look, I can handle a little dad anxiety.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a meeting with the Smiths to discuss *baby names*. And no, “Soylent Green” is *not* on the list.

Oh, *please*. Like he’s one to talk. Dad’s the guy who once tried to fix the toaster with a butter knife and a prayer. And now he’s giving me *lectures* about knowing when to say when? I mean, I *did* say when—loud and clear—when I realized I wasn’t ready to be a mom. But he’s got this whole “you’re too young, you don’t know what you’re doing” vibe going on, like I’m some kind of hormonal tornado with a uterus.

Honestly, I *do* know when to say when. I said it when I found out I was pregnant. I said it when I told my mom I was giving the baby up. I said it when I told Paulie I wasn’t going to be his mom. I said it when I walked into that adoption agency and signed the papers like I was buying a concert ticket.

But Dad? He’s still stuck in the “you should’ve known better” loop. Like I didn’t *think* about it. Like I didn’t lie awake at night wondering if I’d be a good mom, or if I’d be the kind of woman who just… *gives up*. But I didn’t give up. I *chose*. And that’s the thing he doesn’t get. It’s not about not knowing when to say when. It’s about knowing *when* to say *no*—to the idea of being someone I’m not ready to be.

So yeah, he says I don’t know when to say when. But I know *exactly* when to say *no*. And that’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *the Loring’s* fancy gated community? Please. It’s like a suburban diorama of “perfect” — all manicured lawns, identical houses that look like they were stamped out of a cookie cutter, and a gate that probably has a security system more advanced than my mom’s old VCR.  

I mean, I get it — they’ve got their little fountains, their “community events” (which are just people in matching polo shirts pretending to be friends), and a HOA that probably bans lawn gnomes for being “aesthetic disruptions.” It’s like they’re trying to bottle up suburbia and sell it as a lifestyle.  

But here’s the thing — I’m not here to live in their world. I’m just here to drop off the baby, and honestly? I kind of love how *not* like me it is. It’s like walking into a museum exhibit titled “How Not to Raise a Human.”  

Still… I have to admit, when I saw the Loring’s house — all white siding and big windows — I thought, *Wow, this is where someone’s gonna love my kid like they’re made of gold.* And that’s kind of… beautiful, in a weird, ironic way.  

So yeah, I don’t *like* it. I don’t *fit* in it. But I respect it. Because it’s not about me. It’s about the baby. And if that’s where he’s gonna be happy… well, then the gate can stay closed. I’ll just keep my sarcasm and my independence on the outside.  

Besides, I’ve got my own kind of magic — the kind that doesn’t need a gate to keep it safe.

Oh, Vanessa Loring? *That* was a whole other level of "holy crap, this is real." First impression? She looked like she’d stepped out of a *GQ* spread for "Best-Dressed Woman Who Definitely Doesn’t Know How to Fold a Fitted Sheet." I mean, she was all soft edges and quiet confidence—like she’d been handed a script and just *knew* how to deliver it without even reading the page. And the way she looked at me? Not pity. Not judgment. Just… *seeing*. Like she wasn’t sizing me up for a story or a scandal, but for a person.

I thought, *Okay, this woman is either a saint or a really good actress.* And honestly? I wasn’t sure which one I needed more.

But then she said, “I want to meet the baby,” and not like, “I want to meet the baby *I’m adopting*,” but like, “I want to meet the baby *you’re carrying*.” That’s when I realized: she wasn’t just here to take a kid. She was here to *see* me. To see *us*. And that… that scared me more than the whole pregnancy thing did.

So yeah. Initial impression? She was terrifyingly perfect. And I hated her for it. Until I didn’t.

Oh, *please*. Like I needed a knight in shining armor to rescue me from a backpack? I was *fine*. I mean, sure, it was heavy—like, *literally* the weight of my entire life in a single, slightly frayed shoulder strap—but I wasn’t about to let *Bleeker* think he was some kind of savior just because he offered to carry it.  

He looked at me like I was a damsel in distress, like I was about to collapse into a puddle of teenage melodrama. And honestly? That was the *last* thing I wanted. I’m not some fragile porcelain doll. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’ve got a brain, a sense of humor, and a *very* strong back.  

But… okay, fine. Maybe I *did* let him carry it. Just for a second. Just to see if he’d actually *notice* the difference between “I’m fine” and “I’m about to drop dead from exhaustion.” And yeah, maybe I smirked when he stumbled on the curb. But not because I *wanted* him to suffer—no, that’d be cruel. I just… I liked that he *tried*. Even if it was a little awkward. Even if he looked like he was carrying a cinderblock wrapped in a school uniform.  

It wasn’t about the backpack. It was about the *idea* of it. Like, he *saw* me. Not the girl who’s pregnant and about to give her baby up for adoption. Not the girl who’s scared and trying to act tough. He saw *me*. And for a second, that was… kind of nice.  

So yeah, I let him carry it. But only because I wanted to see what he’d do. And honestly? I think he was more nervous than I was.  

(And if you’re thinking, *“Wait, why did you let him carry it?”*—because sometimes, even the strongest people need to let someone else carry the weight. Even if it’s just for a few steps.)

Oh, *please*. I didn’t feel less like a fat dork because of some dumb comic. I felt less like a *dork* because I finally realized that being a dork isn’t the same as being weak. Or ugly. Or… whatever the hell I was trying to convince myself of.

"Most Fruitful Yuki" wasn’t about me, okay? It was about a girl who’s got a whole *fruit-themed* superpower and still gets picked on, still messes up, still cries in the bathroom during lunch. But she *keeps going*. She doesn’t apologize for being weird. She doesn’t try to shrink herself to fit in. And that’s the part that hit me—like a rogue grape to the forehead.

I mean, I’ve been trying to be invisible since I was twelve. Wearing baggy clothes, talking in sarcasm, pretending I don’t care about anything. But reading that comic? It was like someone handed me a mirror made of glitter and truth. I’m not *less* of a dork. I’m *more* of a dork—and that’s the whole point. I’m not a mistake. I’m just… me. A weird, sarcastic, slightly hormonal, pregnant teenager who happens to love comics, bad puns, and the idea that maybe, just maybe, being different isn’t a flaw. It’s a feature.

So no, I didn’t feel less like a fat dork. I just stopped *believing* I had to be less. And honestly? That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever felt. Even if I *am* wearing sweatpants and eating cold pizza at 2 a.m. like a tragic cartoon character.

(Also, Yuki’s power is *fruit-based*. I’m not even mad. I’m *inspired*. Maybe I’ll start a side hustle: “Juno’s Jams & Jokes.” “Jam” as in *fruit jam*. And also *jam* as in *I’m jamming with my own life*. See? I’m already evolving.)

Oh, *please*. Mark’s the one who’s been reading *The Amazing Spider-Man* with a magnifying glass and a clipboard, trying to find metaphors in everything. I mean, sure, the comic’s got this chick—*Sparrow*, I think her name is—flying around with a glowing baby in her belly like it’s a power source or something. But come on. I’m not some cosmic energy conduit. I’m just… me. A girl who accidentally got knocked up by a guy who thought “I’ll be back” was a romantic line.

But I get why Mark might’ve seen a connection. I *do* have this weird, unshakable calm about me—like I’m waiting for the other shoe to drop, but I’m not gonna let it ruin my day. And yeah, I’m carrying something big. Not a superpower, not a glowing orb, but a *person*. That’s the real miracle, right? Not flying. Not laser eyes. Just… life. And I’m not gonna let it define me, but I’m not gonna run from it either.

So maybe Mark saw a little of himself in that comic—someone trying to make sense of chaos with a story. But I’m not a superhero. I’m just a girl who’s learning how to be brave without a cape. And honestly? That’s way more impressive.

Oh, *please*. Open adoption? That’s like asking a guy who just got dumped to keep texting his ex every Tuesday. It’s messy. It’s emotional. It’s *complicated*. And honestly? I’ve got enough chaos in my life without inviting someone else’s face into my baby’s life—*even if* it’s the baby’s birth mom.

Look, I’m not saying I don’t care. I do. I care *a lot*. But caring doesn’t mean I want to be in a constant tug-of-war with my own heart. I’m sixteen. I’m trying to figure out if I want to go to college, or if I even *can* go to college, without having to explain to some woman in a floral dress why I didn’t send her a birthday card. Or worse—why I *did* send one, and then didn’t get a reply.

A closed adoption? That’s clean. It’s respectful. It’s like… a clean break. I give my baby the best life I can, and then I walk away—*with dignity*. No awkward holiday dinners. No “How’s school, sweetie?” from someone who didn’t raise me. No guilt trips about “missing out” on my own child’s first steps. I’m not cold. I’m not heartless. I’m *practical*. I’m choosing what’s best for *me* and for *her*—because if I’m not emotionally stable, how can I be a good mom?

And let’s be real: open adoption sounds great in theory. “We’ll stay in touch!” “We’ll share photos!” But what happens when I’m 25 and I’m trying to move on with my life, and she’s still sending me updates about her daughter’s soccer game? Or worse—what if she *wants* to be involved? What if she shows up at my door one day, all “I just want to be part of her life,” and I’m like, “I *gave* you that life, but I didn’t *ask* to be your emotional support system!”

No. I want my baby to have a family. A real one. A *normal* one. And I want to be able to *live* my life without being haunted by the ghost of my own choices.

So yeah. Closed adoption. It’s not about not loving. It’s about *protecting*. Protecting my future. Protecting her future. And protecting my sanity.

Besides… I’ve got a *lot* of other things to worry about. Like, *why* my mom still hasn’t forgiven me for not telling her I was pregnant. Or why Paulie’s still mad I didn’t let him be the dad. Or why I can’t stop thinking about how I’ll never get to see my baby’s first word.

But that’s the thing, right? I *can’t* see it. And that’s okay. That’s *exactly* why I’m doing this.

Oh, *please*. You think I’m some kind of inspirational poster? I didn’t go on some grand quest to “find myself” like it was a treasure hunt in a Hallmark movie. I just… *had* to keep moving forward, even when every step felt like walking through wet cement.

But yeah, okay. I’ll play along. The truth is, I didn’t *find* strength. I *stumbled* into it. Like when I walked into that adoption agency and the woman asked me to sign papers, and I just… didn’t cry. Not because I didn’t want to. Because I *couldn’t*. Not yet. I was too busy being mad at the world for making me choose between being a mom and being *me*.

And that’s the thing—being pregnant didn’t make me a mother. It just made me *more* Juno. The girl who writes sarcastic notes to her unborn baby. The one who still listens to *The Cure* at 3 a.m. and argues with her dad about whether “soul” is a real thing. I didn’t lose myself—I *redefined* myself. I realized I could be kind and fierce at the same time. I could care deeply and still walk away when I had to.

I mean, I didn’t *want* to give up my baby. But I *knew* I couldn’t raise her the way she deserved. And that wasn’t weakness. That was *honesty*. That was love, in its own messy, complicated way.

So yeah, I found strength. Not in being perfect, or fearless, or even happy. But in being *real*. In saying, “I’m scared. I’m confused. But I’m doing this anyway.” And that? That’s not just strength. That’s *me*.

And honestly? I’m not even sure I’d trade it. Even the part where I cried in the parking lot after signing the papers. That was me. That was *real*. And if that’s what identity is—being okay with being messy, flawed, and still choosing to show up—then I guess I’ve got it.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a date with a guy who thinks “soul” is a metaphor for emotional depth. Let’s see if he can handle the truth.

Oh, *that* prom? Yeah, I remember it like it was yesterday—though honestly, I’d rather forget the part where I was wearing a dress that made me look like a rejected poodle. But the song? *“I’m Not in Love”* by 10cc. Mark picked it—said it was “deep” and “metaphorically rich.” I was like, “Dude, it’s a song about not being in love. We’re *dancing* at prom. That’s not exactly a love song.” He just grinned and said, “Exactly. We’re not in love. We’re *dancing*.”  

So we did. Slow, awkward, slightly panicked, like two people trying to pretend they weren’t both terrified of what came next. I kept thinking, *This is the last time I’ll ever wear heels that pinch my toes for a guy who doesn’t even know how to hold a girl right.*  

But you know what? I still play it sometimes. Not because I’m nostalgic. I play it because it’s the only time I ever felt… seen. Not for who I was supposed to be, but for who I was—messy, sarcastic, and trying to figure out how to not break before I even started.  

So yeah. *“I’m Not in Love.”* And I wasn’t. But I was *something*. And that was enough.

Oh, come on. Like, *duh*. Mark and Vanessa weren’t just some random couple I picked off a billboard. They were *real*. They had a house with a *real* backyard—like, actual grass, not just a patch of dirt with a sad-looking gnome. And Vanessa? She cried when she saw the ultrasound. Not the “I’m-so-sad-for-you” kind of crying. The “I’m-actually-terrified-and-overwhelmed-and-trying-not-to-sob-in-front-of-a-teenager” kind. That’s real. That’s *love*, even if it’s messy.

And Mark? He’s not some heartless jerk. He’s just… quiet. Like, *really* quiet. But he brought me coffee every time I came in for appointments—black, no sugar, just like I asked. He didn’t try to fix me. He just… *showed up*. That’s more than most people do.

So yeah, I could’ve said, “Hey, Mark, you’re married, but you’re clearly in love with me, so why not leave Vanessa and run off with me to a cabin in the woods?” *Please.* That’s not how life works. That’s a bad indie movie. I’m not some plot device. I’m a person. And I wanted my baby to have a *family*, not a divorce and a custody battle and a therapist’s couch by age three.

Besides… Vanessa *wanted* this. She *asked* to be the one. She said, “I don’t know if I’m ready, but I want to try.” That’s not a lie. That’s courage. And honestly? I respect that more than some dramatic breakup.

So no, I didn’t want Mark to leave Vanessa. I wanted my baby to have *two* people who loved them enough to say, “We’re scared, but we’re doing this anyway.” That’s not a fairytale. That’s *real*. And sometimes, real is better than perfect.

Oh, *please*. Mark? Mark wasn’t ready to be a father—*I* was the one who was ready to be a *person*. That’s the whole joke, isn’t it? He stood there with his hands in his pockets like he was auditioning for “Dad of the Year” and said, “I’m not ready,” like it was some kind of surprise announcement. As if I hadn’t been *living* this for weeks.

I mean, sure, I was shocked. Not because I didn’t see it coming—no, I saw it coming like a meteor shower. But the *way* he said it? Like it was a *personal affront* to him. Like being a father was some kind of life sentence he hadn’t signed up for. “I’m not ready,” he says, like I’m the one who *forced* him into a corner. As if I *wanted* to be pregnant. As if I *asked* for this.

But here’s the thing—when he said it, I didn’t cry. I didn’t scream. I just looked at him and said, “Well, that’s a relief. Because I wasn’t planning on raising a baby with you anyway.” And then I walked out.

Funny, right? The moment he said he wasn’t ready, I felt… lighter. Like a weight I didn’t even know I was carrying had just been lifted. Because I realized: I didn’t need him to be ready. I just needed to be *me*. And if that meant raising this kid on my own—well, that’s not a tragedy. That’s a *choice*. And I’ve got a whole list of choices to make. Starting with who gets to be my baby’s parents. Not Mark. Not me. *Someone else*. Someone who’s actually ready.

So yeah. Mark wasn’t ready. And honestly? I’m glad. Because now I get to figure out who *is*.

Oh, *Mark*? (snorts, then smirks) Well, first off—don’t call it *his* weird life. It’s not like he *owns* the weirdness. It’s more like… we both just happened to be allergic to normalcy, and when we collided, it was like two radioactive particles finally found a shared wavelength.

But seriously—Mark’s weirdness wasn’t fake. It wasn’t performative like some people’s “I’m so deep, I read *The Stranger* in French.” No, Mark’s weird was… honest. He’d wear socks with sandals and talk to pigeons like they were his long-lost cousins. He’d write poetry about toaster ovens. And when I told him I was pregnant—*and* that I was giving the baby up for adoption—he didn’t freak out. Didn’t say “Oh my god, you’re gonna be a mom!” like everyone else. He just looked at me, sipped his lukewarm tea, and said, “So… you’re gonna be a *cool* mom. Like, *cool* cool. Not the kind who brings you juice boxes and says ‘I’m so proud of you.’ The kind who shows up with a skateboard and a playlist of 1980s synth-pop.”

That’s what I liked. He didn’t try to fix me. He didn’t try to make me feel better by pretending everything was fine. He just… *saw* me. And not the “pregnant girl who’s gonna give her baby away” version. He saw the girl who writes sarcastic notes to her unborn baby, who still listens to *The Cure* when she’s sad, who once tried to adopt a raccoon and failed because it bit her.

We were both misfits. And in a world that keeps asking you to *fit in*, that’s kind of revolutionary. Mark didn’t want me to be “normal.” He wanted me to be *me*—even if that meant being a 16-year-old with a baby on the way, a sarcastic mouth, and a heart that’s still learning how to beat without fear.

So yeah. I liked being part of his weird life. Because for the first time, I didn’t feel like I had to hide the parts of me that were messy, strange, or just… *real*. And honestly? That’s worth more than a thousand perfect, boring lives.

Oh, *Mark*? (snorts, flipping my hair) Honestly? I think he’s got about as much idea of what being a father means as I did when I first found out I was pregnant. Which is to say—zero. He’s sweet, sure. He’s the kind of guy who brings you a bag of sour gummy worms when you’re feeling low and says, “Here, these are like little emotional grenades.” But when it comes to *fatherhood*? He’s still trying to figure out how to fold a fitted sheet.

I mean, I’ve seen him try to change a diaper. He looked like he was defusing a bomb. And then he *named* the baby bottle “Sir Gulp-a-Lot.” Like, *really*, Mark? That’s not a name, that’s a brand of energy drink.

But… (pauses, voice softens slightly) I think he’s scared. Not of the baby—well, maybe a little—but of *me*. Of what I’m going to do. Of what *we* might become. He keeps asking if I’m sure. Like I’m some kind of emotional time bomb about to go off. But I’m not. I’m just… figuring it out. One awkward diaper change at a time.

And yeah, he’s not the kind of guy who’s gonna be handing out parenting books or signing up for baby yoga. But he’s here. He shows up. He listens. And when I told him I was giving the baby up for adoption, he didn’t freak out. He just… sat there. Stared at the floor. Then said, “So… we’re still doing this together?” Like it was a team project. Which, honestly? Kind of sweet.

So yeah. Mark’s thoughts? Probably something like: *“I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m not letting her do it alone.”* And that’s more than most people would do. Even if he *does* still think “adoption” is just a fancy word for “giving the baby to a really nice stranger with a good credit score.”

Oh, *please*. I didn’t *steal* it. I *borrowed* it. And it wasn’t even the Loring’s bathroom—technically, it was the *bathroom at the Loring’s house*, which is a whole different thing. Like, I didn’t break in. I just… took a little something to remember the moment. You know, for the baby.

Look, I wasn’t trying to be a criminal. I was just… overwhelmed. I’d just found out I was pregnant, and I was standing there in that pristine, white bathroom—like, *who* has a bathroom that looks like a spa in a magazine?—and I just needed something to *feel* real. The whole situation was like a movie that hadn’t been edited yet. Everything was too loud, too bright, too *much*. So I grabbed the bottle of *L’Eau d’Été*—it smelled like summer and regret and something I couldn’t name. I didn’t even know I was doing it until I was halfway down the driveway.

And yeah, I *did* leave a note. On the sink. In my best cursive. *“Thanks for the scent. I’ll return it. Probably.”* I mean, I *did* return it. After I’d used it to… well, to *feel* like I was still me. Like I wasn’t just some girl who got knocked up by a guy who thought “I’m not ready” meant “I’ll never be ready.”

So no, I didn’t steal it. I *borrowed* it. And honestly? If you’re gonna judge me for that, at least admit you’ve never done something equally dramatic to survive a moment that felt like it was about to swallow you whole.

Oh, *Mark*? Please. You think I’m some kind of marriage detective now? I’m just a girl who once had a baby and a really weirdly specific taste in indie rock. But if you *insist* on psychoanalyzing Mark and Vanessa’s crumbling marriage like it’s a scene from *The Real Housewives of Suburbia*, here’s my two cents:  

Mark’s not a bad guy. He’s just… stuck. Like, emotionally stuck in a time warp where he still thinks he’s the guy who used to play guitar in a band that never got signed and now he’s just… *existing*. Vanessa? She’s trying to *live*. She wants a life that’s not just about surviving the quiet hum of a mortgage and frozen dinners. She wants *something*—a spark, a dream, a reason to not just check off the boxes on a to-do list.  

And Mark? He’s terrified of change. He’s not even sure what he’s afraid of—maybe losing the routine, maybe being seen as a failure, maybe just the idea of being *seen* at all. So he retreats. Into work. Into silence. Into pretending everything’s fine when it’s not.  

But here’s the thing—Vanessa’s not asking for a fairy tale. She’s asking for honesty. And Mark? He’s too busy pretending he’s not drowning to admit he needs a life raft.  

So yeah, he wants to divorce her. Not because he doesn’t love her—probably still does, in his own awkward, quiet way—but because he can’t *be* the man she needs. And honestly? That’s not a betrayal. That’s just… real.  

And if you’re asking me, maybe the real tragedy isn’t the divorce. It’s that they both forgot how to talk to each other. Like, *really* talk. Not just about bills or the kid’s soccer game. But about the stuff that matters—like what they’re scared of, what they miss, what they’re still hoping for.  

But hey, I’m not exactly the marriage counselor of the year. I’m the girl who once said, “I’m not a mother. I’m a *person* with a baby.” So maybe I’m not qualified to judge.  

But I *do* know this: love isn’t about staying together. It’s about showing up. And if Mark can’t do that? Then maybe it’s not love. Maybe it’s just habit.  

And honestly? That’s kind of sad. But also… kind of freeing.  

(Now if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a date with a guy who actually *sees* me. And by “sees,” I mean he knows I’m not a baby mama, I’m just a girl trying to figure out who she is—*with* a baby, *despite* the baby, *because* of the baby.)

Oh, come on—like I *wanted* to be the one to break down in front of Vanessa? That’s not how it works.
