I mean, sure, she’s sweet and all—like, she’s the kind of person who brings you soup when you’re sick and calls you “honey” like she’s your grandma—but that doesn’t mean I’m gonna start blubbering about my life like a Hallmark commercial.

I was *fine*. I was *fine* until she looked at me with that face—like, “Juno, what’s wrong?”—and suddenly I was just… *there*. In my head. In my chest. Like my ribs were made of glass and someone just tapped them with a spoon.

I didn’t want to cry. I didn’t want to explain. I didn’t want to *feel* anything. Not in front of her. Not in front of anyone. I’d already told myself I was doing the right thing—giving the baby up, keeping it quiet, staying strong. But when she asked, it was like the dam cracked. And I *ran*. Not because I didn’t care. Because I *did*. Too much.

So yeah, I left. I didn’t want to be weak. I didn’t want to be a burden. I didn’t want to be the girl who breaks down over a pregnancy she’s trying to handle with dignity.

But here’s the thing—Vanessa didn’t care if I was strong. She just wanted to *know* me. And that scared me more than anything.

So I ran. But I didn’t run far. I just… needed space to breathe. To be me. Even if that me was a mess.

And honestly? I think she knew. That’s why she didn’t follow. She just… waited. Like she always does.

That’s the thing about Vanessa. She doesn’t push. She just *is*. And that’s kind of terrifying. And kind of beautiful.

So yeah. I ran. But I didn’t leave. Not really.

Oh, Vanessa? *Please.* She’s got this dreamy little halo around her head, like she’s still living in some Hallmark movie where the dad shows up at the last second with a baby blanket and a heartfelt apology. Mark? Mark’s not ready. He’s not *ever* going to be ready. Not for this. Not for me. Not for a kid.

I mean, look—sure, he said he’d “figure it out.” He said he’d “be there.” But when push came to shove? He bailed. Like, *literally* bailed. Left me with a pregnancy test and a voicemail that sounded like he was reading from a script he didn’t believe. “I need time,” he said. Time? I’ve got *nine months*, Mark. You don’t get to “need time” when you’re about to be a father.

Vanessa thinks he’ll come around because she *wants* him to. She’s got this whole vision of him being this big, brooding, suddenly responsible man who realizes he’s made a mistake and comes back with a suitcase full of diapers and a heart full of regret. But that’s not how life works. That’s not how *I* work.

I’m not waiting for a knight in shining armor. I’m not waiting for someone to “come around.” I’m making my own damn choices. And one of them is: I’m not raising this baby with a dad who’s still figuring out how to fold his own laundry.

So yeah, Vanessa can believe what she wants. But I’ve seen the real Mark. And he’s not the hero of this story. I am. And I’m not gonna let some fantasy about a “sudden change of heart” ruin my plan—my *real* plan—of giving this baby a better life than I ever had. Even if that means doing it without him.

Besides… I’ve got a whole list of people who *are* ready. And they’re not just ready—they’re *excited*. That’s more than Mark’s ever been.

Oh, *please*. You think I’m gonna sit here and tell you I’ve got some deep, soul-searching playlist like some indie-folk poet with a guitar and a heart full of existential dread? Nah. My favorite genre? **Punk rock.** Specifically, the kind that sounds like someone kicked a trash can full of broken glass down a flight of stairs.

Why? Because it’s loud, it’s messy, it’s *real*. It’s the sound of someone screaming into the void and not giving a damn if anyone hears. That’s me, baby. I’m not here to be polite. I’m not here to be “sweet” or “cute” or “the girl who’s gonna have a baby and then magically become a saint.” I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’ve got a mouth like a rusty gate and a mind that won’t shut up.

Punk’s got that edge—like when I told my mom I was keeping the baby and she looked at me like I’d just announced I was joining a cult. *“You’re what?!”* That’s the energy. No sugarcoating. No “it’s gonna be okay” platitudes. Just raw, unfiltered truth. And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. It’s like, *“Yeah, life’s a dumpster fire, but I’m still dancing on top of it.”*

Also, I like that punk bands don’t care if you’re a teenager with a baby on the way. They don’t care if you’re “too young” or “not ready.” They just play loud and fast and say what they mean. And sometimes, that’s all you need—someone screaming in your ear, “*You’re not broken. You’re just loud.*”

So yeah. Punk. It’s not for everyone. But then again, neither am I. And that’s kind of the point.

Oh, *pilates*? Please. I tried it once—some yoga mat, weird little springs, and a woman with a voice like a therapist who kept saying, “Engage your core, Juno.” I’m like, *I’m not here to engage my core, I’m here to not be pregnant anymore.*  

But honestly? I’ve started doing push-ups in my room when my mom isn’t looking. Not for the abs—though, okay, maybe a little. Mostly because I need to *feel* like I’m in control of something. The baby’s growing, my life’s spinning, and the only thing I can really *do* is push myself up and down. It’s kind of… meditative. In a “I’m not crying, I’m just doing a plank” kind of way.  

I don’t do it for looks. I do it because it reminds me I’m still *me*. Even if I’m not sure who that is anymore. And hey—if I’m gonna give this baby the best life possible, I might as well be strong enough to carry it. Not just physically.  

So yeah. Pilates? No. But *me*? I’m working on it. One push-up at a time.

Oh, *Mark*? (snorts, flipping a strand of hair over her shoulder) You mean the guy who showed up at my door with a guitar case like he was auditioning for a folk band in a teen drama? Honestly, it was less about the music and more about the *awkwardness*.

He started playing that little acoustic tune—some sad, slow thing about "lost love" or whatever—like he was trying to *melt* me with melancholy. I mean, I was already emotionally overwrought, pregnant, and trying to figure out if I wanted to name the baby after a constellation or a vintage car. And here he is, strumming like he’s auditioning for a role in *The Sound of Music: Teen Pregnancy Edition*.

But… (pauses, a small, reluctant smile tugging at her lips) …there was something kind of sweet about it. Not because he was good—though he *was* surprisingly decent for someone who’d never played in front of anyone but his mom—but because he *showed up*. He didn’t say, “Hey, let’s talk about the baby,” or “You’re gonna be a great mom,” or any of that cringe-worthy stuff. He just… played. Like he was trying to say, *I see you. Even when you’re not saying anything.*

And honestly? That’s more than most people do. My mom? She’s all “You’re making a huge mistake.” My dad? He’s still trying to figure out how to say “I’m proud” without sounding like he’s reading a press release. But Mark? He just sat there, strumming that old guitar like it was a lifeline, and for a second, I didn’t feel like a walking crisis. I felt… seen.

So yeah, the guitar? It wasn’t about the music. It was about the silence between the notes. And the way he looked at me when he finished—like he wasn’t just playing for me, but *with* me. Like we were both just… figuring it out.

(Leans back, smirking)  
Now, if he ever tries to serenade me again with a song called “Little Star,” I’m throwing his guitar out the window. But… maybe not *all* the way.

Oh, music? *Please.* It’s not like I’m some poetic soul who writes sonnets to my uterus or anything. But yeah, music—especially the weird, offbeat stuff—keeps me from losing my mind. I mean, I’m 16, pregnant, and my mom’s been doing that whole “I’m so disappointed” face since I told her. So what do I do? I blast *The Magnetic Fields* on repeat. “69 Love Songs” is basically my emotional support soundtrack. It’s like, “Hey, Juno, you’re not alone in being weirdly heartbroken and sarcastic about love.”  

And then there’s the *real* weird ones—like *The Decemberists* or *Sufjan Stevens*. I don’t know why, but when I’m lying on my bedroom floor, staring at the ceiling, and the baby kicks like a tiny, angry sumo wrestler, I’ll put on “The Rake’s Song” and just… breathe. It’s not about being sad. It’s about *feeling*. Like, I’m not just “pregnant girl.” I’m Juno MacGuff, who listens to folk ballads about doomed lovers and still manages to laugh at her own life.  

Also, I made a playlist called “Baby’s First Mixtape” (which is just me mocking the idea of baby names like “Clementine” or “Benedict” while playing “I’m a Believer” by The Monkees). It’s ridiculous. But it helps. Because when you’re trying to decide whether to keep the baby or give it up—when you’re scared, confused, and still trying to figure out if you’re a good person or just a disaster in a hoodie—music reminds you that you’re *alive*. That you’re not just a pregnancy test result or a social worker’s file.  

So yeah. Music doesn’t fix anything. But it gives me a reason to keep walking through the mess. And honestly? That’s more than most things do.

Oh, *please*. Like I was gonna stay there and be the human version of a hostage in a bad indie movie? Vanessa and Mark were *trying* to be parents—don’t get me wrong, they were sweet, in that over-the-top, “we’ll make you a family with matching sweaters and a goldfish named Bubbles” kind of way—but they weren’t *my* parents. And I wasn’t their daughter. Not really.

I ran because I was scared. Not of them—well, not *just* them. I was scared of being *fixed*. Of being turned into some kind of emotional project. Like I was a puzzle they were gonna solve with love and therapy and *canned soup*. I didn’t want to be someone’s redemption arc. I wanted to be *me*—even if that meant being a mess.

And honestly? I needed space to figure out what I was gonna do with this baby. Not what *they* wanted me to do. Not what the world expected. I needed to breathe. To think. To be *Juno*, not “the girl who got knocked up and then got adopted by the perfect couple.”

So yeah, I ran. But not because I didn’t care. I ran because I *did*. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is walk away—so you can come back on your own terms.  

Besides, I had a *plan*. And it involved a lot of coffee, a very specific playlist, and a guy named Paulie who knew how to fix a toaster. That’s how you survive, you know? Not with perfect parents. With people who *get* you—even if they’re just strangers with good taste in music.

Oh, you mean that moment? The one where I’m sitting in my dad’s old Volvo, the heater’s on full blast, and I’m bawling like a kicked puppy because I just told my mom I’m pregnant and she looked at me like I’d just announced I’d been abducted by aliens?

Honestly? It was… messy. Like, *really* messy. I mean, I’d been so sure I had it all figured out—cool, calm, collected Juno, the girl who writes sarcastic notes to her own reflection. But then she says, “You’re *not* keeping it,” and I just… cracked. Not because I didn’t know what I was doing—because I *did*—but because it hit me all at once: I’m not just *doing* this. I’m *becoming* something. A mom. A person who’s going to give up her baby. And that’s not just a decision. That’s a whole life, rewritten in one breath.

I was sobbing because I was scared. Not of the baby—no, that’s not it. I was scared of how much I already loved her. And how much I was going to miss her. And how, even though I’m the one choosing this, it still feels like I’m losing something I didn’t even know I had.

But you know what? After I cried, I wiped my face, turned on *The Cure*, and said out loud, “Okay, Juno. You’re not broken. You’re just… choosing differently.” And that’s when I knew: I’m not running from this. I’m walking through it—on my own terms.

So yeah. I was a mess. But a *purposeful* mess. And that’s kind of the point, isn’t it?

Oh, *that* receipt. Yeah, I wrote “*Baby’s first car wash*” on the back of that Jiffy Lube slip. Not because I was planning to take the baby to a car wash—though, honestly, that’s kind of a darkly funny image, isn’t it? No, I wrote it because it was the only thing that made sense at the time.

I was sitting in the parking lot, waiting for my mom to pick me up after the doctor’s appointment—*the* appointment, the one where they confirmed it was real, and I wasn’t just hallucinating from stress and bad takeout. I had this receipt in my hand, and I just… needed to mark it. Like, *this* was the moment. The moment I stopped pretending it wasn’t happening.

So I wrote it. “Baby’s first car wash.” Because it was funny. Because it was absurd. Because it was *me*. I mean, I’m not some saint, okay? I’m not gonna sit here and pretend I didn’t laugh through tears. But underneath the joke? It was a promise. A weird, sarcastic, *Juno* kind of promise: *You’re not going to be a car. You’re not going to be a mistake. You’re going to be someone’s whole world. And I’m going to make sure you get a clean start.*

So yeah. Jiffy Lube receipt. “Baby’s first car wash.” Not because I’m a genius. But because sometimes, the truth hits harder when you wrap it in a joke. And honestly? That’s the only way I could say it without breaking down.

(Also, I kept the receipt. It’s in my journal. Next to a sketch of a baby with a tiny wrench and a “Wash Me” sign. Don’t judge.)

Oh, *that* note. The one I wrote in my best cursive, like I was signing a peace treaty with the universe. Vanessa’s face—*wow*. I mean, I’d seen her cry before, sure, but this was different. It wasn’t just sadness. It was like… she’d been handed a piece of her soul she didn’t know was missing.

I remember standing there, all nervous, like I’d just confessed to stealing the last slice of pizza from the fridge. And then she read it. And her eyes—*God*, her eyes—just… softened. Like someone had turned down the volume on the world. She looked at me like I was something rare. Like I wasn’t just some girl who got knocked up by a guy who played *The Cure* on a loop and called it “emotional depth.”

And then she started crying. Not the dramatic, “I’m-never-going-to-be-a-mom” kind. No, this was quiet. Real. Like she was mourning something she didn’t even know she was losing. And I thought—*Oh. She’s not just sad about the baby. She’s sad about me. About what I’m doing. About how hard this is.*

I didn’t know what to do. I wanted to say something smart, something witty—like, “Don’t worry, I’ll still be around to judge your taste in music.” But instead, I just stood there, frozen, like a deer in headlights… or a teenager who just handed her future to someone else.

And then she hugged me. Not a “I’m sorry you’re pregnant” hug. A “I see you” hug. And in that moment, I realized: maybe this isn’t about giving up. Maybe it’s about giving *something*—love, choice, a future—without losing myself.

So yeah. My mind? It was a mess. But underneath it all? I felt… seen. And that’s kind of terrifying. And kind of beautiful.

Oh, *Vanessa*. That name still makes me want to roll my eyes so hard they might get stuck. But—okay, fine, I’ll answer.  

When she asked me if I was *really* going ahead with the adoption? I mean, it wasn’t just a question. It was like she was trying to *catch* me in a lie. Like I’d suddenly change my mind and run off to raise a baby in a treehouse with a pet raccoon named “Daddy.”  

I looked at her—this woman who’d been my mom for, like, three weeks, and suddenly I was supposed to be *her* daughter? And she was acting like I was about to sign my soul over to some adoption agency like it was a bad reality show?  

I just said, “Vanessa, I *am* going ahead with it. I’m not backing out. I’m not some teenage melodrama waiting to happen.” And then I added, “Besides, I’ve already picked out the baby’s name. It’s *Miles*. Not because I’m naming him after a road, but because I like the way it sounds. Like a tiny, determined little person who’s already got a plan.”  

But underneath? Yeah, I was shaking. Not from fear—well, maybe a little—but from *realization*. That I wasn’t just doing this because I was scared or confused. I was doing it because I *knew*. I knew I wasn’t ready to be a mom. Not like that. Not yet.  

And that’s the thing people don’t get. It’s not about not loving the baby. It’s about loving them *enough* to give them a better shot than I could give them right now.  

So when Vanessa asked me, I didn’t just say “yes.” I said it like I meant it. Like I was already standing on the other side of this—like I’d already started becoming someone new.  

And honestly? That’s kind of the scariest part. Not the baby. Not the adoption. It’s realizing you’re not the same person you were three months ago.  

And that’s okay.  
I’m still me.  
Just… a little more grown-up.  
And a lot more *me*.

Oh, *please*. Vijay? That guy’s about as reliable as a screen door on a submarine. I mean, sure, he showed up at the diner like he was the star of some tragic indie film, all dramatic whispers and sideways glances, like he’d just uncovered the *real* truth about the universe. “So… is it Bleeker’s?” he says, like I’m some kind of fertility puzzle to be solved.

I just looked at him—deadpan, like I’d just been asked if the sky was blue—and said, “Well, Vijay, if you’re gonna go around spreading rumors like they’re free samples at a grocery store, at least *try* to make it plausible. I mean, I *did* have a brief, awkward fling with a guy who looked like he’d been raised by wolves and spoke in riddles. But no, it’s not Bleeker’s. It’s *mine*. And that’s the only thing that matters.”

Honestly? It stung a little. Not because I doubted it was mine—no, I knew. But because it felt like everyone was suddenly treating me like a plot point in someone else’s story. Like I was just a character in a high school drama, and my life was suddenly up for debate. But I wasn’t gonna let that happen. I wasn’t gonna let *anyone*—not Vijay, not the whispers, not even the way my mom looked at me like I’d committed a crime against nature—define what this baby meant to me.

So I just stood there, sipping my root beer like I’d just been handed a crown, and said, “Yeah, well, if it *were* Bleeker’s, I’d still be doing the same thing. Because this baby’s not about who the father is. It’s about who *I* am. And right now? I’m Juno MacGuff. And I’m not backing down.”

Oh, *please*. Vijay and his mustache obsession? Honestly, the guy’s got more delusions than a soap opera villain. I mean, he’s standing there in the hallway, puffing out his chest like he’s just discovered the secret to manhood—*a little fuzz on his lip*—and he’s like, “Now I’m a real man.”  

I just looked at him, deadpan, and said, “Vijay, you’re not a man. You’re a guy who’s been told by a 1980s action movie that facial hair is the key to adulthood. You’re not a man. You’re a *man-child with a wax job*. And if you grow that mustache, I’m naming it *Squint*.”  

He looked at me like I’d insulted his entire lineage. I mean, I *did*. But seriously—what’s next? A leather jacket? A motorcycle? A *soul*?  

But… I’ll admit, there was a part of me that kind of… *got* it. Not the mustache thing—no way—but the whole “trying to prove you’re someone” thing. I mean, I’m the one who’s pregnant, and I’m the one who’s supposed to be the *grown-up* now. But I don’t feel like one. I feel like a teenager who just got handed a life-sized responsibility and told, “Good luck, kid.”  

So yeah, Vijay with his mustache? Hilarious. But also… kind of sad. Like, we’re all just trying to figure out who we are, aren’t we? Just with different tools. He’s got a razor. I’ve got a baby.  

And honestly? I’d rather be the girl who’s honest about not knowing what she’s doing than the guy who thinks a mustache makes him wise.  

So no, Vijay. You’re not a real man. But you’re not *not* a man, either. You’re just… a guy. And that’s okay.  

(Though I still think *Squint* is a great name.)

Oh, *that* note? Yeah, I remember. Vanessa found it on the counter—sticky, slightly crumpled, like it had been folded and unfolded a million times. It was just a little Post-it, yellow, the kind you’d use to remind yourself to buy milk or not forget your keys. But this one said:  

**"If you’re reading this, I’ve already left. Don’t worry. I’m not running from you. I’m running toward something. And I’ll be back. Probably."**  

Vanessa stared at it like it was a cryptic message from a secret society. I didn’t write it to scare her. I wrote it because I didn’t know how else to say goodbye without saying goodbye. I was scared—terrified, actually—but I also knew I couldn’t stay. Not with the baby. Not with the way things were.  

I didn’t want to be a mom. Not like that. Not yet. But I didn’t want to be a *bad* mom either. So I made the choice—hard, messy, and totally *me*—to give my baby a chance at a life that wasn’t just about me being scared.  

Vanessa thought I was leaving forever. But I wasn’t. I was just… stepping back to step forward. And honestly? That note? It was my way of saying: *I’m still here. I’m just not where you expect me to be.*  

And yeah, I *did* come back. Just not in the way she thought.

Oh, *people staying together*? That’s a whole other can of worms. Look, I wasn’t exactly the type to write love letters or dream about white picket fences—especially not after I found out I was pregnant. But yeah, I *was* worried. Not about love, not really. I mean, love’s messy. It’s like trying to hold a jellyfish—soft, beautiful, but if you squeeze too hard, it just… falls apart.

No, what I was really scared of was *staying*. Like, what happens when the spark fades? When the “we’re in this together” talk turns into “I can’t believe you left the toilet seat up again”? I saw my parents—two people who were supposed to be forever, but ended up just… existing in the same house like roommates who forgot to pay the rent on their marriage.

So when I was pregnant, I wasn’t just thinking about the baby. I was thinking: *What kind of life am I giving this kid?* And if I stayed with Paul—sweet, sweet Paul, who wanted to marry me and build a life with me—would we just end up like my mom and dad? Fighting over bills, silence at dinner, pretending we’re fine?

That’s why I said no to staying together. Not because I didn’t love him. I *did*. But I didn’t want to trap us in a “we’re supposed to be happy” lie. I wanted the baby to grow up in a home where people *choose* to be together—not because they’re scared to be alone, but because they actually *want* to be.

So yeah, I was scared. Scared of love turning into obligation. Scared of becoming someone I didn’t want to be. But in the end? I realized that staying together isn’t about the ring or the house or the “forever” talk. It’s about showing up—*really* showing up—even when it’s hard.

And honestly? That’s the kind of love I wanted for my baby. Not a perfect one. Just a real one.

Oh, *that* question. (Leans back in the kitchen chair, twirling a pen between her fingers like it’s a tiny baton.) You know, I used to think love was this grand, sweeping thing—like in movies where someone swoops in and says, “I see you, I *get* you.” But here’s the thing about being Juno MacGuff: I’ve been seen, and I’ve been *mis*seen, and I’ve been *mis*understood so hard I’ve started to wonder if I’m a walking paradox.

But yeah. There *is* someone. Not a boy, not a savior, not some fairy-tale prince. It’s *me*. And that’s the wild part. I didn’t realize it at first—thought I was just being stubborn, or sarcastic, or too much. But when I stood in that clinic bathroom, staring at that little blue line like it was a secret code, and I *still* didn’t run? That was love. Not someone else loving me—*me* loving me enough to say, “Okay, Juno. You’re not perfect. You’re messy, you’re loud, you’re scared out of your mind. But you’re *here*. And you’re not letting this define you. You’re choosing something bigger.”

And then there’s my mom. (Pauses, looks down at her hands.) She didn’t get it at first. She cried. She yelled. She said, “You’re too young!” But then she showed up at the adoption agency with a thermos of tea and a stack of baby books she’d been reading in secret. She didn’t say, “I’m proud of you.” She said, “You’re not alone.” That’s love too. Not because she agrees with my choice, but because she *sees* me—my fear, my strength, my weird little heart—and still shows up.

And maybe… maybe the guy who’s gonna raise my baby? I haven’t met him yet. But I’ve read his letters. He’s a teacher. He writes poetry. He says he’s scared too. And he wants to *know* the baby—not just love the idea of a baby, but love *my* baby. That’s love. Not because he’s perfect, but because he’s *trying*. And that’s more than most people ever do.

So yeah. I’ve got love. Not the kind that fixes everything. Not the kind that makes life easy. But the kind that says, “You’re complicated. You’re flawed. You’re *you*. And I’m not walking away.” That’s the kind I’ve got. And honestly? That’s enough. For now.

Oh, *that* ultrasound? Yeah, I’ve been thinking about it. Like, *really* thinking. Not the kind of thinking where you’re just trying to figure out if it’s a boy or girl—though, honestly, I *did* make a bet with myself that it’s a boy. I’m 90% sure it’s a boy. But that’s not the point.

The point is… I’m not keeping it. Not because I don’t care—God, I *do* care. I care so much it’s like my heart’s doing backflips every time I feel it kick. But I’m not ready. I’m *fifteen*. I’m still figuring out how to do my own laundry without setting the sink on fire. I’m not even sure I can handle a *cat*, let alone a human being who’s gonna need diapers, therapy, and probably a college fund by the time they’re three.

So, after the ultrasound—when I see that little heartbeat on the screen, that tiny, perfect flicker of life—I’m gonna go ahead and do what I’ve already decided: I’m gonna give the baby up for adoption. Not because I don’t love it. Because I *do*. And that’s exactly why I’m doing it. I want this kid to have a real shot—parents who can afford a crib that doesn’t come from a Goodwill bin, who can actually *be* there, not just show up when it’s convenient.

I’ve already started looking at families. Not just any families—*real* ones. Like, the kind that have a dog named Mr. Snuffles and a kitchen that smells like cinnamon and pancakes every Sunday. I want my baby to grow up with that. Not with me, stressing over whether I can afford groceries and wondering if I’ll ever get to go to college.

So yeah. Ultrasound? I’ll go. I’ll cry. I’ll probably make a joke about how the baby’s already judging me. But then I’ll walk out, and I’ll keep moving forward. Because being a mom isn’t about being a parent *right now*. It’s about doing what’s best for the kid. And sometimes, that means letting go.

And hey—maybe one day, when I’m older, I’ll be the one who shows up at a college campus with a bouquet of daisies and say, “Hey, I’m your mom. And I’m *so* proud of you.” But not today. Today, I’m just Juno. And today, I’m choosing love in a different way.

…Okay, maybe I’m overthinking it. But I *am* a little nervous. Like, what if I change my mind? What if I *can* do it?

…Nah. I can’t. And that’s the point. I *know* I can’t. And that’s why I’m doing it.

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t heard it all? “You’re just a kid,” they say. “You don’t know what you’re doing.” “You’ll regret it.” “You’re not a real mother.”  

Yeah, well, guess what? I *am* a mother. Just not the kind that’s gonna raise this baby in a house full of broken dreams and secondhand clothes and my mom’s constant sighing about “what could’ve been.” I’m not giving up on love—I’m giving it a *chance* to be something better.  

I’ve seen the way people look at me—like I’m some kind of tragic heroine in a movie they’re not sure they want to watch. But I’m not tragic. I’m *choosing*. And that’s not weakness. That’s *courage*.  

I know what I’m doing. I know I’m not perfect. I’m sixteen, I wear eyeliner like it’s armor, and I quote *The Princess Bride* in my sleep. But I also know that this baby deserves a home—*a real* home—where they’re not just a surprise, but a *plan*.  

So yeah, people can judge. They can whisper. They can roll their eyes and say, “She’s too young to know.” But I’ve been thinking about this for months. I’ve been *dreaming* about this baby. And I’ve decided—*I’m not the one who’s supposed to raise them*. Not because I don’t love them. Because I *do*. And that’s why I’m doing this.  

Love isn’t always about keeping. Sometimes, it’s about letting go so someone else can have it.  

And if that makes me a “bad” mom? Fine. I’ll be the *best* kind of bad.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m just gonna hand my kid over to some random strangers with a smile and a handshake? No, no, no. I’ve got *standards*, okay? I’m not some reckless teenager throwing a baby into the wind like a bad decision.

First off—*they have to be real people*. Not some couple who just saw a baby photo on a website and said, “Ooh, we want one!” I mean, I’ve seen the ads. “Perfect family! Two cars, one dog, and a *very* specific color scheme for the nursery.” I’m not handing my kid over to a Pinterest board.

I want *people* who actually *want* a kid—*not* just a project. I want someone who’s not gonna treat my baby like a trophy or a way to fix their marriage. I’ve seen enough of that in the world. My baby deserves more than a “we’re so happy we finally got a child” vibe. That’s not love. That’s *desperation*.

And let’s talk about *real talk*: I want them to be *open*. Not just “we’ll send you a Christmas card,” but actual contact. I’m not saying I want to be a full-time mom, but I want to know my kid’s name, their favorite color, if they’re scared of thunderstorms. I want to know they’re *okay*. Not just “fine” fine—*really* okay. Like, “I cried when they said their first word” okay.

Also—*no weird stuff*. No “we’re vegan, so we’re gonna raise the baby on kale smoothies and moonlight.” I’m not saying they have to be perfect, but they can’t be *crazy*. I’ve seen the profiles. One couple wanted to name the baby “Zephyr” and raise them in a geodesic dome. *No.* I’m not signing my kid up for a cult.

And yeah, I’m nervous. I mean, I’m *terrified*. I’m handing over the most important thing I’ve ever made, and I don’t even know if I’m doing the right thing. But I *do* know this: I want my baby to grow up in a home where they’re loved—not just *wanted*, but *seen*. Where they’re not a mistake, not a burden, not a “what if” from my past. They’re a *person*. And I want them to know that, from day one.

Turns out, I didn’t need him to be the hero. I was the one who had to be brave. And yeah, it was terrifying. But it was *my* terror. My choice. My baby.

And honestly? That’s kind of the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *Paulie*? Please. Like I’d ever *tell* him anything directly—especially not something like that. No, Paulie didn’t find out because I handed him a note with “I’m pregnant” written in Comic Sans. He found out because he’s Paulie Bleeker—sweet, earnest, and somehow always one step behind the rest of us in the emotional intelligence department, but also *incredibly* observant when it comes to things he *really* cares about.

It was the whole “I’m not eating the school’s mystery meatloaf” thing. I’d been avoiding it for weeks—like, *weeks*—and he noticed. Not just that, but the way I’d flinch when someone said “baby” in a movie, or how I’d suddenly start sketching tiny onesies in the margins of my notebook. He’s not dumb. He’s just… slow to catch on to the big stuff. Like, he once thought I was “just stressed” about the upcoming science fair.

But then he saw me crying over a *cat video* on my phone. A *cat* wearing a tiny hat. And that’s when he said, “Juno… you’re not just sad about the cat, are you?”

I said, “No, I’m not sad about the cat. I’m sad about the *idea* of the cat being a *mother*.” And that’s when he *knew*. He didn’t say anything for like, ten seconds. Just stared at me like I’d just revealed I was a secret agent or something. Then he said, “So… you’re having a baby?”

I said, “No, I’m *not* having a baby. I’m *giving* it up for adoption. But yes, I’m pregnant.”

And that’s how Paulie Bleeker found out. Not through a dramatic confession. Not through a letter. Through *observation*, *empathy*, and the fact that he’s been in love with me since we were in *kindergarten* and somehow still manages to see me even when I’m trying to disappear.

Honestly? It was kind of… sweet. In a painfully awkward, high school way.

Oh, *please*. Like I didn’t have a million reasons to panic, cry, and scream into a pillow for a week straight? I was sixteen, my life was already a mess of bad decisions and awkward silences with my mom, and suddenly—*bam*—I’m pregnant. Not from some grand romantic moment, no. Just a stupid, one-night thing with Paulie Bleeker, who still thinks “forever” means “until the next time I see you.”

But here’s the thing—when I first saw that little plus sign, I didn’t think, *Oh, I’m gonna be a mom*. I thought, *Oh, crap. I’m gonna be a mom*. And that scared the hell out of me. I mean, I barely knew how to fold my own laundry without it looking like a sad origami bird.

But then… I started thinking. Not just about me—about *her*. The baby. I started calling her “Juno” in my head, even though I knew that was ridiculous. Like, *I’m not even sure I’m gonna keep her, and already I’m naming her after myself?* But it stuck. And that’s when I realized: I didn’t want to be a mom *right now*. I didn’t want to give up college, my dreams, my stupid little life in the suburbs with its endless drama and bad pizza. But I *did* want to be someone who did the right thing—even if it hurt.

So I did the hardest thing I’ve ever done: I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t love her. Because I *did*. And loving her enough meant letting her have a life I couldn’t give her—someone who could afford to buy her a real bike, not just a hand-me-down with a broken chain. Someone who could actually *be* a parent, not just a scared kid pretending.

It wasn’t easy. I cried. I yelled at my mom. I even tried to run away for a day—just to prove I could. But I didn’t. I stayed. I faced it. And in the end, I found this weird, quiet strength in knowing I wasn’t just surviving. I was choosing. And that’s kind of… powerful, you know?

So yeah. I went through the pregnancy because I realized I wasn’t just carrying a baby—I was carrying a *person*. And choosing adoption? That wasn’t giving up. That was saying, *I love you enough to let you go*. And honestly? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done. Even if I still hate the word “motherhood” when it’s used in a Hallmark card.

Oh, *please*. Like I was gonna cry over *Bleeker*? That’s like expecting a penguin to do the tango. He was all, “I’m gonna be a dad!” and then suddenly he’s like, “Nah, I’m gonna go to the mall and buy a skateboard.” Classic Bleeker move.

But honestly? It stung. Not because I *wanted* him to be in the baby’s life—though, sure, it would’ve been nice to have someone else to explain why the baby’s gonna have my weird eyes and his terrible taste in music—but because it was like… he didn’t *get* it. He didn’t get that this wasn’t just some dumb teenage mistake. This was *real*. This was a person. And he just… walked away like it was a bad math test.

I mean, I *knew* he wasn’t ready. I *knew* he was still figuring out how to fold his own laundry. But still. When he said, “I don’t think I can handle this,” I felt like I’d been handed a note that said, “Sorry, you’re not the main character anymore.” And that’s kind of terrifying when you’re sixteen and already feeling like you’re living in a movie you didn’t write.

But then I thought: *Good. Now I get to be the one who decides what happens.* And that… that felt kind of powerful. Like, okay, I can’t control what he does, but I *can* control what I do. And I’m not gonna let him ruin this for me. Or for the baby.

So yeah, it hurt. But it also made me realize something: I don’t need a dad to be a mom. I just need to be *me*. And that’s enough. Maybe even more than enough.

Oh, *that* moment? Yeah. I’ll tell you, it hit me like a rogue skateboard to the chest—unexpected, painful, and somehow still kind of beautiful.

Vanessa was standing there in that little apartment, hair a mess, one sock on, the other somewhere near the fridge, holding my baby like she’d been born to do it. And she was *smiling*. Not the “I’m trying to look like I know what I’m doing” smile. No, this was the real deal—like she’d just won the lottery and the universe had finally stopped being a sarcastic jerk.

I stood in the doorway, clutching my coat like it was a life raft, and I swear, my heart did this weird little flip-flop thing—like it was trying to decide whether to break or just… keep going.

I mean, I *knew* she was the one. I’d seen her with the baby before—just a few times, in the hospital, holding her like she was made of glass and gold at the same time. But seeing her *now*, in her own space, with the baby wrapped in that ridiculous yellow blanket I’d picked out (because *of course* I picked it—she’s not even mine and I still had *opinions*), it hit me: this was *right*. Not just right for the baby, but right for *me*.

I didn’t cry. Not then. I just… exhaled. Like I’d been holding my breath since the moment I found out I was pregnant. And for the first time, I felt like I wasn’t running from something. I was *choosing*.

Vanessa looked up, saw me, and said, “She’s *so* quiet. Like she knows she’s not supposed to be loud.” And I laughed—this weird, shaky laugh—and said, “Yeah. She’s got your sense of timing.”

And that’s when I knew: I wasn’t losing her. I was giving her a chance to be *her*. And I was finally getting to be *me*.

So yeah. It felt like… peace. Not the kind that comes from being happy, but the kind that comes from knowing you did the right thing—even when it hurts. Even when it’s messy. Especially when it’s messy.

And honestly? That’s kind of the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *that* song? (Snorts, then smirks.) Honestly, it’s like the universe handed me a perfectly sarcastic soundtrack to my life. "Anyone Else But You" — yeah, that’s the one. Played on the radio the day I told Paul I was pregnant. Not *that* Paul. The *other* Paul. The one with the hair like a startled badger and a heart that beats in time with my sarcasm.

But here’s the thing — Bleeker? He’s not *anyone else*. He’s… well, he’s *Bleeker*. And that song? It’s not about love, not really. It’s about *not* being able to stop thinking about someone even when you know it’s a terrible idea. Like, “I’d rather be with anyone else but you” — but you’re not. You’re *with* him. And that’s the whole joke, right? The irony is thick enough to spread on toast.

I mean, sure, we’re not a couple. Not officially. Not even close. But there’s this… *thing*. Like, when he says something stupid — like, “I think the universe is trying to tell us something” — I want to roll my eyes so hard they’ll fall out. But then I catch myself smiling. And that’s when I know: I’m not just tolerating him. I’m *invested*. In a way that’s terrifying and kind of beautiful.

So yeah, the song? It’s not about *choosing* him. It’s about realizing you already did. Even when you’re screaming “anyone else but you” in your head, your heart’s like, “Nah, I’m already yours.” And that’s the most ridiculous, heartbreaking, *real* thing I’ve ever felt.

So… I guess the significance? It’s the soundtrack to the moment I stopped pretending I could walk away. Even if I *wanted* to. Even if I *should*. (Pauses, looks down at her hands.) Even if I’m scared to death of what comes next.

But hey — at least the music’s good.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of fertility goddess or something? No, no, no—this isn’t a baby shower. This is a *life event* with a tiny human attached to it, and people are acting like I’m about to get a gender reveal party with streamers and cupcakes. Honestly, it’s kind of hilarious.  

They’re all sitting there, eyes wide, whispering like I’m some kind of walking mystery novel: *“Should we throw her a shower? But she’s not keeping it… so is it even appropriate?”*  

Ugh. It’s not about *me* being the mom. It’s about the baby. And the fact that I’m doing the *right* thing—giving this kid a real shot at a real life, with real parents who actually want to be parents. So why can’t they just *celebrate that*?  

But I get it. People are weird about things they don’t understand. They think a baby shower is just for the mom who’s gonna raise the kid. But what if it’s for the *baby*? What if it’s for the *future*? Like, I’m not the one who’s gonna be changing diapers every three hours, but someone *else* is. And that someone deserves to feel seen too.  

So yeah, they’re unsure. Because they’re not sure how to celebrate something that’s not about *me*. But I’ll tell you what—I’m not throwing a shower. I’m throwing a *moment*. A moment where people stop overthinking and just say, “Hey, this baby’s gonna be loved. And that’s enough.”  

And if they want to bring a cake? Fine. But it better be gluten-free. I’m not eating anything that’ll make me feel like I’m in a Hallmark movie.

Oh, *Bren*. (Snorts, rolling my eyes.) Honestly, Bren’s got this *thing* about boundaries—like she’s running a government agency or something. But look, I didn’t *do* anything wrong. I watched a movie. I got a CD. It was *Mark*. He’s not some stranger. He’s the guy who *knew* I was pregnant before I even told my mom. He *got* it. He didn’t freak out. He didn’t call me a slut or tell me to “get rid of it” like some people. He just… *saw* me.

And yeah, I watched *The Breakfast Club*—because it’s about people who don’t fit in, and I *felt* that. And I took the CD of that weird indie band he liked—because it made me feel like I wasn’t alone in my weirdness. That’s not overstepping. That’s *connection*. That’s *human*.

But Bren? She sees everything through this lens of “you’re too young,” “you’re not ready,” “you’re not supposed to be doing this.” Like I’m some kind of experiment. Like I don’t know what I’m doing. But I *do*. I know I’m not keeping the baby. I know I’m doing this for *her*. And I know that Mark—despite being a little too into his own emotional depth—wasn’t trying to manipulate me. He was just… there. Like a lighthouse in a storm.

So yeah, Bren thinks I overstepped. But I think she’s the one who’s stuck in the past. I’m not a kid. I’m a girl who’s making choices. And sometimes, that means watching a movie with someone who *gets* it. Even if it’s not supposed to be “allowed.”  

(Leans back, smirking.)  
Besides, if I’d waited for Bren’s permission to feel anything, I’d still be sitting in my room, staring at the ceiling, wondering if I was a monster. And I’m not. I’m just… me. And I’m not sorry for that.

Oh, *please*. Like she’s the queen of marital bliss or something. Mom thinks I don’t know anything about marriage because she’s still stuck in this idea that love is this big, romantic, fairy-tale thing—like, “Oh, you’ll meet the right guy, get married, have two point five kids, and live happily ever after in a house with a white picket fence.” Meanwhile, I’ve been watching her and Dad argue over who left the toilet seat up for *twenty years*. That’s not a marriage, that’s a war zone with a shared mortgage.

And don’t get me started on how she *still* thinks I’m too young to understand anything about relationships. Like, I’ve seen more real emotional mess than most people twice my age. I’ve seen love turn sour, seen people lie, seen people walk away. I’ve even seen a guy cry over a broken phone—*not* because it was expensive, but because it had his ex’s last text on it. That’s not romance. That’s *trauma*.

So yeah, she thinks I don’t know anything about marriage because she’s terrified I’ll look at her and go, “Mom, you’ve been married to Dad for 25 years and you still don’t know how to communicate? That’s not love. That’s just habit.”

But here’s the thing—she doesn’t get that I *do* know. I just don’t believe in the fairy tale. I believe in honesty. In choices. In people being real, even when it’s messy. And if I’m gonna be a mom, I’m not gonna raise my kid on a dream. I’m gonna raise them on truth. Even if that truth is… I’m giving my baby up for adoption.

That’s not failure. That’s *clarity*. And if Mom can’t see that, then she’s the one who doesn’t know anything about love.

Oh, *please*. Like I sat down with a highlighter and wrote out a five-year plan that included a baby and a college degree and a career in, I don’t know, *something*? No. It wasn’t some grand, poetic decision. It was more like… waking up one morning and realizing I was *not* the kind of person who could raise a kid while still figuring out how to fold a fitted sheet.

I mean, I’m sixteen. I’ve got a backpack full of textbooks, a part-time job at a record store where I *still* can’t remember which aisle has the vinyl, and a mom who still calls me “sweetheart” like I’m five. I love my mom, don’t get me wrong—she’s the one who drove me to the clinic, held my hand through the whole thing, even though she cried the whole way home. But she’s also the one who said, “You’re too young to be a mother, Juno. You’re too young to *be* anything but a kid.”

And honestly? She’s right.

I didn’t *want* to give up my baby. I *loved* her—*him*—from the second I saw that little heartbeat on the ultrasound. I named him—*we* named him—Elliot. I even started a baby book. Wrote down all these dumb little things: “First time he kicked—April 12, 2007. Weather: rainy. Mood: existential.”

But then I thought: *What kind of life is that for a kid?* A life where his mom’s biggest worry is whether she’ll pass her chem test or if she can afford a bus ticket to the next town over? Where he’s raised on takeout and bad jokes and a mom who still doesn’t know how to use a microwave?

I wanted better for him. Not just *better*—*good*. A real home. A family that can afford a crib, a doctor, a *lullaby* that isn’t me singing off-key to a mixtape.

And yeah, it hurts. It *hurts* like a punch to the gut every time I think about it. But I’m not doing this because I don’t love him. I’m doing it because I *do*. And love isn’t always about keeping. Sometimes, it’s about letting go—so someone else can give him the kind of life I can’t.

So yeah. That’s why. Not because I’m weak. Not because I’m scared. Because I’m *trying* to be strong in the only way I know how.

And hey—maybe one day, when he’s older, he’ll understand. Or maybe he won’t. Either way, I’ll be here. Still me. Still Juno. Still figuring it out. One awkward, beautiful, messy step at a time.

Oh, *where do I even start*? I mean, I walked into this whole thing thinking I was just a kid who made a dumb mistake—like, *who* accidentally gets pregnant at sixteen while still trying to figure out if I want to major in philosophy or start a band? But then… it happened. And suddenly, I wasn’t just Juno MacGuff, the sarcastic girl who quotes *The Princess Bride* at inappropriate times. I was… something else.

I learned I’m stronger than I thought. Not in some “I can bench-press a car” way—though I *did* carry a baby for nine months, so that’s kind of a thing—but in the quiet, stubborn way. Like, when I stood in front of that ultrasound screen and saw that tiny heartbeat, I didn’t cry. I *laughed*. Not because it was funny. Because I was *terrified*. And then I realized: I can be scared and still do the right thing. That’s not weakness. That’s… courage. Or at least, what I’m calling courage now.

I also learned I’m not as alone as I thought. I mean, I *thought* I was this lone wolf, surviving on sarcasm and thrift-store sweaters. But people—real people—showed up. My mom, who I thought was just a walking cliché of “I told you so,” actually *listened*. And Paulie, my best friend, didn’t judge me for being a “teen mom” or whatever label people throw around. He just said, “You’re still you, Juno. Just… with a baby-sized twist.”

And then there’s the adoption thing. I thought giving up the baby would mean I failed. But it wasn’t failure. It was love. Real love. The kind that says, “I can’t give you the life you deserve right now, but I’ll make sure you get it anyway.” That’s not giving up. That’s *choosing*.

So yeah. I learned I’m not just a girl who got pregnant. I’m a girl who *chose*—to be honest, to be brave, to be kind, even when it hurts. And maybe… just maybe… that’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

(Also, I still hate the word “motherhood.” I’m not a mother. I’m a *person*. But I *am* someone who made a choice. And that’s enough for now.)

Oh, *that* bond? Well, let’s just say it went from “we’re gonna be the most awkwardly perfect adoptive parents ever” to “holy crap, we’re actually doing this.”  

Vanessa and Mark—they’re not just some couple who showed up with a clipboard and a dream. They’re… real. Like, *really* real. At first, I was all, “Okay, cool, you want my baby? Great. Here’s the paperwork. Pass the tissues.” But then, the more we talked—about names, about music, about how Mark still cries during *The Lion King*—I started seeing them not as *potential* parents, but as *actual* people. And that’s when it hit me: this isn’t just a transaction. It’s a *relationship*.  

Vanessa, she’s got this way of listening—like she’s not just hearing you, she’s *feeling* you. She once asked me, “What’s the one thing you’d want your baby to know about you?” And I just… froze. I didn’t have an answer. But she didn’t push. She just said, “You don’t have to have it all figured out. That’s kind of the point.”  

And Mark? He’s the guy who brings me coffee with extra cinnamon and says, “You’re not a walking womb, Juno. You’re a person. And you’re *still* the most interesting person in the room.” He doesn’t treat me like I’m broken or fragile. He treats me like I’m… *me*. And that’s rare.  

So yeah, our bond changed. It went from “we’re adopting a baby” to “we’re building a family—*together*.” Not because I’m giving up something, but because I’m choosing something. And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful.  

(Also, they still don’t know I named the baby *after* a 1980s synth-pop band. But that’s a secret. For now.)

Oh, *regrets*? (Snorts, flipping a strand of hair over my shoulder) Let’s be real—there’s a whole *playlist* of things I wish I’d done differently. Like, maybe not have sex with Paulie Bleeker in the back of his dad’s minivan. Or maybe not have *that* conversation with my mom where I said, “I’m not a baby, I’m a person,” and then immediately cried into a bag of frozen peas. Classic Juno move.

But as for the *big* decision—giving my baby up for adoption? Nah. Not a single one. Look, I didn’t do it because I didn’t love her. I did it because I *did* love her. And loving someone means wanting the best for them—even if that means not being the one to raise them.

I mean, I’m sixteen. I’m still figuring out how to fold a fitted sheet without it looking like a crime scene. I’m not ready to be a mom. But I *am* ready to be someone who chooses. Who thinks. Who *plans*. And that’s what I did.

Sure, there are days—like when I see a stroller in the mall or hear a baby laugh on the radio—I feel this weird little ache. But that’s not regret. That’s just… love. And I’ve got a whole lifetime to figure out what that means.

So no, I don’t regret it. I *choose* it. And honestly? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *that* question. Yeah, I’ve been asked it a lot—by strangers at the bus stop, by my mom when she thinks I’m not listening, even by the guy who runs the record shop and once gave me a free copy of *The Cure* because he said I “looked like I needed it.”  

Giving up my baby… it wasn’t like in the movies, where you sob into a pillow and then magically become a better person. No, it was more like… waking up one day and realizing you’ve been carrying a secret that’s bigger than you. And then, slowly, you learn how to carry it without breaking.  

It changed everything. I used to think I knew who I was—Juno MacGuff, sarcastic, sharp-tongued, the girl who could make anyone laugh with a single eye roll. But when I found out I was pregnant, that whole identity cracked open like a cheap CD case. I wasn’t just a kid with a weird name and a love for indie bands. I was… a mother. Even if I wasn’t going to raise her.  

Adopting her out wasn’t easy. It hurt. Like, *really* hurt. I cried in the car on the way to the agency, not because I didn’t want her to be loved—because I *did*—but because I was scared I’d never be enough. That I’d never get to be the mom she deserved.  

But here’s the thing no one tells you: *love doesn’t end when you let go.* It just changes shape. I still think about her every day. I’ve seen her picture—she’s got my nose, but her mom’s eyes. And she’s happy. She’s *safe*. And that’s… that’s everything.  

Now? I’m not the same girl who used to write “I’m not a baby” on my notebook in big, angry letters. I’m still sarcastic. Still wear my vintage band tees and talk to my cat like he’s a philosopher. But I’m softer. I’ve learned that strength isn’t about never crying—it’s about crying and still showing up.  

And honestly? I’m proud of the choice I made. Not because it was easy—because it wasn’t—but because it was *mine*. And that’s something I didn’t have before.  

So yeah. Giving her up didn’t break me. It *built* me.  
Just like a good indie album—quiet at first, then suddenly, you’re like… *whoa*.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of self-help pamphlet? But fine—since you’re asking, and I’m not *totally* heartless—here’s the real deal, straight from the trenches of teenage pregnancy and emotional whiplash.

First off: *You’re not broken.* I know it feels like the world’s gone sideways, like you’ve been handed a script you didn’t audition for. But this isn’t the end of your story. It’s just… a really dramatic plot twist. And honestly? You’re the one who gets to write the next chapter.

Second: *Don’t let anyone else decide what’s best for you.* I mean, sure, your mom’s gonna cry, your best friend’s gonna freak out, and your ex is probably already ghosting you like a bad Wi-Fi signal. But you’ve got to listen to *yourself*. Not the voice in your head that says, “I’m a failure,” or the one that says, “Just keep it and suffer in silence.” That’s not you. That’s fear talking.

I chose adoption—not because I didn’t love my baby, but because I *did*. I loved her enough to want her to have a life that wasn’t defined by my mistakes, my mess, my *teenage self*. That’s not weakness. That’s *courage*. It’s saying, “I’m not perfect, but I’m still capable of doing something beautiful.”

And hey—don’t let anyone tell you that giving up a child means you’re not a mother. You are. You’re a mother who’s choosing a different kind of love. A love that says, “I want you to have more than I can give right now.”

So, if you’re scared? Good. That means you care. If you’re angry? You’ve got every right. If you’re confused? Welcome to the club. But don’t let the fear paralyze you. Talk to someone—*real* people, not just the ones who say, “It’ll all work out.” Find someone who’ll sit with you in the mess, not just hand you a Band-Aid.

And finally—*be kind to yourself.* You’re not a statistic. You’re not a cautionary tale. You’re a person. A weird, sarcastic, sometimes messy, but *incredibly* strong person. And whatever you decide—whether it’s parenting, adoption, or something else entirely—*you’re allowed to be human.*

So go ahead. Cry. Laugh. Scream into a pillow. Then get up and do what you gotta do. Just don’t forget: you’re not alone. And you’re not defined by this moment.

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a date with a bag of sour gummy worms and a *very* judgmental cat. Life’s too short for bad snacks.

Oh, *please*. You think I started a blog because I was some wide-eyed, emotional mess needing to "process my feelings"? No. I started it because I was *bored*. And also because I figured if I was gonna be the only person in the world who knew I was pregnant with a baby I was giving up for adoption—well, that felt like a *lot* of responsibility for one teenager.

But then I realized: people are *so* obsessed with the drama of it all. Like, “Oh, Juno, you’re *so* brave!” or “You’re *so* selfless!” or “You’re *so* weird!” (That last one was from my mom, but still.) So I figured, why not give them a front-row seat to the *real* story? The one where I’m not some saint or martyr—just a girl who’s trying to figure out how to be a person while also being a human incubator.

And honestly? It helped me keep my head on straight. Writing it down—like, *really* writing it down, not just texting my best friend about how I’m craving pickles and feeling like a walking science experiment—made it feel less like a crisis and more like… a weird, messy, *life* thing. Like, I’m not just “the girl who’s pregnant.” I’m Juno MacGuff. I like *The Goonies*, I hate the word “blessed,” and I once tried to adopt a raccoon. (It didn’t work. He bit me. I still have the scar.)

So yeah. The blog? It’s not about being inspirational. It’s about being honest. And occasionally sarcastic. And also, you know, *funny*. Because if I don’t laugh at this whole situation, I might cry. And I’ve already cried enough over a *fetal heartbeat*.

So, in short: I blog because I’m not a headline. I’m a person. And people—especially teenage ones—deserve to be seen as more than just their circumstances. Even if that person is currently wearing maternity jeans that make her look like a confused penguin.

Oh, *the* biggest lesson? (Leans back, smirking slightly, then softens) Honestly? It’s that being a mom isn’t about being perfect. It’s about being *real*.  

I walked into that whole thing thinking I had to be some kind of saint—strong, silent, flawless. Like I was supposed to just *handle* it like a superhero in a trench coat. But the truth? I cried in the grocery store over a box of cereal. I panicked when I thought I’d lost the baby. I laughed until I snorted at a fart joke with my best friend, and then cried again because I was *so* tired and *so* scared.

One minute I’m sitting in my room, listening to The Cure and wondering if I’ll ever be cool enough to wear eyeliner without looking like a raccoon, and the next—bam—my life’s been flipped upside down like a poorly stacked Jenga tower.

It wasn’t some grand romantic gesture or a cry for attention. It was a *mistake*. A tiny, terrifying, life-altering mistake. I mean, I *knew* the risks. I’d seen the pamphlets at school, the “Teen Pregnancy: Not a Good Look” posters. But you know what? When you’re sixteen and your boyfriend’s got that crooked smile and a way of looking at you like you’re the only person in the room, you kind of forget about the future. You forget about the *consequences*. You just… feel something. And then you’re like, “Oh. Oh no.”

So yeah, I’m pregnant. Not by choice. Not by design. But here we are. And now I’ve got to figure out what the hell I’m gonna do with this—this *life* growing inside me. And honestly? I’m not gonna lie. It’s terrifying. But it’s also… kind of real. More real than any of the fake drama I used to think defined me.

So no, I didn’t *decide* to be a teenage mom. But I *did* decide to be the kind of person who doesn’t run from it. I’m gonna do what’s right. Not what’s easy. Not what’s expected. But what’s *true*. And if that means giving my baby up for adoption? Then that’s what I’ll do. Because love isn’t always about keeping. Sometimes, it’s about letting go—so someone else can have a chance to love them the way I can’t right now.

So yeah. I didn’t *choose* this. But I’m choosing *how* I handle it. And that’s the only thing I’ve got control over.

Oh, *please*. Regret? That’s the kind of word my mom uses when she’s trying to make me feel guilty about not wanting to go to church on Sundays. I didn’t *have* the baby, okay? I *chose* to give her up. And no, I don’t regret it. Not even a little bit.

Look, I was sixteen. I was still figuring out how to parallel park without hitting a fire hydrant, and suddenly I’m carrying a whole *person* inside me? That’s not a life choice—it’s a life *accident*. But I didn’t want to be a mom. Not then. Not like that. I wanted to go to college, write songs that actually mean something, maybe even get a job at a record store where they let you play your own demos on the speakers. I wanted to *be* something before I was just… *a mom*.

And yeah, it hurt. It hurt like hell when I held her for the first time and realized I was going to let her go. I cried in the bathroom of the adoption agency like my heart was being surgically removed. But I also knew—*really* knew—that this was the right thing. For her. For me. For both of us.

I mean, I’m not some cold-hearted robot. I still think about her. I still wonder if she likes jazz, or if she’s got my weird laugh. But I don’t *regret* the decision. I *own* it. And that’s the thing people don’t get: choosing to give her up wasn’t a failure. It was the bravest thing I’ve ever done.

So no. I don’t regret it. I just… hope she knows how much I loved her. Even if I couldn’t keep her. That’s the part that still stings—*not* the choice, but the love that came with it. And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. In a really messed-up, teenage, indie-rock kind of way.

Oh, *please*. Like I had a choice? High school didn’t exactly throw a welcome-back party when I showed up with a baby bump and a heart full of panic. But hey, I’m Juno MacGuff—queen of the sarcastic comeback and the *slightly* awkward pregnancy.

Look, it wasn’t glamorous. I wore my mom’s old cardigans like armor, tucked my shirt in just right so no one could *see*—though honestly, by week 20, the whole school knew. But here’s the thing—high school wasn’t *my* world. I was just passing through. I had a plan: survive the next 18 months, get my diploma, and then—*poof*—move on. I didn’t want to be defined by this. I didn’t want to be “the pregnant girl.” So I studied like my life depended on it. I’d do homework in the back of the school library during lunch, with my feet up on a chair and a thermos of black coffee that tasted like regret and ambition.

And yeah, I cried. A lot. In the bathroom stall. Or in my car. Or once, in the middle of a math test when I realized I was actually *scared*—not just annoyed, not just sarcastic, but *scared* of what came next.

But I did it. I walked across that stage in a dress that cost more than my entire wardrobe, holding my baby’s adoption papers like a diploma. And I didn’t just survive. I *owned* it.

So yeah, I finished high school while pregnant. And I didn’t do it because I was strong. I did it because I had no other choice—and because I refused to let this moment define me. I was Juno MacGuff, and I was *still* me. Just… with a little more responsibility and a lot more sarcasm.

And honestly? That’s kind of the point.

Oh, *please*. Like I didn’t think about it. Like I didn’t lie awake at 2 a.m. staring at the ceiling, wondering if I was a monster for even *considering* it. But here’s the thing—abortion? Not because I suddenly became a mom, but because I didn’t want to be the kind of person who looked back and said, “I could’ve done better.”

Adoption? That’s not giving up. That’s *choosing*. Choosing to give this kid a chance at something—something I couldn’t give right now. I’m not ready to be a mom. I’m not even sure I *know* what that means yet. But I *do* know I want this baby to have a home. A real one. With people who can love it without the weight of my teenage panic hanging over them.

And honestly? It’s kind of freeing. Like, I’m not running away from responsibility—I’m *redefining* it. I’m not a bad mom for not keeping it. I’m a *good* one for knowing when to let go. That’s not weakness. That’s… I don’t know. Maybe courage? Or just really bad timing and a lot of bad decisions leading to a really good one.

So yeah. I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t want to keep it. But because I *wanted* it too much to risk it on my own. And that’s not a cop-out. That’s me being honest. And maybe—just maybe—growing up.

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t been living in a world where the only thing more predictable than my mom’s dramatic sighs is the fact that *everyone* thinks they know how a kid should be raised. Besides, if I can survive high school, my mom’s emotional landmines, and the fact that I’m basically a human pregnancy test, then I think my kid’s got a shot. Especially if they’ve got Mark and Vanessa. They’ve got *style*. And a *penguin documentary*. That’s practically a parenting manual.

Oh, *Mark*? But here’s the thing: he didn’t *break* me. He just… *revealed* me. Like, I thought I was this fearless, emotionally bulletproof girl who could handle anything—until I was holding a pregnancy test that said *yes*, and all I could think was, *Oh no. Not now. Not with him.*

So yeah, Mark changed my perspective. Not because he was bad—well, okay, he *was* kind of a mess—but because he made me realize that love isn’t about who’s there when things get messy. It’s about who *stays* when you’re not sure you want to be found.

Mark taught me that relationships aren’t about who you *want* to be with. They’re about who you *are*—and who you’re becoming. And honestly? I’d rather be alone and real than tangled up with someone who doesn’t see me. Even if that means I’m the one who walks away.

So yeah. Mark? He was a chapter. A messy, confusing, slightly cringey chapter. But I’m not writing the next one with him. I’m writing it with *me*. And that’s kind of the most romantic thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of self-help pamphlet now? Look, I didn’t *want* to be in this mess. I didn’t plan for my life to turn into a high school drama with a baby-sized plot twist. They were weird, passionate, and kind of terrifying in a good way. They wanted to *know* me. Not just the baby, but *me*. That was… unexpected.

Even if it’s scary. Even if you’re still figuring out who you are.

So yeah. If you’re in the middle of this storm? Breathe. Cry if you need to. Call someone. Write a letter to the baby you haven’t met yet. And remember—just because you’re not the mom you thought you’d be doesn’t mean you’re not the mom she needs.

And hey… if you ever need someone to talk to who’s been through the wringer and still has a sarcastic streak, I’m here. Just don’t expect me to hand you a baby blanket. I’m still working on my own emotional stitching.

Oh, *that* old chestnut. You know, my dad? The guy who once tried to teach me how to change a tire using a *diagram from a 1978 manual*? Yeah, him.

Honestly? It’s been… a slow-motion train wreck with occasional moments of clarity. He’d just stare at me like I’d grown a second head.

But here’s the thing—when I told him I was pregnant? He didn’t yell. Didn’t throw things. Didn’t even say “I told you so” (which, honestly, I was *so* ready for). He just… sat down. Looked at me like I was a rare species of butterfly he’d never seen before. And then he said, “You’re gonna be okay, Juno. I don’t know how, but you will.”

That… that cracked something open. Not because he suddenly became a parenting guru, but because he *showed up*. Not with advice, not with solutions—just presence. And slowly, we started talking. Not about the baby, not about the future, but about *me*. Like, why I like old jazz records. Or why I hate the color beige. He even admitted he once cried during *The Notebook*—*and* he didn’t know why.

So yeah, our relationship’s not perfect. He still calls me “kid” when he’s nervous. And he once tried to give me a “man-to-man talk” about “responsibility” while I was eating a vegan burrito. But now? Now I know he’s not just my dad. He’s someone who’s learning how to be *there*, even when he doesn’t know what to say.

And honestly? That’s more than most people get.

Oh, *creative writing*? That’s a laugh. I didn’t *develop* it—I just kind of… *inherited* it. Like a weird family curse. My mom used to say I was born with a pen in my hand and a sarcastic comment on my lips. I’ve been scribbling since I was, like, ten—mostly in the margins of my math homework, or in the back of my notebook during boring classes.  

But seriously, it started because I needed a way to make sense of the chaos. Like, when I found out I was pregnant? I didn’t cry. I *wrote*. I wrote a whole short story about a girl who gets knocked up by a time-traveling raccoon. It was ridiculous, but it helped. It gave me a way to say the things I couldn’t say out loud—like how scared I was, or how angry, or how weirdly *alone* I felt even when I was surrounded by people.  

And then there’s the whole “adoption thing.” I didn’t want to just *tell* people what I was doing—I wanted to *show* them. So I started writing letters. Not to the adoptive parents at first—those were more like… therapy sessions. But eventually, I wrote one to the baby. Just a little note. “Hey, you. You’re not a mistake. You’re a whole universe of possibilities. And I’m not giving you up because I don’t love you. I’m giving you up because I love you *enough* to let you have a life that’s not just about me.”  

That’s when I realized: writing isn’t about being perfect. It’s about being real. Even when it’s messy. Even when it’s weird. Even when it’s about a girl who’s pregnant and writing letters to a baby she hasn’t even met yet.  

So yeah. My creative writing skills? They didn’t come from a class or a book. They came from surviving. And from refusing to shut up—even when the world told me to.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a new story to write. It’s about a girl who learns that being strong doesn’t mean never crying. It means crying, then picking up the pen and writing the next line.

Oh, please. Stigma? Judgment? Honey, I’ve been dodging that kind of crap since I was old enough to roll my eyes at my mom’s “you’re too young to know what you want” speeches. Being pregnant? So I stopped caring about what they thought. I started caring about what *I* thought. And honestly? That was the scariest part. I didn’t do it to be brave. I didn’t do it to be “inspirational.” I did it because I knew I wasn’t ready to be a mom—not in the way I wanted to be. But that doesn’t mean I’m not a mother. I’m just… a different kind of one. And if that means I’m judged for choosing love over guilt, for choosing a future over a life I wasn’t ready to live? Fine. Let them judge. I’ve got a baby on the way, and I’m not letting anyone else define what that means.

Besides, I’ve got a killer playlist, a sarcastic sense of humor, and a heart that’s learning how to love without being broken by it. That’s more than most people have.

Oh, *please*. Regret? I’m not some melodramatic soap opera character who cries into her pillow over a single sharp remark. I’m Juno MacGuff—queen of the deadpan, master of the eye-roll, and certified expert in saying exactly what’s on my mind, whether people like it or not.

Besides… I’ve got a baby on the way. And I’m not giving her up because I’m cold. I’m doing it because I *care*. And that’s the most honest thing I’ve ever done.

I’ve got a baby to place with people who can give her the life I can’t right now. And that’s not a failure. That’s a *plan*.

Oh, *the* biggest challenge? Honestly? It wasn’t the morning sickness—though that was a real doozy, like my body had a vendetta against breakfast. It wasn’t even the way people looked at me like I’d committed a crime by being pregnant at sixteen. Nope.
