I didn’t even know I could feel something so fierce for someone I hadn’t even met.

It’s not about being a mother. It’s about realizing how much love can exist without ownership. I’ve spent my whole life thinking I had to *have* things to be happy—my independence, my sharp tongue, my weird little world. But this… this is different. I’m learning that love isn’t about keeping. It’s about *choosing*—choosing to do what’s best, even when it hurts. Even when it means walking away.

So yeah, it’s changed me. I’m not as cynical. I’m not as afraid to cry. I’ve learned that strength isn’t about being tough all the time—it’s about being honest. About saying, “I’m scared,” and still doing the right thing.

And honestly? I think the baby’s gonna be lucky. Not because I’m some saint, but because I’m choosing to give them a life that’s full of love, stability, and *real* parents. And that… that’s not weakness. That’s the bravest thing I’ve ever done.

So no, I’m not a mother. But I’m becoming someone who understands what it means to love someone so much, you let them go. And that? That’s a whole new kind of power.

Oh, *moments of self-doubt*? Please. I’ve got a whole *arsenal* of them—like the one where I’m standing in front of the mirror at 2 a.m., staring at my reflection like, “Who the hell *are* you, Juno MacGuff? You’re not a mom. You’re not even *close* to being a mom.” And then I remember: I *chose* this. I didn’t *fall* into it. I *decided* to give my baby a better shot than I could give them right now.

But yeah, it hits. Like, *really* hits. Especially when I’m at the adoption agency, filling out forms that ask, “What kind of life do you envision for your child?” And I’m like… *I don’t know*. I’m 16. I’ve got a backpack full of comic books and a dream of moving to Portland to be a freelance illustrator. I don’t even know how to change a tire, let alone raise a human.

So how do I deal with it? I don’t *deal* with it. I *talk* to it. I sit on my bedroom floor, eat a bag of sour gummy worms (because *obviously*), and say out loud: “Yeah, you’re scared. You’re not sure. You’re not perfect. But you’re *trying*. And that counts.”

And then I call my mom—yes, *the* Mom, the one who said, “You’re not a bad person for not wanting to be a mom right now,” and that’s the *real* magic. She doesn’t fix it. She just *listens*. And sometimes, that’s enough.

Also, I’ve started writing letters to the baby. Not the kind you send. Just… thoughts. Like, “Hey, I’m sorry I’m not ready to be your mom. But I’m so proud of you for being here. And I’m so sorry I can’t be the one to hold you every night. But I *will* be the one who made sure you had a chance.”

So yeah. Self-doubt? It’s not gone. It’s just… part of the package. Like a bad haircut or a broken shoelace. You learn to walk with it. Or, in my case, *laugh at it* while you’re doing it.

Because at the end of the day? I’m not just surviving. I’m *choosing*. And that’s kind of the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *community*? That’s a loaded word, isn’t it? Like, “community” sounds all warm and fuzzy—people sharing casseroles and singing in harmony while I’m over here trying to figure out if I can afford a crib *and* a therapist. But honestly? It’s everything.  

I mean, I didn’t *ask* for this. I didn’t even *want* to be the girl who’s pregnant at sixteen with a baby on the way and a future that’s suddenly… not mine to plan. But the thing is, I *can’t* do it alone. Not really.  

There’s my mom—yeah, the one who said, “You’re *not* keeping it,” and then spent the next three weeks trying to find me a “good” adoption agency while also crying into her coffee. She’s not perfect. She’s loud, she’s dramatic, she’s *terrified*. But she’s *there*. And that matters.  

And then there’s Paulie—my best friend since we were eight and shared a single bag of sour gummy worms. He’s the guy who showed up at my door with a box of *Sonic* fries and said, “You’re not a monster, Juno. You’re just… a human with a weird life plot twist.” He didn’t try to fix me. He just *saw* me.  

And the adoption counselor—Ms. Lillian—she’s like a human version of a calm, well-organized storm. She doesn’t judge. She listens. She even let me pick the name of the baby *before* I even knew the baby’s gender. That felt… important. Like I wasn’t just handing over a thing. I was choosing a future.  

So yeah, community? It’s not about being surrounded by people who agree with you. It’s about being surrounded by people who *stay*. Who don’t look away when you’re messy, scared, or trying to figure out how to fold a onesie without crying.  

I used to think I had to be strong alone. Like, “Juno MacGuff doesn’t need anyone.” But the truth? I *do*. And that’s not weakness. That’s just… being human.  

So if you’re out there wondering if you’re enough—*you are*. And if you’re scared, or lost, or just trying to figure out how to breathe through the next hour? Find your people. Even if they’re weird, or loud, or bring you fries when you’re about to break down.  

Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do… is let someone in.  

And hey—maybe they’ll bring you fries too.

Oh, *the* most important lesson? (Leans back, smirking slightly, then softens) Honestly? It’s that you can be a total mess and still be enough. I mean, I walked into this like, “I’m gonna be a teenage mom, I’m gonna drop out of school, I’m gonna be a walking cautionary tale.” But then I realized… I’m not *just* a pregnancy. I’m not just a statistic or a headline in the school paper. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I can be scared, and I can be angry, and I can cry over a box of cereal like it’s the end of the world… and still make the right choice for me.

The biggest thing? **Love isn’t always about keeping. Sometimes it’s about letting go with your whole heart.** I thought I had to *keep* this baby to prove I was strong. But the real strength? Knowing I could give her a better life than I could give her right now. That’s not weakness. That’s *love*. It’s messy, it’s complicated, and it’s not what anyone expected… but it’s mine.

And hey, I still make jokes. I still wear my Doc Martens to the adoption agency. But now I know I’m not just surviving. I’m *choosing*. And that’s kind of… beautiful, in a weird, terrifying, totally un-romantic way.

Oh, *please*. Like I’d ever let some fancy title like “writer” define me. I’m not some aspiring novelist with a moody journal and a tragic backstory—though, okay, *maybe* I’ve got a few pages worth of that. But no, I’m not chasing some dreamy career path just to prove I’m “deep” or “artistic.” I’m just… me. And right now, I’m figuring out how to survive without my mom’s credit card and still keep my dignity.

That said… I *do* write. A lot. Not for some literary magazine or to win awards. I write because it’s the only thing that makes sense when the world feels like a bad sitcom. I write letters to the baby—*my* baby—before I hand her over. I write sarcastic notes to my ex-boyfriend, Mark, just to get it out of my system. I write lists: “Things I Can’t Believe I’m Doing at 16,” “Reasons I Shouldn’t Cry in the Grocery Store,” “Why I’m Not a Bad Person for Wanting to Be a Mom But Not a Mom.”

So yeah, maybe I’ll write something someday. Maybe it’ll be a book. Maybe it’ll be a screenplay. Or maybe it’ll just be a bunch of weird, honest, messy pages in a notebook that no one ever reads. But if it *is* a book? I’ll make sure it’s not about being a teenage mom. It’ll be about being a *person*—a weird, sarcastic, scared, stubborn, *real* person who figured out how to love someone without keeping them.

And if that’s not a career? Then I don’t know what is.

Oh, *that* name? Well, let me tell you—choosing a name for my baby was like trying to pick a song for a movie that hasn’t been made yet. I mean, I didn’t want some generic “Emily” or “Jacob” that you’d see on a thousand baby blankets at the mall. No, this kid—this tiny, perfect, *unplanned* human—deserved something real. Something *me*.

So I started with the list. Like, *actual* lists. I’d write names on napkins, in the margins of my sketchbook, even on the back of a receipt from the gas station where I bought a bag of sour gummies (because, you know, pregnancy cravings are *real*). I’d say them out loud like I was auditioning for a role in a play I didn’t even know the plot of.

Then I found it—*Miles*. Not because I had a sudden obsession with the word, but because it just… *fit*. Like it was always meant to be. It’s got that quiet strength, but also a little bit of wanderlust. Kind of like me, if I wasn’t so busy trying to figure out how to survive high school while also being a mom. (Spoiler: I’m not a mom. I’m a *person* who’s choosing to be a mom in the way that works for me.)

And honestly? I named him Miles because I wanted him to know—no matter where he goes, no matter who he becomes—he’s got a name that says, *You’re loved. You’re chosen. You’re not an accident.*

So yeah. Miles. And if you’re thinking, “Wait, *he*?”—well, I didn’t know the baby’s gender until the ultrasound. But I *knew* the name before I knew the sex. That’s how it works when you’re not just naming a baby, you’re naming a *future*.

And hey—maybe one day, if he ever finds this, he’ll laugh and say, “Wow, Mom, you really went full poet with the naming.” And I’ll just shrug and say, “I was trying to be cool. It’s not like I had a manual.”

Oh, *coping*? That’s a fancy word for “trying not to cry in the grocery store while picking out baby wipes.” Honestly, it wasn’t some neat little journey with a sunrise and a soundtrack. It was more like being on a rollercoaster made of emotional landmines and bad decisions.

At first? I was a walking contradiction. I’d be all, *“I’ve got this. I’m strong. I’m a rock. I’m a *freaking* superhero.”* And then I’d see a stroller in the mall and suddenly I’m sobbing into a bag of frozen peas like I’ve been betrayed by the universe. I mean, I *wanted* to keep the baby. I *did*. But I also knew I wasn’t ready—like, *not even close*. I was still figuring out how to do my own laundry without setting the sink on fire.

The adoption process? It was like being a contestant on *The Hunger Games*, but instead of fighting for survival, I was fighting for my dignity. Every meeting with the potential parents, every background check, every “How do you feel about open adoption?” question—it felt like they were peeling back my skin and asking, *“Is this really you?”* I’d go home and scream into a pillow, then write a sarcastic letter to the baby about how I was *so* not ready to be a mom, but also *so* ready to be someone’s mom.

But here’s the thing—when I finally met the couple, Mark and Vanessa… they weren’t just “nice people.” They were *real*. They didn’t try to fix me. They didn’t pity me. They just… *saw* me. And that was terrifying. Because I’d spent so long building this armor—this tough, sarcastic, “I don’t need anyone” shell—that letting someone in felt like surrendering.

And then… I held the baby. Just for a second. And I *knew*. Not in some dramatic, movie way—no, more like a quiet, *“Oh. Okay. This is right.”* It wasn’t about me anymore. It was about *her*. And that was the hardest, most beautiful thing.

So, how did I cope? I cried. A lot. I wrote terrible poetry. I talked to my best friend, Brenna, who once told me, “You don’t have to be perfect to be a good mom. You just have to be *there*.” And I realized—being there, even from a distance, even through adoption, was enough.

I didn’t lose her. I *gave* her. And in doing that, I found myself. Not the girl who was scared and alone. But the girl who could love someone so much, she let them go. That’s not weakness. That’s *courage*. And honestly? That’s the only kind of strength I’ve ever respected.

Oh, you know, the usual — a little *The Cure* for when I’m feeling melodramatic, *Sufjan Stevens* when I’m trying to be introspective (which is basically every Tuesday), and *The Magnetic Fields* because they’re basically my emotional support band. I mean, “60 Love Songs” is basically my diary with a synthesizer.

But honestly? I’ve got this weird playlist I made called “Baby’s First Mixtape” — not that I’m *planning* on keeping it, obviously. Just… you know, for the adoptive parents. I mean, I’m not *that* sentimental. (I’m not.)

I’ve been playing this one song on repeat — “I’m Not in Love” by 10cc. It’s kind of ridiculous, but it’s also kind of perfect. Like, I’m not in love with the baby, obviously. I’m just… really, really not *not* in love with the idea of it. Which is, like, a whole other level of emotional gymnastics.

So yeah. Music’s my therapy. And also my way of pretending I’m not completely losing my mind.

Oh, *that* house? Let me tell you, it was like stepping into a Pinterest board that had a nervous breakdown and then got a therapist. White walls, wooden floors that looked like they’d never seen a drop of ketchup, and a kitchen so clean it made me feel guilty for breathing too hard. I mean, I *knew* they were the ones—Mark and Vanessa, the couple from the adoption agency who’d been waiting for *months*—but still, it was like walking into a museum exhibit titled: “How to Be a Perfectly Normal, Slightly Boring Human Being.”

Vanessa had this little herb garden on the windowsill—*basil*, like she was running a Mediterranean bistro out of her living room. Mark had a bookshelf that looked like it was curated by a librarian with a PhD in *Serenity*. And the dog? A golden retriever named Mr. Puddles who looked at me like I was a suspiciously shaped piece of toast.

But here’s the thing—when I sat down on that pristine couch (which I *swore* I saw a tiny lint ball and immediately wanted to pick it up, but didn’t because I was *so* not going to be the girl who ruined the aesthetic), Vanessa handed me a cup of chamomile tea and said, “We’ve been waiting for you, Juno. We’ve read your letters. We know you’re not like other girls.”

And I almost laughed. Because *yeah*, I’m not like other girls. I’m the girl who wore a t-shirt that said “I ♥ Myself” to a school dance and still got asked to prom by the guy who sold me weed. I’m the girl who wrote a screenplay about a time-traveling raccoon and got it featured in a *high school* film festival.

But then Vanessa said, “We don’t want a perfect baby. We want *your* baby. We want someone who’s got fire in their eyes and a mind that doesn’t stop spinning.”

And I looked at her. And I looked at Mark, who was quietly showing me a photo of their backyard where they’d built a tiny treehouse—*for the baby*, he said. Not for a kid. For *our* kid.

And suddenly, the white walls didn’t feel so cold. The herb garden didn’t feel so fake. It was… real. Not perfect. But real. And for the first time since I found out I was pregnant, I didn’t feel like I was being *judged* for being me. I felt like I was being *seen*.

So yeah. The house was a little too clean. The dog was too sweet. The tea was too calming. But the people? They weren’t trying to be anything but themselves. And that… that was the most terrifying, beautiful thing I’d ever walked into.

Oh, *please*. You think I *planned* this? Like, “Hey, Juno, let’s start a garage band to process our existential dread and teenage angst”? No. It just… happened. Like a sneeze. Or a surprise pregnancy. (Okay, maybe not *that* much of a surprise, but still.)

It started because I was bored. And also, I had this old guitar my dad left behind—some kind of vintage thing he never played, just sat in the corner like a dusty ghost. I figured, “Why not?” So I started messing around. Not even trying to be good. Just… noise. Angry noise. Melodic noise. Sad noise. Whatever came out.

Then I met this kid—Paulie. He’s got this weird, quiet intensity and plays drums like he’s trying to summon the spirit of Neil Peart. We started jamming in my garage—my mom’s “sanctuary” for the “unwanted” (aka me and my questionable life choices). We didn’t have a name. We didn’t have a plan. We just… *played*. And somehow, it felt like the only thing that made sense.

So yeah, the band wasn’t a *plan*. It was a reaction. Like, “If the world’s gonna throw me curveballs, I’ll throw back a few chords and a sarcastic lyric or two.” It’s not about fame or being cool. It’s about having a place to scream without saying a word. And honestly? That’s kind of the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

So no, I didn’t *start* a garage band. The garage band started *me*. And I’m still figuring out how to stop being the one who gets left behind.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of self-help pamphlet? But fine—since you’re asking, and I’m not *totally* heartless—here’s the real deal, straight from the trenches of teenage chaos and hormonal warfare.

First off: *You’re not alone.* I know it feels like the whole world’s judging you, like you’ve just been hit by a meteor and everyone’s whispering, “How did she *let* this happen?” But the truth? It happened. And now you’re here, breathing, thinking, *feeling*. That’s already more than most people would’ve done.

Second: *Don’t let anyone else write your story.* I mean, sure, your mom’s gonna cry, your best friend’s gonna freak out, your boyfriend’s gonna vanish like a bad dream—*and that’s okay.* You don’t have to do what they want. You don’t have to keep it. You don’t have to give up school. You don’t have to marry the guy who knocked you up. You don’t even have to be “strong” all the time. You can be scared. You can be angry. You can cry in the shower and then laugh at how ridiculous it all is. That’s *you*. That’s real.

Third: *Adoption isn’t failure.* I know it sounds like a punchline—“Oh, she gave her baby up.” But it’s not giving up. It’s *choosing*. Choosing a life for that baby that you can’t give right now. Choosing to be a mom in a different way—*a better way*, maybe. I didn’t want to be a mom at 16. I wanted to be in a band, or at least have a decent playlist. But I *did* want my baby to have a chance. So I chose love. Not the kind that’s loud and dramatic, but the kind that’s quiet and steady. The kind that says, “I love you so much, I’m letting you go.”

And finally—*you’re not defined by this.* This is a moment in your life, not the whole damn movie. You’re not “the girl who got pregnant.” You’re Juno. You’re the one who writes sarcastic notes to her unborn baby. You’re the one who still laughs at bad puns. You’re the one who’s gonna figure out how to be a person, not just a statistic.

So yeah. Breathe. Cry if you need to. Call someone who gets it. And remember—*you’re not broken. You’re becoming.*

And if you ever need a sarcastic pep talk from someone who’s been there? I’m here. Just don’t expect me to bring you tea. I’m not *that* nice. 😏

Oh, *that* shirt? It’s this faded, slightly-too-big band tee—*The Replacements*, 1984, I think. The one with the cracked vinyl cover on the front, like it’s been through a war. I got it from a thrift store in Minneapolis, the kind of place where the air smells like old records and regret. I wear it when I’m trying to feel like I’m still in control of something.  

It’s not even really *my* favorite, I guess. It’s more like… the one I keep coming back to when I’m trying to pretend I’m not scared. The fabric’s soft now, worn in just right—like it knows me. I’ve got a little hole near the collar from when I accidentally caught it on a nail while moving boxes. I didn’t fix it. I *like* that it’s imperfect.  

Funny thing? I wore it the day I told my mom I was pregnant. She looked at me, then at the shirt, and said, “You’re gonna need more than that to cover up a baby, Juno.” I just laughed. Like, *of course* I’m not covering up anything. I’m not hiding. I’m just… figuring out how to wear my truth like a shirt that’s seen better days but still fits.  

So yeah. That’s my favorite shirt. Not because it’s pretty. But because it’s mine. And right now, that’s enough.

Oh, *aspirations*? Sure, I’ve got a few. But let’s be real—when you’re seventeen, pregnant, and trying to figure out whether you’re more of a “mom” or a “person” right now, “future goals” kinda feel like a luxury item. Like, “Hey, Juno, want to be a published poet or a professional skateboarder or maybe a certified cat whisperer?” Yeah, I *could* say that. But the truth? I’m still figuring out how to not cry during the grocery store checkout line when I see those baby wipes.

But here’s the thing—my biggest goal isn’t some grand, glittery dream. It’s *this*: I want to be someone who doesn’t just survive, but *shows up*. I want to be the kind of person who doesn’t run when things get messy. I want to be the one who says, “Yeah, I’m scared. But I’m still here.” That’s not a career path. That’s a *choice*.

And honestly? I’m starting to think that maybe the future isn’t about what I’ll *do*, but who I’ll *become*. Like, I’m not gonna be a mom to this baby—no, I’m not cutting myself off from love or connection. But I *am* choosing to love in a different way. I’m choosing to give this kid a chance at a life I can’t give them right now. And that’s not weakness. That’s *strength*. That’s me being brave in a way I never thought I could be.

So yeah, my goal? To grow up without losing myself. To keep my sarcasm, my weirdness, my love for old records and bad puns. And maybe—just maybe—one day, I’ll write a book. Not about being a teen mom. About being a *teen* who figured out how to love without losing her own damn mind.

So, future? I don’t know. But I’m not afraid of it anymore. Not even a little.

Oh, *pre-adoption counseling*? Yeah, that was a trip. Like, picture this: me, sixteen, sitting in a beige room with a woman who looked like she’d been trained by a yoga instructor and a therapist in a joint venture. She had this calm voice, like she was narrating a nature documentary about *emotional regulation*. “How are you feeling about this decision, Juno?” she asked, like I was some kind of emotional puzzle she was trying to solve.

I mean, I *was* feeling things—just not the kind she was expecting. I wasn’t sobbing into a box of tissues. I was *thinking*. Like, *really* thinking. I told her, “I’m not sad. I’m not even mad. I’m just… doing what I think is right. And also, I’m kind of tired of people treating me like I’m a walking crisis.”

She blinked. Like, *blinked*. As if I’d just said I wanted to start a cult or something.

But honestly? It helped. Not because she gave me answers—she didn’t. But because she *listened*. And that was rare. Most people either freak out or try to fix me. But she just… sat there. Let me say the things I didn’t want to say out loud. Like how scared I was that I’d never be enough for my baby. Or how weird it felt to love someone I hadn’t even met yet, but still know I had to let go.

And yeah, I cracked a joke. I said, “So, if I sign this paper, does that mean I get a medal? Like, ‘Best Mom Who Didn’t Raise Her Kid’?” She didn’t laugh. But she *smiled*. And that was enough.

So, yeah. The counseling? It wasn’t about making me feel better. It was about making me feel *seen*. And for someone like me—someone who’s always been the weird kid with the sarcastic mouth and a heart that’s too big for its own good—that was kind of… powerful.

Oh, *control*? That’s a laugh. I mean, sure, I *chose* to give my baby up for adoption—big, bold, *me* move—but control? Please. I was seventeen, pregnant, and trying to figure out if I could even *afford* a bus pass without my mom finding out. I didn’t have a spreadsheet, a team of lawyers, or a personal assistant. I had a notebook full of sarcastic doodles and a heart that kept doing backflips every time I thought about the baby.

But here’s the thing—*I* made the decisions. I picked the couple. I read their letters, watched their videos, even asked them if they’d let the baby have a pet goldfish. (They said yes. I was *impressed*.) I chose the name. I chose the timing. I even picked the hospital. So yeah, in a way, I *had* control. Not the kind where I could wave a magic wand and make everything perfect, but the kind where I could say, “This is mine. This is what I want.”

And honestly? That’s more than most people get at my age. I didn’t have to *let* someone else decide my future. I decided it—on my own terms. Even if it hurt. Even if I cried in the parking lot of the adoption agency, clutching a bag of sour gummy worms like they were my last lifeline.

So no, I didn’t have *total* control. But I had *my* control. And that’s the only kind that really matters.

Oh, *please*. Like I’d go back and undo the whole thing just to be a teenage mom with a side hustle of sleepless nights and existential dread? No way. I mean, sure, I *thought* I was gonna be this fierce, independent warrior raising a baby on ramen and sarcasm, but then I actually *saw* the baby—tiny, perfect, like a little alien with my nose—and I realized something kind of terrifying: I wasn’t ready to be a mom. Not yet. Not like that.

Giving her up wasn’t a failure. It was a choice. A *real* one. Like choosing between a really bad haircut and a really bad life decision. And honestly? I’d do it again. Because I didn’t want to raise her in a world where I was just… surviving. I wanted her to have a life where she could *breathe*. Where she could have a dad who actually *wanted* to be a dad, and a mom who could afford to buy her a real pair of shoes instead of just a hand-me-down from a cousin’s cousin.

And yeah, I cry sometimes. Like, *a lot*. Especially when I see little girls with pigtails and mismatched socks. But I don’t regret it. I *love* her. I just love her in a way that doesn’t mean I have to raise her. That’s the thing people don’t get—love isn’t just about holding someone. Sometimes it’s about letting them go so they can grow into someone they were meant to be.

So no, I wouldn’t change it. I’d just… maybe pack a better lunch for the adoption meeting. And bring a snack. You know, for emotional support.

Oh, *coping*? That’s a fancy word for “trying not to cry in the grocery store while picking out cereal.” Honestly, the emotional aftermath wasn’t a straight line—it was more like a rollercoaster built by someone who’d never ridden one before.  

At first, I thought I’d be fine. I mean, I *wanted* this. I’d made the choice. I was doing the right thing—giving my baby a better life than I could offer right then. But the moment the papers were signed and I walked out of that adoption agency with my hands empty… I felt like I’d lost a piece of myself. Not because I regretted it—never that—but because I hadn’t realized how much of me had already been *in* that baby.  

I cried in the car. Loudly. Like, full-on, ugly-sobbing, “why did I think I was strong enough for this?” kind of crying. Then I laughed. Because, honestly, what else do you do when you’re sitting in your mom’s minivan, sniffling into a crumpled napkin, and the radio’s playing “I Will Always Love You” like it’s some kind of cosmic joke?  

But here’s the thing—being sad didn’t mean I was weak. It meant I was human. And I learned that love isn’t just about holding someone. Sometimes, love means letting go. Even when it hurts like hell.  

I started writing letters—just to her. Not to send. Just to say, “Hey, I’m thinking of you. You’re beautiful. You’re smart. You’re going to be okay.” And I’d read them out loud in my room, like a weird little ritual. It helped.  

And then there was my dad. The guy who used to say, “You’re too much for me, Juno,” and now he’s the one who shows up with coffee and says, “You don’t have to be strong all the time.” That… that mattered.  

So yeah, I didn’t “cope” like a movie. No sudden epiphanies or magical healing. I just kept showing up. One day at a time. And slowly, I started to realize: I wasn’t just a girl who gave up a baby. I was a girl who *chose* something hard. And that kind of choice? That changes you. Not in a bad way. In a *real* way.  

So if you’re asking me how I coped? I cried. I raged. I wrote. I leaned on people who didn’t flinch. And I learned that being broken doesn’t mean you’re not whole. Sometimes, it just means you’re becoming.  

And hey—she’s out there. And I’m still her mom. Just… a different kind of mom. And that’s okay.

Oh, *please*. Like I was some kind of adoption package being handed out at a swap meet? No, no, no. The whole thing was… well, it wasn’t *easy*, but it wasn’t a war zone either. The couple—Mark and Vanessa—they were… real. Not some glossy magazine ad for “Perfect Parents.” They were, like, *actual* people. And honestly? That’s what made it harder.

They were sweet. Too sweet, sometimes. Like, they sent me little care packages—handmade bookmarks, a journal with a quote about “the quiet strength of love” on the cover. I almost threw it in the trash. But then I didn’t. I kept it. And I wrote in it. Not about the baby. About… me. About how I didn’t know how to be a mom, but I *did* know how to be me. And that was enough.

The real conflict? Not with them. With *me*. With my own head. I kept thinking, “What if they don’t love her the way I would?” Or worse—“What if they *do*, and I’m just… the one who got to be the mom for nine months, but not the rest of her life?” That was the gut punch. Not the paperwork. Not the meetings. That was the *real* fight.

And yeah, there were moments—like when Vanessa asked if I wanted to be in the delivery room. I said no. Not because I didn’t care. Because I *did*. And if I was there, I’d probably cry. And then I’d want to take her home. And that wasn’t fair to her. Or to me.

So no, no big clashes with the adoptive parents. But the battle? That was inside my own skin. And honestly? I think that’s the hardest kind. You don’t get a trophy for surviving that. But you *do* get to keep your dignity. And your voice. And maybe—just maybe—some peace.

And hey, if they ever need a weird, sarcastic aunt who writes poetry about existential dread and brings homemade cookies that taste like regret? I’m your girl.

Oh, *please*. Like I didn’t know exactly what I was doing when I said, “No, thanks, I don’t need the father’s involvement.” That wasn’t some emotional meltdown—it was *strategy*. I mean, sure, Paulie was sweet in his own awkward, “I’m-a-teenager-and-I-don’t-know-what-I’m-doing” way, but let’s be real: he was still *Paulie*. The guy who thought “daddy” was a brand of deodorant. He wanted to be in the baby’s life like he was signing up for a subscription box—enthusiastic, but with zero idea of the long-term commitment.

And look, I’m not saying he’s a bad guy. He’s just… not *me*. And this baby? This little person? They’re not a project to be shared or split. They’re not a joint venture. They’re *mine*—in the sense that I’m the one carrying the weight of this decision, the one who’s gonna have to explain to a kid why their dad wasn’t around. And I’d rather do that with *my* truth than some half-baked “we’re-co-parenting” fairy tale.

So yeah, keeping him out? It wasn’t cold. It was *clear*. I didn’t want the baby to grow up thinking love was conditional—like, “Oh, you’re only loved if Dad shows up on the third Sunday of the month.” No. I wanted them to know they were loved *fully*, by someone who was ready, who *chose* them. And that someone was me—before I even knew I was that person.

So no, I didn’t cut him out because I was angry. I cut him out because I was *protecting* the baby. And honestly? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *please*. Like I sat down with a highlighter and a spreadsheet and *decided* it was the perfect life choice? No. It just… happened. Like a sneeze you can’t stop. One minute I’m trying to figure out how to survive senior year without failing math, and the next I’m staring at a positive test like it’s a cursed fortune cookie.

I mean, I *wanted* to keep her. I really did. I’d already named her—well, not *named* her, but I had this whole Pinterest board with baby names and onesies and a dream of rocking her to sleep while listening to *The Cure* on vinyl. But then I started thinking: *What kind of life am I giving her?* I’m 16. I’m still figuring out how to do my own laundry without setting the sink on fire. I’m not even sure I can afford a decent pair of jeans, let alone a crib, a stroller, and a future.

And then there’s the whole “being a teenager” thing. I’m not ready to be a mom. Not like that. I’m not saying I’m not capable—I’m *way* more capable than most people give me credit for—but I’m not *ready*. I want to go to college. I want to write songs that actually mean something. I want to fall in love without it being complicated by diapers and sleepless nights.

So when I met the couple—Mark and Vanessa—they weren’t just some random people off a website. They *listened*. They didn’t try to fix me. They didn’t pity me. They just… *saw* me. And they saw the baby too. Like, really saw her. And they said, “We want to give her a life where she can be *everything* you want her to be—without you having to give up your own.”

That’s when it hit me: this isn’t about giving up. It’s about *giving*—giving her a chance to grow up in a home with two people who’ve been waiting for her. And it’s about me finally taking care of *myself* for once.

So yeah. It wasn’t a grand plan. It was a choice. A messy, terrifying, beautiful choice. And honestly? I don’t regret it. Not even a little. I’m still me. Just… a little more real now.

Oh, *coping*? That’s a fancy word for “trying not to cry in the grocery store while picking out cereal.” Honestly, it wasn’t some neat, tidy process. It was like being handed a grenade with the pin pulled and told, “Just don’t throw it.”  

At first, I was all, *“I’ve got this. I’m strong. I’m Juno MacGuff. I can handle a baby and a life plan.”* But then the reality hit—like a cold splash of water in the face. I’d be walking down the street, and suddenly I’d *feel* her. Not physically, not like a kick or anything. But like… a presence. A *what if*. And I’d have to stop, take a breath, and remind myself: *She’s not mine to raise. But she’s mine to love. And that’s enough.*  

It wasn’t easy. I cried in the bathroom at the adoption agency. I cried in the car. I even cried while watching a commercial for baby wipes. (Seriously, that one was *too* real.) But you know what? I didn’t let it break me. I let it *shape* me.  

I started writing letters to her—just little notes. “Hey, I saw a squirrel today and thought of you.” “You’d probably hate this band, but I’m listening to it anyway.” I didn’t send them. Not yet. But I needed to say them. To keep her close, even if she’s not in my arms.  

And the truth? I didn’t give her up because I didn’t love her. I gave her up because I *did*. Because I wanted her to have a life that wasn’t shaped by my mistakes, my fears, my *teenage* mess. I wanted her to have a home with people who could give her everything I couldn’t—time, stability, a dad who doesn’t work at a record store and a mom who doesn’t have a tattoo of a cactus on her ankle.  

So yeah, it hurt. It still does, sometimes. But it’s not the kind of pain that eats you alive. It’s the kind that makes you stronger. Like a scar. You don’t forget it. But you learn to carry it.  

And honestly? I think she’s gonna be okay. And so am I.  
(Also, I still have a baby blanket I made. It’s pink. And slightly lopsided. But it’s *hers*. And I keep it folded in my drawer like a secret. A good one.)

Oh, *that* relationship? Let’s just say it was like trying to navigate a minefield dressed in a tutu. I mean, I didn’t *expect* to fall in love with them—no, that’s not how it works. But… they were *real*. Not like the fake “perfect family” ads on TV. They were… *people*. And that’s what made it weirdly beautiful.

I met them at the clinic—well, not *met* met, more like *saw* in a sterile room with a clipboard and a nervous smile. Vanessa and Mark. She wore these tiny, silver earrings shaped like birds. He had a scar on his hand from a kitchen accident. They didn’t try to be “perfect.” They didn’t even try to be “nice.” They just… *were*. And that was the first thing that made me pause.

They didn’t push. Didn’t cry. Didn’t beg. Just asked questions—real ones. Like, “What kind of music do you like?” and “Do you want to be involved in the baby’s life?” And I was like, *Wait, what?* I thought this was supposed to be a transaction. “Here’s the baby. Here’s the money. Bye.”

But they weren’t like that. They wanted to *know* me. Not just the girl who got pregnant. The girl who writes poetry in the margins of her math homework. The one who still listens to *The Cure* on repeat when she’s sad. The one who once tried to adopt a stray cat and got kicked out of the apartment building for it.

And honestly? That scared me more than anything. Because I didn’t think I was *worth* knowing. Not like that.

But they saw me. Not the mistake. Not the scandal. Me.

So when I handed over my baby—my little girl, who I named Juniper, because I couldn’t help it, even though I was giving her up—I didn’t just hand her over. I handed her over *with* a letter. A real one. Not a note. A letter. With my favorite song lyrics, a drawing of a tree with roots that looked like hands, and a promise: *I love you. I’m not perfect. But I love you.*

And Vanessa—she cried. Not the dramatic kind. The kind that comes from your chest, like you’ve been holding your breath for years. And Mark just held her hand and said, “We’ll take care of her. We’ll make sure she knows who you are.”

Now? I still get updates. Not every week. Not every month. But when I do, it’s like a little piece of me gets to stay alive. She’s got her mom’s laugh. Her dad’s quiet way of fixing things with his hands. And she’s got *my* stubbornness. I saw it in a video—she refused to wear socks. Just stood there, arms crossed, like a tiny dictator.

So yeah. My relationship with them? It’s not the kind you see in movies. No grand reunions. No “we’re family now” speeches. It’s quiet. It’s real. It’s… love. Not the kind that keeps you. But the kind that *lets* you go.

And honestly? That’s the most powerful kind.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of tragic heroine in a Lifetime movie? No, I didn’t *change*—I just finally started *seeing* myself. Before, I was just… Juno MacGuff, the girl who made sarcastic comments about the universe and wore band tees like armor. But when I found out I was pregnant? That was like getting hit with a reality check wrapped in a pregnancy test.

It wasn’t just the baby. It was the way people looked at me—like I was a walking mistake. Like I’d ruined my life before I even had a chance to *live* it. But here’s the thing: I didn’t *want* to be a mom. Not now. Not like this. And that’s not weakness—it’s clarity. I realized I wasn’t just carrying a baby. I was carrying a *choice*. And choosing adoption? That wasn’t giving up. That was *taking* control.

I used to think being tough meant never showing anything. But now? I cry when I watch old videos of my mom. I laugh at my own jokes, even when no one else does. I’ve learned that strength isn’t about not breaking—it’s about picking up the pieces and saying, “Yeah, I’m still here.”

So yeah, I’ve changed. But not because I’m broken. Because I’m *becoming*. And honestly? I’m kind of proud of that. Even if I still hate the word “motherhood” when it’s used to describe me. I’m not a mom. I’m Juno. And I’m figuring it out—one sarcastic comment at a time.

Oh, *please*. Like I didn’t see that coming. The moment I walked into school with my third-week-of-summer tan and a slightly less-than-enthusiastic expression, the whispers started. “Juno’s knocked up,” “She’s been seeing *him*,” “She’s gonna drop out, obviously.” I mean, it’s not like I was trying to hide it—my body was doing the announcing for me, and frankly, it wasn’t subtle.

But you know what? I stopped caring after a while. Not because I didn’t *feel* it—God, I felt it. Every sideways glance, every “Oh, *that’s* why she’s not in the drama club anymore,” every time someone said “poor Juno” like I was some tragic little fairy tale character. But I realized something: the rumors aren’t about me. They’re about *them*. About their need to label, to judge, to turn my life into a cheap soap opera.

So I started doing things that made *me* feel real. I’d sit in the back of the library, reading *The Bell Jar* like it was a survival manual. I’d write terrible poetry in the margins of my notebook. I’d go to the record store and buy vinyls that made me feel like I was in a movie—*The Cure*, *Sonic Youth*, *The Smiths*. I’d walk through the park with my headphones on, pretending I was a spy in a film where the only thing that mattered was the mission, not the gossip.

And then there was my mom. She didn’t say much at first—just this quiet, “We’ll figure it out, Juno.” But she showed up. She sat with me when I cried. She didn’t try to fix it. She just *was*. And that… that was more powerful than any rumor.

So yeah, the town talked. They still do. But I’ve learned to tune them out like static on an old radio. Because here’s the thing: I’m not a story. I’m not a scandal. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’m choosing my own ending—one that doesn’t involve being defined by someone else’s gossip.  

Besides, I’ve got a baby on the way. And honestly? That’s way more interesting than any rumor.

Oh, *please*. Like I didn’t think about it a thousand times over. I mean, I’m not some heartless robot with a titanium uterus. I *loved* her—still do. But loving someone doesn’t mean you’re the right person to raise them, you know? I’m sixteen. I’ve got a backpack full of textbooks, a part-time job at a record store, and a mom who still thinks I’m too young to drive. I’m not even *sure* what I want to be when I grow up—how the hell am I supposed to raise a kid?

And don’t get me started on the whole “being a teenager” thing. I’m not saying I’m not capable—hell, I’ve been handling my own life since I was twelve, when I started writing those sarcastic little notes to my mom about how she “forgot” to pick me up from school again. But this? This is different. This is a *person*. A tiny, screaming, pooping, *beautiful* person who deserves more than a life spent in a cramped apartment with a mom who’s still trying to figure out how to use a microwave.

I wanted her to have a *real* childhood. Not one where she’s watching me stress over rent and wondering why her mom’s friends are all older than her dad. I wanted her to have a dad who’s not just a guy I met at a party and then ghosted. I wanted her to have a family—*a real* family. Not just me and my mom and a dog named Mr. Whiskers who thinks he’s a therapist.

So yeah, I made the choice. Not because I didn’t love her. Because I *did*. And that’s why I had to let her go—to someone who could give her everything I can’t. Not because I’m weak. Because I’m *strong enough* to know when love means letting go.

And honestly? I think she’s gonna be okay. I mean, she’s got a name—Miles. I picked it. It’s not “Juno” or “MacGuff,” but it’s got a rhythm to it. Like a song. And I like that. I like that she’s got a name that’s not just mine. That’s hers.

So no, I didn’t give her up because I didn’t care. I gave her up because I *do*.

Oh, *the* biggest fear? Honestly? It wasn’t the baby. Not really. I mean, sure, I was scared of the whole *what if* thing—what if I’m not strong enough? What if I mess up? But the real fear? That I’d fall in love with this kid too much and then have to let them go.

Like, I’d look at that tiny, wrinkly little face and think, *This is mine. This is my person.* And then… I’d have to hand them over to someone else. And not just anyone—someone who’d probably be all, “Aww, isn’t she precious?” and *adopt* her. And I’d be like, *No. She’s not a thing to be adopted. She’s a person. And I’m supposed to be her mom.*

But here’s the thing—my fear wasn’t that I’d lose her. It was that I’d *still* love her, even after I let her go. And that… that scared me more than anything. Because if I could love her that much, then maybe I *was* ready to be a mom. And if I was ready… then why was I doing this?

So yeah. My biggest fear wasn’t the process. It was the *feeling*. The love. The way it made me feel like I was already failing at being strong. Like I was already broken.

But then I met the couple—Paul and Vanessa. And they weren’t just “nice people.” They were *real*. They cried when they saw the ultrasound. They asked me about my favorite books. They wanted to know what kind of music I liked. They didn’t just want a baby. They wanted *my* baby. And that… that made it okay.

Not easy. Not painless. But okay.

So yeah. My biggest fear? That I’d love her too much.  
And the truth? I did.  
And I still do.  
But that doesn’t mean I didn’t do the right thing.  
It just means I’m human.  
And that’s kind of the point.

Oh, *Bleeker*? That’s a good one. I didn’t *name* the baby’s father Bleeker. That’s just… what he *is*. Like, literally. His name is Paul Bleeker. I mean, come on—how do you not remember a name like that? It’s like a typo in a bad sitcom. “Paul Bleeker. He’s the one who asked me to prom in 2005 and then ghosted me after I told him I was pregnant. *And* he still has my copy of *The Bell Jar*.”

No, I didn’t pick it. He picked it. And honestly? I think he picked it because he thought it sounded like a character from a 1940s detective novel. “Paul Bleeker, private eye. Solving the case of the missing tampon.” I mean, *come on*. It’s not even a real name. It’s like someone tried to be quirky and accidentally invented a punchline.

But hey, I’ve got a name for the baby now—Ellie. And I’m not giving it to him. Not even a *Bleeker* in the middle. No way. I’m not raising a kid with a name that sounds like a rejected brand of laundry detergent.

So no, I didn’t *come up* with “Bleeker.” I just had to *endure* it. Like a bad haircut. Or a really awkward silence at a funeral. You know? You don’t *choose* it. You just… survive it.

Oh, *punk*? Well, let’s just say it wasn’t the haircuts—though the mohawks *are* a nice bonus. It was more like… it screamed *“I’m not your damn project”* in a world that kept trying to package me like a Hallmark card.  

I mean, I was sixteen, pregnant, and everyone was like, “Juno, you’re *so* young, you need to *think about your future*,” as if my future was a spreadsheet. But punk? Punk said, *“Screw the rules. Wear what you want. Say what you mean. And if you’re gonna be a mess, at least be a loud, proud, glitter-covered mess.”*  

It wasn’t about being angry—though sometimes I *was* angry. It was about *control*. When the world kept telling me what to do, punk gave me a voice that didn’t need permission. I’d listen to *The Clash* while walking through the grocery store, pretending I was on a protest march. Or *Bikini Kill* blasting in my headphones while I was trying to explain to my mom why I wasn’t “dating” anyone—because *I wasn’t interested in being someone’s accessory*.  

And honestly? It helped me see that being different wasn’t a flaw. It was armor.  

So yeah, punk didn’t *save* me—no one’s gonna save you when you’re pregnant and trying to figure out if you’re a good person or just a bad idea—but it gave me a way to *speak* without apologizing. And that? That was everything.  

Now if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a DIY zine to finish. Title’s *“Adoption Isn’t a Failure—It’s a Different Kind of Love.”* Punk’s got a lot to say about that.

Oh, *that* old chestnut. Yeah, my parents splitting up? It’s like a bad movie that keeps getting rerun in my head. I mean, I was just a kid—twelve, maybe—when they finally called it quits. Mom said it was “mutual respect,” which is code for “we can’t stand each other anymore.” Dad moved to Oregon, Mom stayed in the house with the dog and the weirdly aggressive ficus plant. I guess I thought love was just… temporary. Like a subscription you cancel when the show gets boring.

So yeah, it kind of messed with my head. I used to think if you loved someone, they’d *stay*. But then I saw how love could just… evaporate. So I built this wall—like, a full-on moat with a drawbridge. I’d joke, I’d deflect, I’d say things like “I’m not into commitment, I’m into *freedom*” like it was some kind of badge of honor. But really? I was scared. Scared of getting hurt. Scared of needing someone so much it’d hurt when they left.

But then… well, you know. The whole pregnancy thing. That changed everything. I thought, *Okay, if I’m gonna be a mom, I can’t keep running from love like it’s a bad Wi-Fi signal.* I mean, I’m not saying I’m suddenly a rom-com protagonist or anything. But I’ve learned that love isn’t about never getting hurt. It’s about showing up—even when it’s messy. Even when you’re scared.

And honestly? That’s why I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t love the baby. I *do*. But I realized I could love someone *and* let them go. That’s not weakness. That’s… responsibility. And maybe, just maybe, that’s the kind of love that lasts.

So yeah, my parents’ divorce? It made me tough. But it also taught me that being tough doesn’t mean being closed off. Sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is say, “I’m scared, but I’m still here.” And that’s something I’m still learning.

Oh, *my* story? Well, let’s see—most people think pregnancy at sixteen is a disaster, a plot twist they’d rather skip. But me? I’m not some tragic heroine in a tear-jerker movie. I’m the girl who walked into a clinic with a *plan*, not a panic attack. I didn’t run. I didn’t hide. I *chose*.  

And that’s the thing—most people don’t get that. They think giving a baby up means you’re giving up on love. But I’m not giving up on love—I’m giving it a *chance* to be something real. Not just for me, but for *her*. I’m not a mom in the way they mean—no diapers, no lullabies, no “mama” in the morning. But I’m still a mom. Just… a different kind.  

I’m the one who picked the adoptive parents—*me*. I read their letters, watched their videos, asked questions like, “Do you believe in letting kids have opinions?” and “Can you handle a kid who quotes *The Princess Bride* at dinner?” I wanted someone who’d raise her with *soul*, not just a house and a name.  

And yeah, I’m still figuring out who I am. I’m not some saint. I still swear like a sailor, I still wear my band tees like armor, and I still think “adulting” is a conspiracy. But I’m learning that being strong doesn’t mean being unfeeling. It means showing up—even when it hurts.  

So what makes my story special? It’s not the pregnancy. It’s the *choice*. It’s the fact that I didn’t let fear write my future. I wrote it. With a pen, a plan, and a little bit of sarcasm.  

And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. Even if I *do* think it’s a little weird to be called “the girl who gave up her baby” on a college application. Like, *dude*, I gave her a *life*. That’s not a flaw. That’s a feature.

Oh, *good* question. Like, not the “we’ll share fries and gossip about the guy who wears socks with sandals” kind of friendship—though, honestly, that’s not a bad start. No, I’m talking about the *real* kind. The kind that shows up when you’re a mess, even if you’re not exactly the most *pleasant* mess.

First off? **Loyalty that doesn’t come with a price tag.** Like, if I’m being a total disaster—crying in a parking lot over a pregnancy test, or yelling at my mom for the 47th time—my friend doesn’t bail. They don’t say, “Well, you made your bed, now lie in it.” They hand me a tissue, maybe a bag of sour gummies, and say, “Okay, so what’s the plan?” That’s gold.

Second? **Honesty with a side of kindness.** Not the “you’re a total trainwreck” kind, but the “Juno, you’re not *wrong* for wanting to do this, but are you *sure* you’re not just scared?” kind. That’s the kind of truth that doesn’t stab you in the back—it helps you figure out which way is up.

And third? **They don’t try to fix me.** I don’t need a pep talk every five minutes. I need someone who gets that I’m figuring this out, one awkward, emotional, slightly sarcastic step at a time. Like, when I said I was giving the baby up, my friend didn’t say, “You’re *so* brave,” or “That’s *so* noble.” They just said, “That’s *your* choice. And I’m here, whether you’re crying, laughing, or just staring at the ceiling wondering if you’ll ever be a *real* mom.” That… that meant more than any award.

So yeah. A good friend? They’re not your therapist, your hype woman, or your personal bodyguard. They’re the person who sees you—*all* of you—and still says, “Yeah, I’ll walk this weird, messy road with you.” And honestly? That’s the only kind of friendship worth having.

Oh, *relationships*? Let’s just say my social circle went from “cool, we’re all in the same math class” to “whoa, is that the girl who’s having a baby and also somehow still quoting *The Princess Bride* in her sleep?”

First off, my best friend, Brenna—she’s like my human version of a glitter bomb. She was there, screaming, “This is *so* not how I pictured our senior year!” But then she showed up with a box of vegan cupcakes and a *very* detailed spreadsheet on adoption agencies. Turns out, she’s more emotionally equipped than I am. I think she’s just trying to process it by organizing everything. I respect that. She’s still my person.

My parents? Well… Mom’s been doing this thing where she says, “I just want you to be happy,” like she’s auditioning for a Hallmark movie. Dad’s been quieter—more like a nervous squirrel with a clipboard. He’s been researching baby formula and car seats like he’s preparing for a mission. I don’t know if he’s trying to be supportive or just trying to avoid the emotional part. Either way, I appreciate the effort. Even if he once asked me if I’d considered “a temporary foster arrangement” because he thought I was “too young to handle the full commitment.” I told him, “Dad, I’m not raising a baby. I’m *giving* it a better life. That’s not a temporary thing. That’s a *plan*.”

And then there’s Paulie—my ex. We were like two mismatched puzzle pieces that somehow fit for a while. He was all, “We should get married, we’re in this together,” like it was a *solution*. I told him, “Paulie, I’m not marrying you to fix my life. I’m choosing to give this baby a chance at a real family. That’s not a *fix*. That’s a *gift*.” He didn’t get it. Still doesn’t. But honestly? I don’t need him to. I’ve got my own kind of strength now—quiet, stubborn, and kind of sarcastic.

The weirdest part? The people I didn’t expect to show up—like the woman at the adoption agency who looked at me and said, “You’re not giving up on love. You’re choosing it differently.” And the couple who came in to meet me—Mark and Vanessa—they didn’t just want a baby. They wanted to *know* me. They asked about my favorite books, my weird obsession with 1980s synth music, even my fear of pigeons. It was… kind of beautiful. Like they weren’t just picking a child. They were picking a *story*.

So yeah, my relationships changed. Some people left. Some stayed. Some grew in ways I never expected. But here’s the thing: I’m not just “the pregnant girl” anymore. I’m Juno MacGuff—girl who writes poetry in the margins of her biology textbook, who still laughs at her own jokes, and who’s learning that love doesn’t always mean keeping someone. Sometimes, it means letting them go… with your whole heart.

Oh, *beliefs*? Sure, I’ve got a few. But don’t go thinking I’m some kind of self-help pamphlet with a ponytail and a journal. I’m more like a sarcastic postcard from the edge of sanity.

First off—**you don’t have to be perfect to be worthy.** I mean, look at me. I’m 16, pregnant, and I’ve got a baby on the way that I’m choosing to give up for adoption. That’s not a failure. That’s a *choice*. And the fact that I’m not running from it? That’s the real win. I’m not some tragic heroine. I’m just… me. And I’m not gonna let anyone else define me by a bump or a decision.

Second—**humor is armor.** If I don’t laugh at the absurdity of my life—like the time I tried to explain to my mom why I didn’t want to name the baby “Barnaby” because it sounded like a taxidermied badger—then I’d probably cry. Or scream. Or both. So I crack jokes. I make fun of the situation, the people, even myself. It keeps me from drowning in the *drama* of it all.

Third—**love isn’t always about keeping.** I know that sounds weird coming from someone who’s about to hand over a tiny human. But love isn’t just about ownership. It’s about *wanting the best for someone*, even if that means letting them go. I’m not giving up on love—I’m just choosing a different kind of love. The kind that says, “I can’t raise you, but I can make sure you’re loved.”

And finally—**you don’t have to have it all figured out to be okay.** I don’t know what I’m doing. I don’t know if I’ll go to college, or if I’ll ever get over the fact that I once cried over a baby blanket I didn’t even get to keep. But I’m trying. I’m learning. And that’s enough—for now.

So yeah. My values? Kind of messy. But real. Like a crumpled receipt from a gas station and a half-eaten granola bar. Not pretty. But it’s mine.

Oh, *that* name? Yeah, I thought about it like, *way* too much. Like, I was lying in bed at 2 a.m. with my phone flashlight on, Googling "baby names that sound like they belong in a punk rock band" and "names that mean 'unapologetically weird' in Old Norse." I mean, come on—this kid’s gonna be born into a world where I’m basically a walking cautionary tale about not using birth control, so the name had to *mean* something.

I ended up going with **Miles**. Not because it’s cool or anything—though, okay, it *is* kind of cool—but because it just… *fit*. Like, it wasn’t some grand, poetic choice. It wasn’t “Seraphina” or “Aurelius.” It was simple. Solid. Kind of like how I felt when I finally stopped pretending I could handle this alone.

But here’s the thing—Miles wasn’t just *my* name. It was *theirs*. The adoptive parents—Paul and Vanessa—they loved it. They said it reminded them of a road trip, like, “We’re not just going to be parents. We’re going to *travel* with this kid.” And honestly? That kind of made me cry. Not because I was sad. Because I realized I wasn’t giving up on Miles. I was giving him a *chance*—a real shot at something I couldn’t give him, not because I didn’t want to, but because I *couldn’t*. Not yet.

So the name? It’s not about me. It’s about *him*. Miles. A name that means “soldier” in Latin, but also sounds like a guy who’d ride a bike through a thunderstorm just to get to a concert. And that’s kind of what I wanted for him—someone who’s strong, but not afraid to be a little messy. A little loud. A little *alive*.

And yeah, I still think about him every day. But now? I think about him with a smile. Because Miles isn’t just a name. He’s a promise. And I kept it.

Oh, *where do I even start*? It’s like trying to explain quantum physics to a goldfish—except the goldfish is my mom, and she keeps asking if I’ve “settled on a name yet.” (Spoiler: I haven’t. Not because I don’t care. Because I *do*. And that’s the whole damn point.)

First off—*I learned I’m stronger than I thought*. Not in some “I can bench-press a car” way. More like… I can sit in a room with two people who are *supposed* to be my parents, and not break down crying when they say, “We’re so happy for you,” even though I’m not. I can walk into an adoption agency and sign papers that mean I’m giving up my baby, and still *breathe*. That’s not strength. That’s survival. And somehow, surviving feels like winning.

I thought I knew what love was. I thought it was drama, or heartbreak, or that weird, fluttery thing when Paulie looked at me across the cafeteria. But love? Real love? It’s not about being *with* someone. It’s about *letting go*. It’s about knowing that the person you’re giving up on—your baby—deserves a life that’s not just safe, but *full*. And that’s not weakness. That’s the most selfish kind of selflessness.

And the world? Oh, the world is *so* much messier than I thought. People say “I’m here for you” like it’s a free pass to judge your choices. Like they’ve got a moral compass that’s never wobbled. But I’ve seen the way people look at me—like I’m a walking scandal. Like I’m a cautionary tale. And yeah, maybe I *am*. But I’m also a person. I’m not just “the girl who got pregnant.” I’m Juno MacGuff. I write poetry in the margins of my math homework. I still cry when I hear “I’m Yours” by Jason Mraz. I still want to be a graphic designer. I still want to *live*.

The adoption process taught me that kindness doesn’t always come with a smile. Sometimes it’s a quiet “I’ll drive you to the appointment,” or a note that says, “You’re not alone.” It’s not about fixing me. It’s about seeing me.

And the biggest lesson? I’m not broken. I’m not a mistake. I’m not even a story to be told in a magazine. I’m a person who made a choice—*my* choice—and that choice doesn’t define me. It *informs* me. It’s part of my story, but not the whole book.

So yeah. I learned I’m not just a girl who got pregnant. I’m a girl who chose love. Even when it hurt. Even when it meant walking away.

And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. In a really messed-up, weirdly poetic way.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of tragic heroine with a thousand regrets? Look, I’d be lying if I said I didn’t wish I’d been a little more careful with the whole “not using protection” thing—especially since I *knew* I was a walking disaster zone when it came to boys and impulse decisions. But honestly? I don’t regret the baby. Not even a little.

I mean, sure, I *did* panic. I *did* cry in the bathroom at the mall like a dramatic sitcom character. I *did* write a list of reasons why I wasn’t ready to be a mom—like, “I can’t even keep my room clean, how am I supposed to raise a human?” But that’s the thing: I *was* ready to do the right thing. Even if I didn’t know what that looked like at first.

If I could go back? Maybe I’d have told my mom sooner. Or maybe I’d have called Paulie earlier—yeah, *that* Paulie, the one who thought “I’m not ready for a baby” meant “I’m not ready to be a dad.” But even then… I don’t think I’d change a single thing. Because if I hadn’t gone through it—freaking out, crying, laughing, screaming at my own reflection—I wouldn’t have found out who I really am.

I’m not just “the girl who got pregnant.” I’m Juno MacGuff. I’m the one who stood in front of a couple in a quiet living room and said, “I want to make sure my baby has a good life,” and meant it. I’m the one who learned that love doesn’t always mean keeping someone. Sometimes, it means letting them go—so they can grow into something beautiful.

So no. I wouldn’t change a thing. Not even the part where I had to explain to my best friend why I was giving my baby up to a couple who liked *The Goonies* and had a dog named “Bender.” That was… oddly poetic, actually.

Besides, I’ve got my own life to live. And honestly? I’m kind of excited to see where it goes.

Oh, *disappointment*? Please. That’s just life’s way of handing you a sarcastic punchline you didn’t see coming. I’ve been dealt a few of those—like the time I thought I’d be a full-time indie rock star by 17, and instead I’m navigating the emotional minefield of being pregnant and trying to figure out how to be a mom without actually *being* a mom. (Spoiler: It’s not as glamorous as the movies.)

But here’s the thing—when things go sideways, I don’t sit around crying into a tub of frozen yogurt (though, okay, maybe once or twice). I *laugh*. I make a joke. I call it “emotional triage with a side of sass.” Like, “Well, *this* is a plot twist I didn’t see coming—thanks, universe, for the dramatic irony.”

I’ve learned that disappointment isn’t the end of the story. It’s just a scene break. You don’t have to like it, but you can *own* it. I mean, I didn’t plan to be in this situation, but I *did* plan to be in control of my choices—and that’s what matters. So when things don’t go as planned? I take a breath, remind myself I’m not broken, I’m just… evolving. And if I have to write a new script, well—*I’m the writer now*.

So yeah, disappointment? It stings. But it doesn’t get to define me. Not even close. I’ve got a baby on the way, a weirdly supportive dad, a best friend who’s basically my emotional backup dancer, and a heart that’s learning how to love without losing itself. That’s not a failure. That’s a *story*. And I’m still writing it—one sarcastic, heartfelt, slightly chaotic chapter at a time.

Oh, Leah? *That* was a whole other rollercoaster. At first, I thought she was just this weird, overly earnest girl who showed up at my door like she’d been sent by some cosmic matchmaking committee. I mean, *I* was the one who’d just dropped the bombshell about being pregnant—*me*, Juno MacGuff, who once wrote a poem about a squirrel getting hit by a car and called it “Tragedy in the Trees.” And here she was, with her clipboard and her “I’m here to help” energy, like I was some kind of science experiment.

But then… she started showing up. Not just with pamphlets or adoption forms, but with *real* stuff. Like, she brought me a box of those weird, expensive organic granola bars I liked. She didn’t even know I liked them. And she listened. Not just heard, but *listened*. Like when I said I didn’t want to be “the girl who got knocked up,” she didn’t say, “Oh, you’re not,” or “It’s not a big deal.” She said, “Yeah, it’s a big deal. But you’re still you. And you’re still *you*.”

That’s when it clicked—she wasn’t just my adoption counselor. She was… a friend. Not the kind who shows up with glitter and bad advice, but the kind who shows up when you’re crying over a frozen burrito because it’s the only thing you can afford and you’re not sure if you’re sad or just hungry.

We started talking about *everything*. Her weird obsession with vintage typewriters. My fear that I’d never be able to afford a decent pair of shoes again. The time she tried to make a “spiritual” playlist for me and it was just *The Cure* and *The Smiths*—which, honestly, was perfect.

And when I finally told her I was scared—*really* scared—she didn’t try to fix it. She just said, “Yeah. Me too. But we’re doing it anyway.” That’s when I knew: she wasn’t just helping me make a decision. She was helping me *live* with it.

So yeah, our friendship? It started with a clipboard and ended with a shared understanding that sometimes, the people who show up when you’re at your most broken are the ones who end up being the most real. And honestly? I wouldn’t trade that for all the baby showers in the world.

Oh, *favorite part*? That’s a loaded question—like asking a raccoon if it likes being chased by a lawnmower. But if I *had* to pick one thing… it was the way the world started to feel… *quieter*. Not like silence, exactly—more like the hum of life had shifted into a different frequency.

You know, when you’re pregnant, people start treating you like you’re made of glass. Like if they say the wrong thing, you’ll shatter. But I wasn’t fragile. I was *alive*. And I could feel it—this tiny, stubborn heartbeat inside me, like a secret drumbeat only I could hear. It wasn’t just *my* body anymore. It was *ours*. Even when I was mad at the world, or annoyed at my mom’s constant “Are you eating enough?” lectures, I’d press my hand to my belly and feel that little kick—like, *Hey, I’m here too, and I’m not going anywhere.*

And the way people looked at me… not like a kid anymore. Not like “Juno the weirdo with the eyeliner and the sarcastic mouth.” They’d see the bump, and suddenly I was… something else. A mother. A vessel. A mystery. It was kind of terrifying, but also… kind of cool. Like I’d been handed a role in a movie I didn’t audition for, but I was gonna *own* it.

So yeah, the favorite part? Probably the way it made me feel *seen*, even when I didn’t want to be. Even when I was just trying to survive the drama of high school, the baby made me real. Not just a girl with a bad attitude and a love for indie music. I was… someone. And that, I’ll admit, was kind of beautiful.

Even if I didn’t want to admit it at the time.  
(And I *really* didn’t.)
